questions.text: Name the type of joint marked in the following image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Saddle joint

Explanation:

  • Articulating surfaces between the malleus and incus are saddle-shaped i.e. one surface is convex while the other is concave.
  • Saddle synovial joint:
    • Examples include
      • Joint between malleus and incus.
      • Sternoclavicular joint.
      • 1st carpometacarpal joint.
      • Calcaneocuboid joint.

Type of joint

Examples

Hinge Joint

Elbow joint, Knee joint, Interphalangeal joints

Pivot Joint

Superior radioulnar joint, C1 and C2 joint (Option C)

Ball-and-Socket Joint

Shoulder (glenohumeral) joint, Hip joint, Incus, and stapes joint (Option A)

Saddle Joint

Sternoclavicular joint, Carpometacarpal joint of the thumb, Joint between the malleus and the incus.

Ellipsoid (Condyloid) Joint

Radiocarpal (wrist) joint, atlantooccipital joint, Metacarpophalangeal joints

Gliding Joint (Option D):

  • Examples: Lateral end of clavicle and acromion process(acromioclavicular joint).
  • Gliding joints (also known as plane joints) have flat surfaces that glide or slide past each other.
  • They allow for limited movement in various directions, such as sliding or twisting.

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the Gluteus maximus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inferior gluteal nerve
 

Explanation:

  • The inferior gluteal nerve (from the sacral plexus, specifically from L5, S1, and S2 nerve roots) primarily innervates the gluteus maximus muscle.
  • It arises from the posterior division of the sacral plexus and passes through the greater sciatic foramen to reach the gluteal region.
  • This nerve provides motor innervation to the gluteus maximus, which is the largest muscle in the buttocks and plays a significant role in movements such as hip extension and external rotation.

Action of the Hip joint, corresponding muscles, and their innervation:

Action

Muscles

Nerve supply

 

 

 

Flexion
  • Psoas major (chief flexor)

Anterior rami of L1, L2, L3
  • Iliacus (chief flexor)
  • Sartorius
  • Rectus femoris
  • Pectineus

 

Femoral nerve (L2, L3) (Option A)

 

 

Extension
  • Gluteus maximus (chief extensor)

Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • Hamstring muscles

 

Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)

 

 

Abduction
  • Gluteus medius and minimus (chief abductors)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)

 

 

 

 

Adduction
  • Adductor longus
  • Adductor brevis
  • Adductor magnus (chief adductors)
  • Gracilis

Obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4) (Option C)
  • Pectineus

 

Double nerve supply (Femoral nerve and obturator nerve)

 

 

Medial rotation
  • Anterior fibres of gluteus minimus and medius (chief medial rotators)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)

(Option D)

 

 

 

 

 

 

Lateral rotation
  • Piriformis

Ventral rami of S1, S2
  • Obturator externus

Posterior division of obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Obturator internus and
  • Associated gemelli,
  • Quadratus femoris (These muscles are generally termed short rotators)

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of blood in her stools. Physical exam reveals firm, enlarged inguinal lymph nodes. A contrast CT scan is performed and a possibly cancerous mass is visualized in the lower part of the gastrointestinal tract. In which location is the mass most likely located?

choices.text: Anal canal inferior to the pectinate line

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anal canal inferior to the pectinate line

Explanation:

  • Lymphatic drainage from this region primarily goes to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.
  • A cancerous mass in this location would lead to enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes, as seen in this patient.

Distal rectum (Option B): This option is incorrect as lymph from the inferior part of the anal canal drains to the superficial inguinal nodes.

Sigmoid colon (Option C): This option is incorrect as sigmoid colon lymph nodes drain to the inferior mesenteric nodes.

Proximal rectum (Option D): This option is incorrect as the proximal rectum drains to the sacral nodes.

questions.text: The fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis contribute to which wall of the inguinal canal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Roof

Explanation:

The roof of the inguinal canal is formed by the fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles. These muscles contribute to the structure that covers the canal from above.

The inguinal canal is a passageway in the lower abdominal wall.

Contents of the inguinal canal:

  • In males: Spermatic cord and ilioinguinal nerve
  • In females: Round ligament of the uterus and ilioinguinal nerve

 

The boundaries of the inguinal canal are:

  • Anterior wall: It is formed from superficial to deep by: (Option A)
    • Skin
    • Superficial fascia in its extent.
    • External oblique aponeurosis
    • Internal oblique muscle fibers, in lateral one-third.
  • Posterior wall: It is formed from deep to superficial by: (Option B)
    • Fascia transversalis, in the whole extent
    • Conjoint tendon, in medial two-third
    • Reflected part of the inguinal ligament, in the medial-most part.
  • Roof: It is formed by the lower arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles.
  • Floor: It is formed by: (Option D)
    • Grooved upper surface of the inguinal ligament in the whole extent
    • Abdominal surface of the lacunar ligament at the medial end.

                                                             Fig: Contents of Inguinal canal

                                                            Fig: Inguinal canal boundaries

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect regarding the Adrenal gland?

choices.text: The left adrenal gland is present below the spleen
The right adrenal gland is crescent in shape

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The right adrenal gland is crescent in shape

Explanation:

The right adrenal gland is triangular or pyramidal, not crescent-shaped.

Right Adrenal Gland

  • Shape: Pyramidal
  • Parts:
    • Base: Below, overlaps the upper end of the right kidney.
    • Apex: Above, anterior surface presents a hilum.
    • Anterior Surface:
      • Medial area: Related to the inferior vena cava (IVC).
      • Lateral area: Related to the liver.
    • Posterior Surface:
      • Upper area: Related to the diaphragm.
      • Lower area: Related to the kidney.
    • Borders:
      • Lateral: Overlapped by the liver.
      • Medial: Related to:
        • Below: Celiac ganglion.
        • Above: Inferior phrenic artery.

Left Adrenal Gland

  • Shape: Semilunar
  • Parts:
    • Lower End: Rounded, anterior surface presents hilum.
    • Upper End: Narrow, related to the medial end of the spleen (Option B)
    • Anterior Surface:
      • Upper area: Related to the stomach bed.
      • Lower area: Overlapped by the body of the pancreas and crossed by the tortuous splenic artery.
    • Posterior Surface:
      • Lateral area: Related to the left kidney.
      • Medial area: Related to the left crus of the diaphragm.
    • Borders:
      • Lateral: Overlaps the left kidney.
      • Medial: Related to:
        • Below: Celiac ganglion.
        • Above: Inferior phrenic artery.

Yellow-colored structures (Option A): The adrenal cortex tends to exhibit a yellowish hue due to its higher fat content, while the adrenal medulla appears more reddish-brown in color.

It is located retroperitoneally (Option D): The adrenal glands are situated on top of each kidney in the retroperitoneal space.

questions.text: Which of the following drains into the IVC?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Left renal vein

Explanation:

 

Left Renal Vein directly drains into the Inferior Vena Cava (IVC). This vein receives blood from the left kidney and left gonadal vein.

 

 

Inferior vena cava:

  • Origin: Formed by the union of the right and left common iliac veins at the level of L5 vertebra.
  • Termination: Opens into the lower and posterior part of the right atrium.
  • Course: It ascends along the front of the vertebral column, positioned to the right of the aorta, creates a groove on the posterior surface of the liver, and passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm at the T8 vertebral level.

Tributaries of IVC

Key features

Right and left 3rd and 4th lumbar veins

It drains the posterior, lateral, and anterior abdominal walls into IVC.

Right gonadal vein

Left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava.

Right suprarenal vein

Left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava.

Right inferior phrenic vein

Left inferior phrenic vein drains into the left suprarenal, or left renal vein.

Right and left renal veins

Left renal vein (7.5cm) is three times longer than right renal vein (2.5cm)

Hepatic veins

Three large and many small veins open directly into the anterior surface of the inferior vena cava just before it pierces the diaphragm.

Left Gonadal Vein (Option A):

The left gonadal vein (left testicular vein in males or left ovarian vein in females) drains into the left renal vein, and then the blood flows into the IVC.

Left adrenal vein (Option B):

The left adrenal vein also drains into the left renal vein, which eventually connects to the IVC.

Right ascending lumbar vein (Option D):

  • Right ascending lumbar vein drain into the azygous vein
  • Azygous vein is on right side
  • Azygous will drain in Superior Vena Cava (SVC) at T4 level

questions.text: Lateral plantar nerve supplies which of the following muscles?

choices.text: Flexor digitorum brevis, Abductor hallucis, Flexor hallucis brevis
Flexor digitorum brevis, Abductor hallucis, Extensor digitorum brevis
Flexor digiti minimi brevis, Abductor hallucis, Abductor digiti minimi
Flexor digiti minimi brevis, Abductor digiti minimi, Adductor hallucis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Flexor digiti minimi brevis, Abductor digiti minimi, Adductor hallucis

Explanation:

The lateral plantar nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve and supplies several muscles in the foot, mainly located in the lateral side and the deep layers of the sole.

Muscles supplied by the lateral plantar nerve:

  • Abductor digiti minimi
  • Flexor digiti minimi brevis
  • Adductor hallucis
  • Quadratus plantae
  • 2nd, 3rd, and 4th lumbricals
  • Plantar interossei
  • Dorsal interossei

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pulmonary trunk

Explanation:

  • The marked structure in the given image is the pulmonary trunk.
  • The pulmonary trunk starts from the upper part of the right ventricle, near the left 3rd costal cartilage, and runs backward and leftward.
  • It ends beneath the aortic arch, in front of the left principal bronchus, dividing into the right and left pulmonary arteries.

(Options A, B, and C ruled out)

Main pulmonary trunk:

  • Pulmonary trunk - Carries blood to the pulmonary circulation.
  • The pulmonary trunk, originating from the upper right ventricle, is approximately 5 cm long.
  • It curves back and to the left through the middle mediastinum before dividing into the right and left pulmonary arteries below the aortic arch and in front of the left bronchus.
  • Divides into left and right at the T4-T5 level.

questions.text: The correct sequence of the auditory pathway?

choices.text: Cochlea → Spiral Ganglion → Cochlear Nerve → Superior Olivary Nucleus
Spiral Ganglion → Cochlea → Cochlear Nerve → Superior Olivary Nucleus
Spiral Ganglion → Cochlear Nerve → Cochlea → Superior Olivary Nucleus
Cochlea → Spiral Ganglion → Cochlear Nerve → Inferior Olivary Nucleus

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is: Cochlea → Spiral Ganglion → Cochlear Nerve → Superior Olivary Nucleus

Auditory pathway:

  1. Cochlea
  2. Cochlear Nerve
  3. Cochlear Nucleus (in the brainstem)
  4. Superior Olivary Complex
  5. Lateral Lemniscus
  6. Inferior Colliculus (in the midbrain)
  7. Medial Geniculate Nucleus (in the thalamus)
  8. Primary Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals are sent to the primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe (Heschl’s gyrus), where sound perception, including the identification of pitch, rhythm and speech occurs.

questions.text: Which of the following ribs is fractured in the X-ray given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 6

Explanation:

The X-ray in the question displays a fracture at the 6th rib on the left side.

To count ribs:

  • Start counting from the costo-vertebral junction. Locate the first rib and trace its outline from posterior to anterior aspect.
  • Immediately below it you will find the second rib.
  • Similarly you can count the rest of the ribs on the radiograph.
  • Most rib fractures can be diagnosed as discontinuity in the outline of the rib on the radiograph.
  • Some rib fractures (especially those of the lateral part of the ribs) may not be visible on a PA view and may need an oblique view.
  • In doubtful cases, a CT Chest may resolve the query. In clinical practice, rib fractures are diagnosed using clinical and radiological findings.

questions.text: What is the name of the test performed in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Allen's test

Explanation:

Image shows Allen’s test, used to evaluate the patency of radial and ulnar arteries supplying the hand.

 

Allen's test:

  • The examiner compresses both arteries at the wrist while the patient clenches their fist to drain blood from the hand.
  • Subsequently, pressure on one artery is released, and the return of hand colour is observed.
  • A rapid colour return indicates an adequate blood supply from that artery.
  • It ensures an adequate collateral circulation and is especially useful before procedures such as arterial blood gas sampling or harvesting the radial artery for grafting.

Incorrect Options:

Adson test (Option B): Adson's test is a provocative test for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome accompanied by compression of the subclavian artery by a cervical rib or tightened anterior and middle scalene muscles.

Barbeau test (Option C): The Barbeau test is another method for assessing the patency of the arterial palmar arch. It utilizes pulse oximetry and plethysmography to assess the palmar arches, so this choice is incorrect.

Homan's test (Option D): The Homan's test is a physical examination procedure used to diagnose Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). A positive Homan’s sign in the presence of other clinical signs may be a quick indicator of DVT, so this choice is incorrect.

questions.text: All of the following organs or tissues demonstrate insulin-dependent glucose uptake, except for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Adipose tissue

Explanation:

  • Adipose tissue has GLUT 4 transporter which mediates insulin-stimulated glucose uptake.
  • GLUT proteins are distributed in various tissues according to their specific functions.

Glucose Transporters:

Transporter

Tissue Location

Functions

GLUT 1

Brain, kidney, colon, placenta, erythrocytes

Facilitates glucose uptake

GLUT 2

Liver, pancreatic β cells, small intestine, kidney

Enables rapid glucose uptake or release

GLUT 3

Brain, kidney, placenta

Assists in glucose uptake

GLUT 4

Heart and skeletal muscle, adipose tissue

Mediates insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

GLUT 5

Small intestine

Facilitates fructose absorption

SGLT 1

Small intestine and kidney

Actively transports glucose against a concentration gradient
  • GLUT 1-5 are facilitative bidirectional transporters, whereas SGLT 1 is a sodium-dependent unidirectional transporter.

questions.text: A 14 year old male presents with a mushroom like tumor in the distal femur for the past 2 years. Which of the following features suggest its malignant transformation?

choices.text: Bone marrow is continuous with the parent bone
The cartilaginous growth goes towards the joint

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thickness of cartilage cap > 2cm

Explanation:

MRI showing thickness of cartilage cap >2 cms is suggestive of malignant transformation in Osteochondroma.

Osteochondroma:

Description
  • Also known as Exostosis
  • Most common primary benign bone tumor (but not a true bone tumor)
  • Benign cartilaginous neoplasms arising from physeal cartilage beneath the periosteum.
  • More common in males, usually appearing during adolescence.
  • Affects long bones, lower end of femur > upper end of tibia

Types
  • Solitary Osteochondroma
  • Multiple Osteochondromas (MO)

Clinical features
  • Painless mass- most common presentation
  • Pain: secondary to bursa formation/fracture/nerve compression

Radiographic Appearance
  • X-ray: Pedunculated cauliflower-like mass originating from metaphysis
  • MRI: used to assess cartilage thickness

Malignant transformation
  • Very rare
  • MRI showing cartilage thickness > 2 cms suggests malignant transformation (Option A)

Management
  • Asymptomatic cases: No treatment required
  • Symptomatic cases: Excision with biopsy

questions.text: In the case of an ongoing bleeding in a patient with a fracture of the pelvic bone, what is the immediate action that needs to be taken to address the situation, if the patient is in hypotension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Crystalloids

Explanation:

In a case of pelvic bone fracture with hypotension, the immediate next step will be to administer crystalloids and stabilise the patient.

Management steps to be followed in this patient:

  • Assessment of vital signs and initiation of ATLS protocol - administration of crystalloids.
  • Pelvic binder is applied to reduce bleeding and maintain hemostasis. (Option D)
  • An external fixator is then applied until the patient's hemodynamic status is stable, followed by internal definite fixation once the patient is fit for surgery.

Complications and Management of Pelvic fracture:

Shock:

  • Hemorrhagic shock from pelvic injury is the most common cause of mortality (30%).
  • Management:
  • Initial Management: Primary survey (ABCDE) and simultaneous resuscitation as per Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines. (Option A)
  • Laparotomy: Immediate laparotomy if the patient remains unstable.
  • Preperitoneal Packing (PPP): Used to create a tamponade effect.
  • Resuscitative Endovascular Balloon Occlusion of the Aorta (REBOA): Uses balloon catheter to occlude the aorta in life-threatening hemorrhage ; Can be inflated for up to 60 minutes ; Intermittent inflation helps with resuscitation and reduces reperfusion injury.
  • Surgical Fixation for Unstable Pelvic Fractures:
  • External Fixation: Provides initial stabilization, particularly in hemodynamically unstable patients. Pins are placed in the iliac wings or anterior inferior iliac spine. (Option B)
  • Definitive Repair: Undertaken once the patient is stable ; Various techniques include anterior symphyseal plating, ORIF of the ilium, or sacroiliac screw placement depending on the fracture type. (Option C)

Urethral Injuries:

  • More common in males, with the membranous urethra being the most commonly affected site.
  • Rupture can be complete or incomplete, partial or full thickness.
  • Cardinal signs of urethral injury: Blood at the urethral meatus, perineal hematoma, distended bladder.
  • Treatment:
    • Drainage of the bladder via suprapubic cystostomy.
    • Micturating cysto-urethrogram after 6 weeks to assess for urethral stricture, followed by appropriate treatment.

Bladder Injuries:

  • Extraperitoneal injuries are treated nonoperatively.
  • Intraperitoneal injuries require surgical repair.

Sigmoid and Rectal Injuries:

  • Intraperitoneal injuries are debrided and primarily repaired if possible.
  • Extraperitoneal rectal injuries are managed with primary repair and diverting colostomy.

Vaginal Lacerations: First-degree injuries are treated with gauze packing; second- and third-degree injuries require surgical repair.

questions.text: In the emergency room, a 40-year-old male patient arrived with a complaint of pain and swelling in the right shoulder region following a fall. The patient's X-ray indicates a tear in which of the following ligaments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Both the above

Explanation:

Above X-ray indicates grade-III injury of the Acromioclavicular joint as per Rockwood classification. In grade-III injury, both coracoclavicular and acromioclavicular ligaments are disrupted.

Acromioclavicular joint injuries:

Description
  • Acute acromioclavicular (AC) joint injury, commonly following direct trauma; includes sprains, subluxations, and dislocations.

Mechanism of Injury
  • Fall on the shoulder with arm adducted leading to ligament strain or tear. Severe forces may cause complete dislocation.

Classification
  • Type I: AC ligament sprain; joint remains undisplaced.
  • Type II: AC ligaments torn; joint subluxated with slight clavicle elevation.
  • Type III: AC and coracoclavicular ligaments torn; joint dislocated, visible step deformity. (Option C)
  • Type IV: Posterior clavicle displacement.
  • Type V: Marked upward clavicle displacement.
  • Type VI: Inferior clavicle displacement beneath the coracoid.

Clinical Features
  • Signs: Pain, bruising, and tenderness at the injury site. Visible ‘step’ in cases of dislocation.
  • Movement: Limited shoulder movement with severe pain in dislocation.

X-ray
  • Views: Anteroposterior, cephalic tilt, and axillary views are recommended. Stress view may differentiate Type II vs Type III.
  • Stress View: Measure the distance between the coracoid and clavicle; >50% difference indicates dislocation.

Treatment
  • Sprains/Subluxations: Rest in a sling, pain subsides within a week, followed by shoulder exercises.
  • Dislocations: Techniques include ligament reconstruction or clavicle excision.
  • Post-surgery Rehab: Elbow/forearm exercises day after surgery, shoulder movements 2 weeks later. Avoid strenuous lifting for 4–6 months.

questions.text: For which type of fractures does the Hawkins classification apply?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Talus

Explanation:

Hawkin’s classification is used for fractures of the neck of the talus.

Hawkin’s classification:

Type I

Undisplaced fracture of the talar neck.

Type II

Displaced fracture with subluxation or dislocation of the subtalar joint.

Type III

Displaced fracture with dislocation of the talus body from the ankle joint.

Type IV

Displaced vertical talar neck fracture with associated disruption of the talonavicular joint.

 

Tibia (Option B): The Schatzker classification is used for categorizing tibial fracture

Humerus (Option C): The Neer's Classification is used for categorizing humerus head fracture.

Calcaneus (Option D): The Sanders classification is primarily used for categorizing fractures of the calcaneus.

questions.text:
Calculate the anion gap:

Na- 145mmol/L

K- 4mmol/L

Cl- 90mmol/L

HCO3- 15mmol/L
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 44

Explanation:

Anion Gap = (Na⁺ + K⁺) – (Cl⁻ + HCO₃⁻)

= (145+4) - (90+15)

= 44

Anion gap:

Definition

The difference between the measured cations and the measured anions in the extracellular fluid (ECF).

Cations (Measured)

Sodium (Na⁺) and Potassium (K⁺)

Anions (Measured)

Chloride (Cl⁻) and Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻)

Unmeasured Anions

Protein anions, sulfate, phosphate, and organic acids.

Reason for Anion Gap

The unmeasured anions cause the difference between the measured cations and anions.

Formula

Anion Gap = (Na⁺ + K⁺) – (Cl⁻ + HCO₃⁻)

Normal Value

~12 mmol/L

questions.text: A child was being delivered oxygen by nasal cannula at 3L/min. What is the FiO2 being delivered?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) 30%

Explanation:

  • For each liter per minute (L/min) of oxygen flow, you can estimate an increase in FiO2 of about 4%. 1L/min of O2 corresponds to an FIO2 of 24%
  • In this case, with an oxygen flow rate of 3 L/min, the FiO2 delivered is approximately 32%

Nasal cannula:

  • Used in low to medium concentrations of O2 (22-44%)
  • When these are attached to the flow meter which is connected to the central pipeline supply of an ICU or cylinders and is turned on at 1L per minute, these deliver oxygen of about 24%.
  • Atmospheric oxygen is from 20 to 21%
  • When the concentration of oxygen is increased, it leads to an increase in the concentration of FIO2
  • This device can only deliver up to 6L per minute
  • Every liter corresponds to its subsequent FiO2:
    • 1 L/min-24%
    • 2 L/min-28%
    • 3 L/min-32%
    • 4 L/min-36%
    • 5 L/min-40%
    • 6 L/min-44%
  • This device is not beneficial for a capacity of > 6 liters
  • Advantages: Patients can talk and eat with 02 support when using a nasal cannula and a nasal cannula can be used in home settings.
  • Disadvantages: It may irritate nasal and pharyngeal mucosa. If the flow is given for more than 6L, the FiO2 may vary.

 

24% (Option A): An FiO2 of 24% corresponds to 1L/min of oxygen.

44% (Option C): An FiO2 of 44% corresponds to 6L/min of oxygen.

40% (Option D): An FiO2 of 40% corresponds to 5L/min of oxygen.

questions.text:
Steps of intubation sequence are:

a. Flexion of lower cervical spine and extension of Atlanto-occipital joint

b. Inflate cuff of endotracheal tube

c. Introduce a laryngoscope from the right side of mouth

d. Confirm the position of tube
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) a, c, b, d

Explanation:

Steps of intubation:

  • Flexion of the lower cervical spine and extension of the atlanto-occipital joint. It is an optimal and ideal position for intubation (also called the Morning sniffing position).
  • If you are a right-handed person then you will hold the laryngoscope in your left hand and start entering from the right side of patient’s mouth till you see the epiglottis, once the epiglottis is visible, push the epiglottis anteriorly in adults then vocal cords will be visible
  • After this place the endotracheal tube, then inflate it.
  • Cuff pressure should not exceed 25

questions.text: Decreased % transferrin saturation is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Iron deficiency anemia

Explanation:

Laboratory findings in iron deficiency anemia:

Hemoglobin Indices

Low Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH), Low Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)

Peripheral Blood Smear

Microcytosis, Hypochromia, Anisocytosis

Serum Ferritin

Decreased

Serum Iron

Decreased

Transferrin Saturation

Decreased

Total Iron-Binding Capacity

Increased

Stool for Occult Blood

May be positive

Mentzer Index

>15

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis

Normal

Bone Marrow Aspiration/Biopsy

Iron stores absent on staining
  • In the rest of the conditions, the % transferrin saturation is normal or increased

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the pediatric ER in acute respiratory distress. On examination, the abdomen is scaphoid. Which of the following should not be performed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Bag and mask ventilation

Explanation:

  • A neonate with acute respiratory distress with a scaphoid could potentially be experiencing complications of a diaphragmatic hernia.
  • Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) patients due to the risk of worsening respiratory distress and increasing intrathoracic pressure, which can further impede lung expansion and exacerbate the hernia.

 

Management of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia:

  • Initial Stabilization:
    • Airway Management:
      • Immediate endotracheal intubation (ET) is critical. (Option D ruled out)
      • ECMO: If there is no response to ET
    • Avoid excessive, mean airway pressure to prevent barotrauma
    • Gastric Decompression: An orogastric tube is inserted to prevent gastric distention that worsens lung compression.
    • Bag and Mask Ventilation is Contraindicated in CDH

  • Surgical Repair is done only after pulmonary stabilisation in CDH (Immediate surgery done in case of Traumatic Hernia)

 

PPV (Positive Pressure Ventilation) (Option A): This can be performed but should be done carefully to avoid overinflating the stomach, which can worsen respiratory distress. Intubation with PPV is preferred.

Oxygen therapy (Option C): This is safe and can help improve oxygenation but is usually insufficient alone for severe respiratory distress in CDH.

questions.text: A farmer presents with fever and physical examination findings as seen in the image. His serum creatinine is 1.4 mg/dL, and platelet count is 88,000/mm³. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Scrub typhus

Explanation:

Scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by Trombiculid mites (chiggers).

  • Characteristic eschar (necrotic ulcer with a black scab) is seen at the site of the mite bite.
  • Common in farmers and individuals exposed to rural, wooded, or grassy areas.
  • Other features include fever, thrombocytopenia, acute kidney injury (AKI), hepatosplenomegaly, and rash.

Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

Anthrax (Option B): Cutaneous anthrax presents with painless ulcers with black eschar but has extensive surrounding edema and is more commonly seen in individuals handling animal hides or wool.

Leptospirosis (Option C): Causes Weil’s disease with jaundice, renal failure, and hemorrhage, but does not present with an eschar. Common in farmers exposed to rodent-contaminated water.

Brucellosis (Option D): Presents with undulant fever, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly, and endocarditis, but no eschar is seen. More common in people working with livestock or unpasteurized dairy products.

questions.text: What is the order of the band in the sarcomere?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Z-I-A-H-M

Explanation:

 

 

Sarcomere

The functional unit of a myofibril, composed of alternating dark A bands and light I bands.

Z Line

A dense, narrow line that bisects the I band; contains 2 actin molecules.

I Band

The light band alternating with the dark A band; bisected by the Z line.

A Band

The dark band in the sarcomere; includes the central H zone and is composed of thick filaments.

H Zone

The lighter region in the center of the A band.

M Line

The dark line in the middle of the H zone; contains M protein.

questions.text: What should be the next course of action in managing a patient with pneumonia who is on a ventilator, weighs 50 kg, has a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, a bicarbonate level of 18, a pH of 7.33, a paCO2 level of 48 mmHg, a Pao2 level of 110 mmHg, a PEEP of 12 cm H₂O, a tidal volume of 420 mL, and a SpO2 level of 100% with an FiO2 of 90%?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Decrease FiO₂

Explanation:

  • Lung Protective Ventilation is the current standard in mechanical ventilation. If Fio2 > 60%, oxygen radical formation can occur causing worsening of symptoms.
  • FIO2 has to be decreased in this patient to prevent free radical formation and since PaO2 is higher than normal.

Clinical Modes of Management in ARDS

  • Lung Protective Ventilation (LPV):
    • Tidal volumes: ≤6 mL/kg of ideal body weight to prevent alveolar overdistension. (Option D ruled out)
    • PEEP: Use moderate levels to avoid alveolar collapse. (Option A ruled out)
    • Plateau pressure: Limit to ≤30 cm H₂O to minimize barotrauma and pneumothorax.
    • Permissive hypercapnia: Allow mild-to-moderate respiratory acidosis to avoid lung injury. (Option C ruled out)
    • FiO₂: Minimize while targeting PaO₂ >55 mmHg or SpO₂ >88%. (Option B)
  • Recruitment Strategies:
    • Use of PEEP to recruit collapsed alveoli and improve oxygenation.
    • Prone positioning: Shown to improve survival in severe ARDS (P/F ratio ≤150).
  • Advanced Techniques:
    • Neuromuscular blockade: Early use may benefit patients with severe ARDS (P/F ratio <150).
    • ECMO: Considered for severe, refractory ARDS in specialized centers.
  • Rescue Therapies (Limited evidence for survival benefit):
    • High-frequency oscillatory ventilation: No significant outcome improvements.
    • Inhaled vasodilators (iNO, prostaglandins): Transient oxygenation improvement but no long-term benefit.
  • Fluid Management:
    • Conservative fluid management: Improves oxygenation and ventilator-free days.
  • Corticosteroids: Mixed results; may benefit ARDS from bacterial sepsis but not viral pneumonia (except SARS-CoV2).

questions.text: Which part of the haemoglobin molecule does 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) bind to in order to regulate oxygen release?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Beta chains of haemoglobin

Explanation:

  • 2,3-BPG binds within the central cavity of the deoxyhaemoglobin tetramer.

  • It interacts with positively charged residues (mainly lysine and histidine) on the β-chains.

  • This binding stabilises the T (tense) state, lowering haemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen and promoting oxygen delivery to tissues.

Effect of 2,3 BPG on Hb:

  • Reduces the affinity of Hb for oxygen and helps unload oxygen to tissues.
  • A by-product of glycolysis. (Rapaport Leubering Cycle)

 

 

Alpha chains of haemoglobin (Option A):
Incorrect because 2,3-BPG binds primarily to residues on the β-chains, not the α-chains.

Heme iron centre (Option B):
2,3-BPG does not bind directly to heme or iron; it acts allosterically, not at the active oxygen-binding site.

Globin-heme interface (Option D):
This is the site of coordination between globin and heme, not where 2,3-BPG binds.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents with fever and retro-orbital headache for 2 days. Her Tourniquet test and NS1 antigen are positive, suggesting Dengue infection. Which of the following findings qualifies as a severe dengue criterion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) AST and ALT >1000

Explanation:

  • Severe dengue (Dengue hemorrhagic fever grade III & IV / Dengue shock syndrome) criteria include:
    • Severe plasma leakage → leading to shock or fluid accumulation (pleural effusion/ascites).
    • Severe bleeding.
    • Severe organ involvement:
      • Liver: AST/ALT >1000 U/L (marker of severe hepatitis).
      • CNS involvement: Encephalitis, seizures.
      • Myocarditis, renal failure.

Clinical presentation of Dengue:

Uncategorised fever

  • No typical features

Break bone fever

(Classical dengue fever/ acute viral infection)

 
  • Retro orbital pain
  • Arthralgia
  • Severe myalgia and headache
  • Bimodal presentation of fever:
    • 39-40°C, peaks on days 1-2
    • Resurges: day 5-6
    • Recovery: day 7-10.
  • Rash: pin-point eruptions on the face, neck and chest followed by maculopapular or scarlatiniform on 3rd or 4th day.

Dengue haemorrhagic syndrome
  • Dengue fever + hemorrhagic manifestations(bleeding from any orifice)
  • Rash: Maculopapular/ Rubelliform
  • Lab diagnosis
    • 20% increase in hematocrit
    • Thrombocytopenia (<1 lac)
  • Clinical diagnosis
    • Tourniquet test- >10 petechiae/ sq inch area

Dengue shock syndrome
  • Pulse pressure - <20 mmHg
  • Mean systolic pressure - <90mmHg: adults, <80 mmHg: children.

Dengue complications

Neurological
  • Dengue encephalopathy is most commonly encountered neurological complication of dengue virus
    • linked primarily to dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome
    • EEG may show abnormalities such as burst suppression and seizures
    • CSF profiles typically remain normal.
    • Neuroimaging can be normal or reveal diffuse cerebral edema.
  • Encephalitis
  • GBS
  • Stroke

Cardiomyopathy
  • Dengue virus-induced dilated cardiomyopathy should always be considered if a dengue fever patient has refractory shock and signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure.

Hepatic injury
  • Liver involvement in dengue is a crucial feature
  • The effect ranges from an asymptomatic rise in liver enzymes to the development of ALF
  • The most common atypical manifestation reported was hepatitis

Pneumonia

 
  • Staphylococcus pneumonia is an important accompanying problem seen in dengue patient
  • co-infection between dengue and influenza can result in exacerbation of pneumonia

Orchitis

 
  • Orchitis usually occurs together with epididymitis
  • Commonly seen in men between 14 and 35 years of age.

Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever

All of the following:

  • Acute onset of fever
  • 2-7 days duration
  • Hemorrhagic manifestations
    • Positive tourniquet test/Petechiae
    • Ecchymosis
    • Purpura/Bleeding from mucosa, GIT, Injection sites, etc
  • Platelet count ≤ 100,000 cells/cu.mm.
  • Plasma leakage
    • Rising hematocrit
      • Hemoconcentration >20%
    • Pleural effusion, ascites/Hypoproteinemia)

Dengue Shock Syndrome
  • DHF criteria plus Signs of Shock
  • Tachycardia/Cool extremities/Weak pulse/Lethargy/Restlessness
  • Pulse pressure <20 mm Hg with increased Diastolic pressure (e.g. 100/80)
  • Hypotension (Systolic <80 mm Hg for age <5 years/80-90 mm Hg for older children and adults)

Leucopenia plus thrombocytopenia (Option A): Thrombocytopenia (<100,000/mm³) and leucopenia are common findings in dengue fever, but they do not indicate severe dengue unless associated with bleeding, shock, or organ involvement.

Persistent vomiting (Option B): It is a warning sign for dengue progression, but alone does not classify as severe dengue.

Hepatomegaly >1 cm (Option C): Mild hepatomegaly is seen in dengue, but it becomes severe only when associated with AST/ALT >1000 U/L.

questions.text: An 18-day-old baby presents with fever and cough. On examination, vesicles are observed over the trunk and upper limb. The mother had genital ulcers one year ago, which have since resolved. Biopsy of the vesicles reveals multinucleated giant cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Herpes simplex virus (HSV)

Explanation:

Neonatal HSV infection typically results from vertical transmission during vaginal delivery, especially if the mother had genital HSV infection.

  • The presence of vesicles in a newborn with a maternal history of genital ulcers strongly suggests neonatal herpes simplex infection.
  • Microscopic features
    • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground-glass' chromatin (Tzanck cells).
    • Formation of Lipschutz bodies (Cowdry type A).

Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV) (Option B): MCV causes pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication, not vesicles.

Human papillomavirus (HPV) (Option C): HPV is associated with warts, not vesicular lesions.

Varicella (Option D): Varicella (chickenpox) also causes vesicular rash, but it is less likely in a neonate unless there is maternal varicella exposure close to delivery. Multinucleated giant cells can be seen in both HSV and VZV, but maternal history of genital ulcers favors HSV over varicella.

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Calcium

Explanation:

Rate limiting step in glycogenolysis:

 

Glycogen phosphorylase:

  • Phosphorolytic cleavage of the 1→4 linkages of glycogen
  • Different isoenzymes exist in liver, muscle, and brain, encoded by different genes
  • Requires pyridoxal phosphate as coenzyme
  • Activators:
    • cAMP
    • Glucagon - only in liver
    • Epinephrine
    • Calcium
    • 5’AMP
  • Inhibitors:
    • Protein Phosphatase 1 (PP1)
    • Insulin
    • Glucose - only in liver
    • Glucose 6 phosphate
    • ATP
    • Fructose 1 phosphate - only in liver

questions.text: Which of the following viral infections has the least teratogenicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Herpes Simplex Virus-2

Explanation:

  • Herpes Simplex Virus-2 rarely causes congenital malformations. Neonatal herpes is usually acquired perinatally during vaginal delivery, leading to skin, eye, and mouth (SEM) disease, encephalitis, or disseminated disease, but not congenital structural defects.
  • Not a significant teratogen compared to CMV, rubella, or varicella.
  • TORCH infections include toxoplasmosis, rubella, CMV, Herpes and HIV.

Vertical transmission of diseases.

1st trimester

Rubella, Chickenpox/varicella

2nd trimester

Parvovirus

3rd trimester

Toxoplasmosis, CMV, Hepatitis B and Syphilis.

During delivery

HIV and herpes

 

Infection

Pathogen & Transmission

Clinical Features

Toxoplasmosis

Toxoplasma gondii (transplacental from infected mother, cat feces, undercooked meat)

Classic triad: chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications; anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, seizures, intellectual disability

Varicella

(Option B ruled out)

Varicella-zoster virus (aerosols, direct contact, transplacental)

Congenital varicella syndrome: skin lesions, limb hypoplasia, neurodevelopmental delay

Syphilis

Treponema pallidum (sexual transmission, transplacental, peripartum)

Stillbirth, Hutchinson triad (notched teeth, interstitial keratitis, deafness), skeletal abnormalities

Parvovirus B19

Parvovirus B19 (respiratory droplets, transplacental)

Hydrops fetalis, neurodevelopmental defects, fetal anemia

Rubella

(Option D ruled out)

Rubella virus (respiratory droplets, transplacental)

Congenital rubella syndrome: sensorineural deafness, cataracts, congenital heart disease, hepatosplenomegaly

Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

(Option A ruled out)

CMV (body fluids, blood transfusion, organ transplant, transplacental, peripartum, breast milk)

Leading cause of non-genetic congenital hearing loss, petechiae, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, neurodevelopmental deficits

Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1 & HSV-2)

HSV (direct contact, mucosal exposure, peripartum)

Neonatal herpes: vesicular rash, encephalitis, seizures, bulging fontanelle, viral sepsis, organ failure

questions.text: What does iron deficiency anemia (IDA) stand for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

Explanation:

Laboratory findings in iron deficiency anemia:

Hemoglobin Indices

Low Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH), Low Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)

Peripheral Blood Smear

Microcytosis, Hypochromia, Anisocytosis

Serum Ferritin

Decreased

Serum Iron

Decreased

Transferrin Saturation

Decreased

Total Iron-Binding Capacity

Increased

Stool for Occult Blood

May be positive

Mentzer Index

>15

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis

Normal

Bone Marrow Aspiration/Biopsy

Iron stores absent on staining

questions.text: What happens to chloride levels in sweat and pancreatic secretions in cystic fibrosis?

choices.text: Chloride is decreased in pancreatic secretions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chloride is raised in sweat

Explanation:

Cystic fibrosis:

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive disorder.

Genetic Cause

Mutations in the CFTR gene (cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator).

CFTR Function

Cyclic AMP-regulated chloride (Cl−) transporter.

Symptoms
  • Chronic bacterial infections in airways and sinuses.
  • Fat maldigestion due to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.
  • Infertility in males due to abnormal development of the vas deferens.

Diagnostic Feature

Elevated chloride levels in sweat (>60 mmol/L).

questions.text: Which of the following organisms exhibits transcellular movement with the aid of actin filaments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Listeria

Explanation:

Listeria shows tumbling type of motility at 25°C and non-motile at 37°C, which is known as differential motility.

It uses Actin Filaments for Intracellular Motility and Cell-to-Cell Spread .

  • It takes over the host actin cytoskeleton by expressing ActA, which polymerizes actin filaments and forms actin comet tails.
  • This propels the bacterium through the cytoplasm and into adjacent cells, allowing transcellular movement.
  • This mechanism helps evade immune detection and enables spread across the intestinal, placental, and blood-brain barriers.

Enteroinvasive E. coli (Option B): Does Not Use Actin-Based Motility

  • EIEC invades colonic epithelial cells but does not use actin filaments for movement.
  • Instead, it uses a type III secretion system (T3SS) for intracellular invasion.

Salmonella (Option C): Uses Actin for Invasion, Not Intracellular Motility

  • Salmonella uses actin cytoskeleton remodeling to enter host cells.
  • It employs Salmonella Pathogenicity Islands (SPI-1 and SPI-2) for invasion and intracellular survival.

questions.text: Identify the test:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rothera’s test

Explanation:

Rothera's test:

  • The presence of ketosis can be established by the detection of ketone bodies in urine by Rothera's test.
  • Method-Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulfate. Add a few drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside followed by 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube. Development of a purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine.

questions.text: A patient with HIV presents with white patches on the tongue and buccal mucosa. These patches cannot be removed by scraping. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Epstein-Barr Virus

Explanation:

  • Oral Hairy Leukoplakia is caused by EBV and is strongly associated with HIV/AIDS.
  • It presents as painless, white, corrugated patches on the lateral borders of the tongue and sometimes on the buccal mucosa.
  • Unlike oral candidiasis, these lesions cannot be scraped off.

 

Candida (Option B): Oral candidiasis (thrush) is common in HIV, but the white plaques can be scraped off, leaving an erythematous base.

  • Confirmed with potassium hydroxide (KOH) prep, showing budding yeast and pseudohyphae.

HSV (Option C): HSV causes painful vesicles or ulcers rather than white plaques.

HHV-8 (Option D): HHV-8 is associated with Kaposi sarcoma, which presents as vascular, reddish-purple nodules, not white plaques

questions.text: A sample from a patient was stained and examined under a microscope. Which of the following correctly identifies the organism and staining method used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nocardia and acid-fast stain

Explanation:

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching filamentous bacteria that is partially acid-fast due to the presence of mycolic acid in its cell wall.
  • It is best identified using modified acid-fast staining (Kinyoun or Ziehl-Neelsen stain), which helps differentiate it from Actinomyces (which is acid-fast negative).

 

Streptococcus and Gram Stain (Option B): Streptococcus is a gram-positive cocci and is best visualized using a Gram stain, not an acid-fast stain.

Cryptococcus and India Ink (Option C): Cryptococcus neoformans is a yeast with a polysaccharide capsule, best visualized using India ink stain, which highlights the clear halo around the yeast cells.

Coccidioidomycosis and PAS Stain (Option D): Coccidioides (a dimorphic fungus) is best visualized using Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain or Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain, but it does not appear as branching filamentous bacteria.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old women present with upper respiratory tract infection and orbital pain. What is the likely diagnosis?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Orbital cellulitis

  • The given CT is confirmatory of orbital cellulitis as there is proptosis visible on the CT and the patient is also having orbital pain.

Orbital Cellulitis

Definition
  • Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the soft tissues of the orbit located behind the orbital septum.

Etiology
  • Exogenous Infection: Occurs due to penetrating injuries. Example: foreign body retention, surgical procedures like evisceration, enucleation, orbitotomy, dacryocystectomy.
  • Endogenous Infection: From metastatic infections. Example: breast abscess, puerperal sepsis, thrombophlebitis, septicemia
  • Extension from Neighboring Structures (most common): Paranasal sinuses (most common: ethmoid sinus), teeth, face, eyelids, intracranial cavity, and intraorbital structures.

Clinical Features

Symptoms:

  • Swelling and severe pain (worsened by eye movement or pressure).
  • Systemic symptoms: fever, nausea, vomiting, prostration.
  • Vision loss and/or diplopia in moderate to advanced cases.

Signs:

  • Swelling of lids with woody hardness and redness.
  • Chemosis (conjunctival swelling), which may lead to necrosis.
  • Axial proptosis.
  • Restricted eye movements.
  • RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect) may occur due to optic neuropathy or central retinal artery occlusion.
  • Fundus examination may show retinal vein congestion, papillitis, or papilledema

Staging

Modified Chandler staging system:

  • Stage I: Preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis (limited anterior to orbital septum)
  • Stage II: Inflammatory orbital oedema/ Orbital cellulitis (Posterior to orbital septum)
  • Stage III: Subperiosteal abscess
  • Stage IV: Orbital abscess
  • Stage V: Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Investigations
  • Cultures: Nasal, conjunctival, and blood samples for bacterial culture.
  • Complete Blood Count: Leukocytosis.
  • X-ray PNS: To detect sinusitis.
    • Orbital Ultrasonography: To detect orbital abscesses.
  • CT Scan/MRI: Differentiates preseptal from postseptal cellulitis, detects abscesses, intracranial extension, and guides surgical drainage.

Incorrect Options:

Sinusitis (Option B): This option is incorrect as proptosis is visible on imaging.

Both A and B (Option C): This option is also incorrect.

Periosteal abscess (Option D): This option is incorrect as CT findings of periosteal abscess show abscess behind the orbit.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with the complaints of vertigo which is sudden in onset, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea, vomiting and vagal symptoms. Investigations show there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Meniere's Disease

Explanation:

  • The correct answer is Meniere’s Disease because the patient presents with the classic triad: episodic vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) and tinnitus (ringing or roaring sound in the ear)

Meniere’s disease/Endolymphatic hydrops:

  • An inner ear disorder is characterised by the excessive buildup of endolymph fluid.
  • Age/Sex: Typically affects individuals aged 35-60, with a higher prevalence in males.
  • Cardinal Symptoms:

Vertigo
  • Episodic with sudden onset
  • Attacks occur in clusters, interspersed with periods of remission accompanied by nausea, vomiting, ataxia & nystagmus.
  • Loud noises might trigger vertigo due to the Tullio phenomenon.

Hearing Loss
  • Fluctuating hearing loss may improve between attacks but may progressively worsen over time, with some degree of permanent hearing loss.
  • Sensorineural hearing loss initially affecting lower frequencies.
  • Patients might experience distorted hearing or Diplacusis

Tinnitus
  • Low-pitched & Roaring type
  • It can be aggravated during acute attacks and might persist during periods of remission

Aural Fullness

Fluctuates & may vary in intensity

Emotional Impact

The recurrent nature of symptoms can lead to emotional stress and apprehension about future attacks, contributing to overall distress.

Incorrect Options:

Presbycusis (Option B): Age-related bilateral SNHL, mainly affecting high frequencies, with no vertigo or episodic nature.

Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (Option C): Characterized by brief vertigo episodes triggered by head movements, without hearing loss or tinnitus.

Acoustic Neuroma (Option D): Acoustic neuromas are noncancerous, usually slow-growing tumors that form along the branches of the eighth cranial nerve (also called the vestibulocochlear nerve)

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are advantages of a saline mount compared to an iodine mount in stool microscopy?

1. Motility of trophozoites

2. Internal structure of cysts

3. Differentiate bile stained and non bile stained
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 and 3

Explanation:

Saline Mount (Normal Saline Wet Mount) - Advantages:

  • Motility of trophozoites (Statement 1) → Saline mount preserves the natural motility of protozoan trophozoites (e.g., Giardia lamblia shows "falling leaf" motility, Entamoeba histolytica shows directional motility).
  • Differentiation of bile-stained vs non-bile-stained ova (Statement 3) → Saline mount allows observation of color differences, making it useful to distinguish bile-stained ova (e.g., Ascaris lumbricoides fertilized eggs) from non-bile-stained ones.

Internal Structure of Cysts( Statement 3) → Iodine mount is better for cyst structures.

  • Iodine stains the glycogen and nuclei of protozoan cysts, improving visualization of internal structures (e.g., Entamoeba histolytica, Giardia lamblia cysts). Saline mount does not enhance internal details well.

Stool sample processing

Microscopic examination of stool samples

This is done by two methods:

  • Direct wet mount examination
  • Permanent staining methods

Direct wet mount

Preparation:

  • Drops of saline and Lugol’s iodine are used on the left and right sides of the slide.
  • Mix ~2 mg of feces to form a smooth suspension.
  • Place a coverslip on the mount for examination under a microscope.

Observation:

  • Trophozoites
  • Normal constituents of stool like plant fibers and starch cells can be seen
  • Cellular Elements:
    • Pus cells (in inflammatory diarrhea)
    • Red blood cells (in dysentery)
  • Charcot-Leyden Crystals

 

 

Types of wet mounts:

Saline mount:

  • Uses: Detects trophozoites, cysts, helminth eggs, and larvae.
  • Advantages:
    • Demonstrates motility of trophozoites and larvae.
    • Bile staining property can be assessed (bile-stained eggs appear golden brown).

Iodine mount:

  • Advantages: Better visualization of nuclear details in cysts, larvae, and eggs.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Iodine immobilizes and kills parasites, hindering motility observation.
    • Bile staining property cannot be assessed.

Permanent stained smears

 
  • This method stains the internal structures.
  • Purpose: For accurate detection of protozoan cysts and trophozoites.
  • Common Stains:
    • Iron-hematoxylin stain.
    • Trichrome stain.
    • Modified acid-fast stain for coccidian parasites (e.g., Cryptosporidium).

 

Sedimentation techniques and Flotation techniques are concentration techniques used to recover low numbers of parasites in stool samples.

  • Useful for epidemiological studies and assessing treatment response.
  • Detects eggs, cysts, and larvae but does not detect trophozoites, as these get destroyed in the process.
  • Sedimentation techniques:
      • Eggs and cysts settle at the bottom due to higher density.
      • Example: Formalin-ether concentration increases detection sensitivity by 8–10 times.
    • Flotation techniques:
      • Specimens are suspended in a denser medium (e.g., saturated salt solution) in which the eggs and cysts float.
      • Limitations: Cannot concentrate non-floating parasites (e.g., unfertilized Ascaris eggs).

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with the function of elongation factor-2 (EF-2)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diphtheria toxin

Explanation:

Diphtheria toxin (Produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae), ADP-ribosylates elongation factor-2 (EF-2), leading to inhibition of protein synthesis.

  • This results in cell death, leading to pseudomembrane formation in the pharynx and systemic complications like myocarditis and neuropathy.

 

Diphtheria Toxin

Production and Structure
  • DT is a protein exotoxin produced by the toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Consists of two fragments (Bipartite), A and B, with a molecular weight of approximately 62,000 daltons.

Role of Lysogenic β-phage
  • The tox gene is carried by a lysogenic β-phage.
  • Only phage-infected strains produce toxin; nontoxigenic strains can become toxigenic if infected.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae remains localized at the infection site, with only the toxin entering circulation, causing toxaemia but not bacteremia.

Mechanism of Action
  • Fragment B binds host cell receptors, facilitating fragment A entry into the cytoplasm.
  • Fragment A catalyses ADP-ribosylation of EF-2, halting protein synthesis.

Systemic Effects
  • DT spreads via blood, causing myocarditis and neuritis.
  • Myocarditis is potentially fatal.

Factors Affecting Production
  • Influenced by environmental factors: alkaline pH (7.8-8.0), oxygen, and iron concentration in the growth medium.
  • High production with low iron availability; iron addition inhibits production.

Toxoid Formation
  • Treatment with formalin (0.2-0.4%), and incubation at 37°C for 4-6 weeks converts DT to toxoid.
  • Toxoid lacks toxicity but induces an immune response; used in vaccines.

Immunity
  • Immunity is primarily mediated by antitoxin antibodies neutralizing DT.

 

Clostridium toxin (Option B): Clostridium species produce neurotoxins that act by blocking neurotransmitter release, not EF-2 inhibition.

Bacillus toxin (Option C): Bacillus anthracis produces anthrax toxin (PA, EF, LF), which disrupts cell signaling via adenylate cyclase, not EF-2 inhibition.

Vibrio toxin (Option D): Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin, which increases cAMP via ADP-ribosylation of Gs protein, causing watery diarrhea but does not affect EF-2.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. He is diagnosed with otosclerosis and recommended stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests on this patient?

choices.text: Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to right ear
Rinne’s Test - negative; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s Test - negative; Weber’s Test - lateralized to right ear

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Rinne’s Test - negative; Weber’s Test - lateralized to right ear:

Explanation:

  • The patient is experiencing bilateral hearing loss, worse in the right ear due to bilateral otosclerosis. In patients with otosclerosis, there is a conductive type of hearing loss hence Rinne will be negative. Weber will be lateralized to the diseased side, meaning towards the right ear.

Tests for Diagnosing Stapedial Otosclerosis

  • Otoscopy
    • Examines external and middle ear.
    • Identifies abnormalities; typically, the tympanic membrane appears normal in otosclerosis.
  • Fistula Test
    • Evaluates inner ear response to pressure changes.
    • Helps diagnose conditions like superior semicircular canal dehiscence, especially with vertigo.
  • Tuning Fork Tests
    • Weber and Rinne's tests differentiate conductive from sensorineural hearing loss.
    • Less sensitive than audiometry but useful when other findings are inconclusive.
  • Audiometry
    • Pure-tone Audiometry
      • Diagnoses and characterizes hearing loss.
      • Initial low-frequency conductive loss progresses to flat maximal loss as stapes become fixed.
      • Carhart effect may reduce bone conduction thresholds, noticeable at 2 kHz.

    • Speech Audiometry
      • Assesses speech understanding
      • High speech recognition with appropriate hearing aids.
    • Stapedial Reflex Testing
      • Assesses stapedius muscle response to sound.
      • Reflex is often absent or abnormal in otosclerosis.
    • Tympanometry
      • Measures tympanic membrane and middle ear system mobility.
      • Mobility is usually normal, but compliance may be low.
      • Helps exclude other middle ear conditions.
  • Imaging
    • High-Resolution CT Scan
      • Sensitive and specific for active otosclerosis.
      • Reveals hypodense lesions in active disease.
      • Less effective for inactive disease due to dense otic capsule.

Incorrect Options:

Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear (Option A): In otosclerosis there is a conductive type of hearing loss hence Rinne will be negative.

Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to right ear (Option B): In otosclerosis there is a conductive type of hearing loss hence Rinne will be negative.

Rinne’s Test - negative; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear (Option C): Weber will be lateralized to the diseased side meaning towards the right ear.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with the complaint of hearing loss and can understand only shouting or amplified speech. What will be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Severe hearing loss

As the patient understands only shouted or amplified speech, the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech would be severe.

  • Normal conversation is up to 60dB
  • Shouting would indicate that the patient can hear only >60dB, this falls under severe impairment.
WHO grading of degree of hearing loss
Degree of hearing loss  Hearing threshold in better ear (average of 500, 1000 and 2000 Hz)
Not significant  0-25 dB 
Mild  26-30 dB
Moderate  41-55 dB 
Moderately severe  56-70 dB 
Severe 71-91 dB 
Profound  Above 91 dB 
Total   

Incorrect Options:

Mild hearing loss (Option A): This option is incorrect as mild hearing loss is at 26 to 40dB only.

Moderate hearing loss (Option B): This option is incorrect as Moderate hearing loss is at 41 to 60 dB.

Profound hearing loss (Option D): This option is incorrect as Profound hearing loss is above 80 dB.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from nose, nasal obstruction, and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination what will be the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Rhinosporidiosis

  • The given histopathology and clinical scenario (bleeding, nasal obstruction, and red polyploidal mass) is suggestive of Rhinosporidiosis, as on histopathology there are sporangia with spores.

Rhinosporidiosis:

  • It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by an aquatic protistan protozoa- Rhinosporidium seeberi.
  • It is a water-borne disease- contaminated water of ponds usually with cow dung.

Epidemiology:

  • Common in India, Sri Lanka, and Pakistan
  • More common in southern states than in northern India

Life cycle:

  • Trophic stage → Development of sporangium → Release of endospores

Clinical Features:

  • Blood-tinged nasal discharge
  • Nasal block
  • Epistaxis
  • Leafy, polypoidal, pink to purple colored mass attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall.
  • Very vascular mass and bleeds easily on touch.
  • White dots are studded on its surface representing the sporangia.

Incorrect Options:

Basal Cell Carcinoma (Option B):

  • This option is incorrect as basal cell carcinoma exhibits the findings given below.

Rhinoscleroma (Option C):

  • This is incorrect as Rhinoscleroma presents with nasal obstruction, erythematous granular or nodular swellings, crusts on the swellings, and swelling of the lips and gums.

Lupus Vulgaris (Option D):

  • This option is incorrect as Lupus vulgaris (also known as tuberculosis luposa) are painful cutaneous tuberculosis skin lesions with nodular appearance, most often on the face around the nose, eyelids, lips, cheeks, ears, and neck.

questions.text: The HIV genome requires which of the following to initiate the process of entering the host cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) GP120

Explanation:

GP120 (Glycoprotein 120) is the first viral protein involved in HIV entry.

  • It binds to the CD4 receptor on host T-helper cells (CD4+ cells).
  • After binding to CD4, GP120 undergoes a conformational change, allowing it to interact with co-receptors (CCR5 or CXCR4), facilitating viral entry.

HIV is a spherical virus and its capsid has an icosahedral symmetry and also contains two copies of single-stranded positive-sense RNA in its core.

Structure of HIV

  • HIV is a spherical virus measuring 80–110 nm in diameter and belongs to the lentivirus family. Its structure includes:
  • Envelope: Composed of:
    • Lipid Component: Derived from the host cell membrane.
    • Protein Component:
      • gp120: Glycoprotein forming knob-like spikes on the surface.
      • gp41: Glycoprotein that acts as anchoring transmembrane pedicles. (Option C ruled out)
  • Nucleocapsid: The capsid has an icosahedral symmetry and contains core proteins. Inside, there is a dense cylindrical inner core that houses:
    • RNA: Two identical copies of single-stranded positive-sense linear RNA.
    • Viral Enzymes: Including reverse transcriptase, integrase, and proteases, which are closely associated with the RNA.

HIV Serotyping

Serotypes: HIV is classified into two main serotypes: HIV-1 and HIV-2.

  • HIV-1 Groups:
    • Divided into groups M, N, O, and a proposed group P.
    • Group M: Dominant globally with eleven subtypes (A-K) and circulating recombinant forms (CRFs).

Quasispecies: Hosts may have multiple closely related viral subtypes or CRFs.

  • Geographical Distribution:
    • Subtype A: Common in West Africa.
    • Subtype B: Predominant in Europe, America, Japan, and Australia.
    • Subtype C: Most common worldwide (47%); dominant in Southern/Eastern Africa, India, and China.
    • Cameroon: High diversity and possible origin of the virus.

Transmission:

  • Subtypes C and E are more often transmitted heterosexually.
  • Subtype B spreads primarily through blood and homosexual contact.

 

  • HIV-2: Comprises eight subtypes (A–H), mainly found in Africa and parts of India, with Group A being the most common.

 

CCR5 (Option B) & CXCR4 (Option D):

  • Co-receptors needed after GP120 binding.
  • CCR5 → Used by R5-tropic HIV strains (mostly during early infection).
  • CXCR4 → Used by X4-tropic HIV strains (seen in later stages, more aggressive

questions.text: A patient presented with a 3-day history of fever. Complete blood count (CBC) showed a platelet count of <90,000. For a suspicion of dengue, which of the following cannot be done on day 3 of infection?

choices.text: Xenodiagnosis using culture in Aedes mosquito

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) IgM ELISA

Explanation:

Dengue-specific IgM antibodies typically appear around day 4 of illness.

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Fever: Must be present.
  • Any 2 of the following 6 features:
    • Retroorbital pain, myalgia, or "break-bone fever"
    • Protracted nausea or vomiting: Can lead to dehydration
    • Rash: Observed during the illness
    • Warning signs: Any 1 positive sign (e.g., severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting)
    • Positive tourniquet test:
      • >20 petechiae per square inch
      • BP cuff inflated between systolic and diastolic blood pressure
      • The cuff inflated for 5 minutes
    • Leucopenia: Decreased white blood cell count

Investigations

Test Type

Description

ELISA
  • IgM dengue virus (MAC-ELISA)
  • Positive by Day 4 of infection
  • Indicates recent infection

NAAT
  • Detects viral RNA
  • Useful for early diagnosis

NS-1 Antigen

(Option B ruled out)
  • NS-1 (IgG)
  • Positive on Day 1 of infection
  • Should be performed within 7 days of symptom onset

 

PCR (Option A): Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) is used to detect dengue viral RNA and is highly sensitive in the early phase of infection, typically within the first 5 days. It is useful for confirming the diagnosis in the acute stage.

Xenodiagnosis using culture in Aedes mosquito (Option D): Xenodiagnosis involves infecting mosquitoes with a patient’s blood to detect the virus. While not a standard clinical diagnostic method, it theoretically could be performed on day 3. However, its practical use is limited to research settings rather than routine diagnosis.

questions.text:
Mark the correct statement/ statements regarding Inner and Outer hair cells?

I. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses.

II. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells.

III. Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of Tectorial membrane.

IV. · Outer and inner hair cells present in the ratio of 3:1.

choices.text: I, II and IV are correct
I, II and III are correct

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) I, II and IV

  1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses - is correct as type 1 hair cells(inner hair cells) are single and are afferent and transmit excitatory impulses.
  2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells. It is a correct statement as Type 2 also known as outer hair cells are multiple and efferent.
  3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for the movement of the Tectorial membrane.- It is incorrect as there is no such rule about the movement of tectorial plates.
  4. Outer and inner hair cells present in the ratio of 3:1. - It is correct as outer hair cells are around 12000 and inner hair cells are about 3500.

Incorrect Options:

I, II, and III (Option B): This is incorrect as the 3rd statement is false.

All are correct (Option B): It is incorrect as the 3rd statement is false.

II, IV (Option D): It is incorrect as the 1st statement is also correct.

questions.text: Which of the following does not constitute grievous hurt under Section 320 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 7 days hospital admission

Explanation

BNS 116 (Old Section 320 IPC) defines following injuries as grievous:

  1. Emasculation (cutting off the penis, castration, or causing loss of power of erection due to spinal injury). (Option A ruled out)
  2. Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.
  3. Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear. (Option C ruled out)
  4. Privation of any member (part, organ, limb) or joints
  5. Destruction or permanent impairing of powers of any member or joint.
  6. Permanent disfiguration of head or face.
  7. Fracture or dislocation of a bone or a tooth. (Option B ruled out)
  8. Any hurt which endangers life, or which causes the sufferer to be, during the space of 20 days, in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his daily routine.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses are required to undergo reverse transcription for PCR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) RSV

Explanation:

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is an RNA virus belonging to the Paramyxoviridae family. Since PCR typically amplifies DNA, reverse transcription is required to convert the viral RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) before PCR can proceed.

 

EBV (Option B): Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is a DNA virus belonging to the Herpesviridae family. As a DNA virus, it does not require reverse transcription for PCR.

CMV (Option C): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is another Herpesviridae family member and a DNA virus. PCR can directly amplify its DNA, so reverse transcription is unnecessary.

Adenovirus (Option D): Adenoviruses are non-enveloped DNA viruses. Like other DNA viruses, they do not require reverse transcription for PCR.

questions.text: What causes the blackening around a gunshot entry wound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Smoke particles

Explanation:

  • The blackening is caused by soot or smoke particles from the combustion of gunpowder, which adhere to the skin around the entry wound. This phenomenon is typically observed in close-range gunshot wounds.

Incorrect Options:

Unburned gunpowder (Option B): Tattooing or stippling results from the impact of partially burned or unburned gunpowder particles on the skin. These cause small reddish-brown or black marks but do not lead to blackening.

Muzzle of firearm (Option C): The muzzle may leave an imprint if the firearm is discharged at close or contact range, but this does not cause the blackening around the wound.

Fire effect (Option D): The flame from the firearm may produce thermal burns near the wound, but this is distinct from the blackening caused by smoke particles.

questions.text: Which of the following extracellular adhesions is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Occludens

Explanation:

  • V. cholerae produces Zonula Occludens Toxin (Zot), which opens tight junctions in the small intestine, increasing permeability and fluid loss, contributing to profuse watery diarrhea.
  • Encoded by the zot gene within the CTXф phage genome, alongside cholera toxin (CT) and Ace enterotoxin genes.
  • Zot is anchored to the outer membrane of V. cholerae and E. coli when expressed in both.
  • Functions of Zot Domains:
    • N-terminal: Involved in CTXф phage morphogenesis, similar to gene I products of filamentous phages.
    • C-terminal: Responsible for enterotoxic effects.

 

Integrin (Option A): Integrins are transmembrane receptors involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion. Vibrio cholerae does not directly target integrins as part of its pathogenic mechanism.

Cadherin (Option B): Cadherins are calcium-dependent cell adhesion molecules primarily involved in adherens junctions. Vibrio cholerae does not disrupt cadherin-mediated adhesion.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother with a complaint of abdominal pain. The patient's urine pregnancy test (UPT) is positive. What should be the first step by you as a medical officer?

choices.text: Take consent from the patient's mother

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inform the police

Explanation:

  • In cases involving minors with a positive pregnancy test, suspicion of sexual assault or abuse must be considered. The first step is to notify the police, as per the Protection of Children from Sexual Offenses (POCSO) Act, which mandates mandatory reporting of such cases to protect the child and initiate an investigation.

Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act

  • Enacted in 2012, it is law in India designed to protect children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse, sexual harassment, and pornography.

Key Features of the POCSO Act:

  • Gender-neutral law
  • It covers penetrative and non-penetrative assault, sexual harassment, and use of children for pornography
  • Burden of proof is on the accused, unlike many other criminal laws where the burden is on the prosecution
  • Mandatory reporting by adults and failure to do so can be punishable
  • Special courts for the trial of offenses to ensure a child-friendly environment
  • Identity of the victim is to be protected, and the proceedings are to be conducted in camera to prevent exposure

Recent Changes and Developments in the POCSO Act:

  • 2019 Amendment
    • Stricter Punishments: Death penalty for aggravated sexual assault against children
    • The minimum punishment for penetrative sexual assault increased to 10 years, and for aggravated penetrative sexual assault increased to 20 years, with the possibility of life imprisonment or death in extreme cases.
  • Fast-track Courts to ensure swift disposal of POCSO cases, given the backlog of pending cases.
  • Clarifications on ‘Touch’ and Sexual Intent:
    • The intent behind physical contact is crucial in determining whether it qualifies as an offense under POCSO.
  • Digital Crimes Against Children:
    • Provisions related to the use of children for pornographic and online exploitation purposes have been emphasized with stricter penalties.

questions.text: Cadaveric spasm is seen in death due to all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Traumatic asphyxia

Explanation:

  • Traumatic asphyxia typically results from external compression of the chest, leading to venous congestion and petechial hemorrhages. It does not typically cause cadaveric spasm as the mechanism of death is slower compared to the instantaneous deaths associated with cadaveric spasm.

Incorrect Options:

Suicidal gun-shot wound (Option A): Cadaveric spasm can occur in individuals who commit suicide by gunshot, particularly if they were holding the weapon at the time of death. The intense emotional state and instantaneous death may lead to this phenomenon.

Electrocution (Option B): Cadaveric spasm is often observed in electrocution cases due to the immediate and intense contraction of muscles caused by the electric current and tight grasping of electric wire.

Drowning (Option C): In cases of drowning, cadaveric spasm may involve the hands tightly clutching weeds, mud, or other objects in the water, indicating a struggle before death.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with a lesion on the nose as shown in the image below. The lesion bleeds on the touch. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Basal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

Basal cell carcinoma

  • Aka rodent ulcer
  • BCC is a slow-growing, locally invasive tumor and it rarely metastasizes.
  • It arises from pluripotent cells within the basal layer of the epidermis or follicular structures.

Clinical Features

  • It presents initially small, scaly plaque
  • Slow progressive course of peripheral extension
  • Develops into nodular-ulcerative lesions, it has a thread-like margin, telangiectasia and it bleeds on touch.

Site: Face, Around eyes, Nose

Histopathology: peripheral palisading of tumour cells (shown in the image), the cells resemble cells of stratum basale that have grown into the dermis. This cluster of cells is surrounded at the periphery by perpendicularly arranged cells. It also has a well-organized stroma surrounding it.

Treatment

  • Medical: Imiquimod, 5-FU,Intralesional interferon α-2b
  • Hedgehog pathway inhibitors:(Vismodegib)
  • Surgical:
    • Mohs micrographic surgery, Done in recurrent BCCs.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option A):

  • Clinical Features: There is a presence of a papule, nodule, or plaque with induration, accompanied by signs of photodamage such as crusting and scaling.
  • Histopathology: Keratin pearls.

Melanoma (Option C): The image presented above doesn’t meet the diagnostic criteria of malignant melanoma (ABCDE)
