  • Asymmetry: Irregular shapes.
  • Border: Irregular.
  • Colour: Various colours present or uneven distribution.
  • Diameter: > 6 mm.
  • Evolution: Changes in lesion over time (size, shape, itching, or bleeding).

Discoid lupus erythematosus (Option D): This is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by red, scaly, and atrophic lesions, typically without a tendency to bleed. Discoid lupus has distinct features like a well-demarcated, scaly plaque, and it usually lacks the ulcerative appearance seen in this case.

questions.text: A patient presented with altered sensorium, hypotension, and constricted pinpoint pupils. Which of the following is likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Opioids

Explanation:

  • Opioid toxicity is characterized by the classic triad of altered mental status (e.g., drowsiness or coma), respiratory depression, and miosis (pinpoint pupils).
  • Hypotension may also occur due to vasodilation and reduced sympathetic tone.

Opium is extracted from the unripe poppy capsule (shown in the image below).

Opium:

Introduction
  • Dried extract from the poppy plant (Papaver somniferum)

Extraction
  • Obtained by vertical incisions from unripe poppy capsule (toxic part)

Toxic principles
  • Phenanthrene group: Morphine, Codeine and Thebaine
  • Benzylisoquinoline group: Papaverine and Noscapine

Mechanism of action (MOA)
  • Exhibits action via 3 receptors mainly - Mu(μ), Delta(δ) and Kappa(κ) receptors and release Endorphins.
  • Addictive potential is due to its action on Mu(μ) and Delta(δ) receptors
  • Action on Kappa(κ) receptor causes dysphoria - no addictive potential

Effects
  • Tolerability, Addiction, Dysphoria (κ-receptor)
  • Pruritus is a common adverse effect.
  • Other effects: Constipation, Respiratory depression, Urinary retention.
  • Tolerability is developed for all actions except: 3 C's
    • Constipation
    • Convulsions
    • Constriction of pupils (Miosis)

Fatal dose

Opium: 2 g

Morphine: 0.2 g

Codeine: 80 mg

Fatal period: 6-12 hours

Management

  • Support vitals: Use a respirator and other emergency procedures.
  • Decontamination:
    • Stomach wash with 1:5000 KMnO₄, leaving some solution in the stomach to oxidize any secreted alkaloid.
    • Perform lavage even after IV/IM drug injection, as it is secreted in the stomach.
    • Administer activated charcoal as the primary decontamination method.
    • Enema with sodium sulfate twice daily.
    • Whole-bowel irrigation for body packers.
  • Antidote:
    • Naloxone

Incorrect Options:

Datura (Option B): Datura poisoning typically presents with anticholinergic symptoms such as mydriasis (dilated pupils), dry skin, hallucinations, tachycardia, and hyperthermia, which are inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

Cocaine (Option C): Cocaine use usually leads to sympathetic stimulation, resulting in symptoms like mydriasis, hypertension, tachycardia, and agitation. These are inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

Amphetamine (Option D): Amphetamines cause increased sympathetic activity, leading to symptoms such as mydriasis, tachycardia, and hypertension, which do not match the pinpoint pupils and hypotension observed in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following injuries is not expected in a person brought to the hospital with a history of a road traffic accident (RTA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chop wound

Explanation:

  • Chop wounds are deep, incised wounds caused by heavy, sharp-edged weapons like axes or machetes.

Chop/ Slash wound

  • Deep, gaping wounds caused by a blow from a sharp-cutting edge of a heavy weapon (e.g., hatchet, axe, sword, chopper).
  • Wound size corresponds to the cross-section of the blade.
  • Undermining occurs in the direction of chop.
  • The heel (lower end) of the axe typically strikes first, leading to deeper wounds than the toe (upper end).
  • The deeper end indicates the assailant's position.
  • Clean slicing through bone at impact; rebound can create irregular fragments; may lead to complete or incomplete amputations.
  • Mostly homicidal injuries to exposed body parts (head, face, neck, extremities)

Incorrect Options:

Contusion (Option A): Contusions (bruises) are commonly observed in RTAs due to blunt force trauma sustained during the impact or collision.

Abrasions (Option B): Abrasions are also frequent in RTAs, resulting from friction or scraping of the skin against rough surfaces, such as the road or vehicle parts.

Laceration (Option C): Lacerations, or irregular tears in the skin, are often seen in RTAs, especially in cases involving glass shards, sharp edges of vehicles, or other objects.

questions.text: A patient on anti-PD1 immunotherapy (nivolumab) comes with pruritis, eczema, and urticarial rashes. Histopathological examination reveals a subepidermal blister and direct immunofluorescence of the lesions showed linear C3 and IgG on basement membrane. What isthe diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bullous Pemphigoid

Explanation:

Bullous Pemphigoid:

  • BP is a common subepidermal immunobullous disorder mainly affecting elder people. Autoantibodies against hemidesmosomal target proteins BP230(BPAG1) and BP180(BPAG2) which finally leads to bullae formation.
  • It is characterised by a prodromal non bullous stage with pruritis which is followed by a bullous stage. The later has intense pruritus with tense blisters and vesicles.
  • These blisters show a negative Nikolsky sign but a positive Bulla spread sign.
  • The rupture of blisters leads to yellow or hemorrhagic crust formation, which later heal without any scar.
  • Oral lesions can occur sometimes.
  • HPE shows a subepidermal split with inflammatory infiltrate, immunofluorescence shows a linear binding of immunoglobulin (IgG and C3) at the dermo-epidermal junction.
  • Topical and systemic steroids are the mainstay of treatment.

Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option A)

  • DH is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy associated with deposition of IgA in the dermal papillae, not linear IgG or C3 at the basement membrane.
  • DH typically shows granular IgA deposition in immunofluorescence and not the linear patterns seen here.

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option B)

  • PV is characterized by intraepidermal blistering and acantholysis (loss of cell-to-cell adhesion between keratinocytes).
  • Immunofluorescence shows intercellular IgG (not linear staining at the basement membrane zone).
  • The presence of subepidermal blisters here excludes PV.

Pemphigus foliaceous (Option C)

  • PF is another type of pemphigus that features intraepidermal blistering and acantholysis but lacks subepidermal blistering.
  • Immunofluorescence in PF typically shows intercellular IgG, not the linear IgG and C3 at the basement membrane observed in this case.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with an asymptomatic Collarette scale as shown in the image below. Identify the pattern.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

Explanation:

The image depicts an asymptomatic Collarette scale. This presentation is characteristic of Pityriasis rosea, a common skin condition that often begins with a single, large, scaly plaque known as the "herald patch." The subsequent rash that follows often has a distinctive "Christmas tree pattern" on the trunk, which corresponds to the orientation of the lesions.

 

Wickham's striae - Lichen planus (Option B): Wickham's striae is a term used to describe the fine white lines or dots that are characteristic of Lichen planus, a chronic inflammatory condition. However, Lichen planus typically presents with polygonal, flat-topped papules rather than the described Collarette scale.

Christmas tree pattern - Lichen planus (Option C): Lichen planus is characterized by Wickham's striae, as mentioned above. However, the description of a Collarette scale is more indicative of Pityriasis rosea.

Woronoff ring - Seborrheic dermatitis (Option D): A Woronoff ring refers to a ring-shaped area of clearing or central healing within a skin lesion. It is not specifically associated with Seborrheic dermatitis. Seborrheic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous, scaly plaques in areas rich in sebaceous glands, such as the scalp and face.

questions.text: All of the following are used in the identification of a dead body except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Nail

Explanation:

  • Nails are not a primary tool for identification. While they may occasionally provide DNA, their utility is limited compared to teeth and blood and muscle.

Samples Collected from Dead Bodies

Fresh Dead Bodies
  • Use unclotted 10 mL blood in a sterile EDTA tube as the preferred DNA source.
  • EDTA buffers inhibit DNA-degrading nucleases.
  • Clotted blood is unsuitable due to WBC settling.

Intermediate Postmortem
  • Brain tissue is a good DNA source.

Advanced Decomposition
  • Hard tissues like bone and teeth (vascular pulp) are ideal for DNA extraction.
  • Recommended materials: muscle, spleen, bone marrow (femur), and molars.
  • Postmortem samples are less reliable due to DNA degradation and putrefaction.

Incorrect Options:

Teeth (Option A): Teeth are highly reliable for forensic identification due to their resistance to decomposition and the ability to compare dental records. They can also be a source of DNA for profiling.

Blood (Option B): Blood is a primary biological material used for DNA analysis, providing a unique genetic fingerprint for identifying the deceased.

Muscle (Option D): Muscle tissue, while less durable, can be used for DNA extraction if preserved adequately. It serves as an auxiliary source for identification when other tissues are unavailable.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions causes non-scarring alopecia?

1. Alopecia areata

2. Telogen effluvium

3. Androgenic alopecia

4. Folliculitis Decalvans
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2 and 3

Explanation:

Cicatricial alopecias

Non-cicatricial alopecias

Loss of hair follicle stem cells

Stem cells are not affected

Irreversible cessation of hair cycle

Damage to hair cycle can be reversed

Dermoscopy: Absent follicular ostia

Dermoscopy: Ostia are present. Black dots may be seen

Examples:

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia.
  • Folliculitis.
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Scleroderma

Types:

  • Patterned: Androgenetic alopecia
  • Diffuse: Effluvium
  • Patchy:
    • Alopecia areata,
    • Trichotillomania.
    • Tinea capitis,
    • Moth-eaten alopecia

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Correct Optlon B- 1, 2 and 3:

1. Alopecia areata:

  • Alopecia areata is an autoimmune condition that can cause non-scarring alopecia. It typically presents as well-defined, round or oval patches of hair loss on the scalp or other areas of the body. While it can lead to non-scarring alopecia, in some cases, it may progress to involve the entire scalp or body, resulting in complete hair loss.

2. Telogen effluvium:

  • Telogen effluvium is a form of non-scarring alopecia characterized by diffuse hair shedding. It occurs when a large number of hair follicles enter the telogen (resting) phase simultaneously, leading to increased hair loss. It is often triggered by various factors such as childbirth, surgery, illness, or significant stress.

3. Androgenic alopecia:

  • Androgenic alopecia, also known as male-pattern baldness or female-pattern baldness, is a genetic condition that leads to progressive hair thinning. It is a common cause of non-scarring alopecia, especially in a specific pattern on the scalp.

Folllculltis Decalvans (Option D): Folliculitis decalvans is a type of scarring alopecia. Folliculitis decalvans typically presents as clusters of small, red, inflamed papules or pustules atthe site of hair follicles, often accompanied by crusting and scaling. Over time, the affected area may progress to form patches of smooth, bald skin with visible scarring.

questions.text: Where is the apocrine gland present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Axilla

Explanation:

  • Apocrine secretion involves the release of cellular products along with portions of the cytoplasm.
  • Apocrine sweat glands present in the axilla, perineum, and groin regions secrete their secretion into hail follicles by apocrine mechanism and are primarily responsible for producing body odour.
  • The mammary gland (Modified apocrine gland) produces milk by apocrine secretion.

Types of glandular secretion

 

Merocrine

Apocrine

Holocrine

Mechanism

By exocytosis

The apical part of the cell is pinched off.

Whole-cell is disintegrated while secretion

Examples

Eccrine sweat glands.

Salivary glands.

Globlet cells.

Apocrine sweat glands.

Mammary glands.

Sebaceous glands

 

Palm and soles (Option A)

  • The palms and soles are free of apocrine glands.
  • These areas primarily contain eccrine sweat glands, which are responsible for thermoregulation through merocrine secretion.

Face (Option B)

  • While the face contains sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands, apocrine glands are absent from the face.
  • The sebaceous glands in the face use holocrine secretion to release sebum, not apocrine mechanisms.

Scalp (Option D)

  • While the scalp has eccrine sweat glands and sebaceous glands, apocrine glands are not located on the scalp.

questions.text: A 13-year-old patient presents with the velvety lesion shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acanthosis Nigricans

Explanation:

The presence of velvety, hyperpigmented lesions is characteristic of Acanthosis Nigricans. This condition is caused by hyperkeratosis (thickening of the skin) without an increase in melanocyte or melanin production. It commonly affects intertriginous areas (skin folds such as the neck, axillae, groins, and submammary folds) and is associated with obesity, insulin resistance, hypothyroidism, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), acromegaly, and other metabolic disturbances.

  • Pathogenesis: The condition is linked to increased production of IGF-1 (insulin-like growth factor 1).
  • Types:
    • Benign Acanthosis Nigricans: Associated with diabetes, obesity, or metabolic syndrome.
    • Malignant Acanthosis Nigricans: Rapid onset and linked to visceral malignancies, such as adenocarcinomas of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Velvety, asymptomatic, symmetrical darkening of the skin.
    • Often begins in the neck, axillae, groins, or other intertriginous areas.
    • May lead to the development of skin tags in affected regions.
  • The presence of these lesions is a cutaneous marker for underlying metabolic abnormalities and insulin resistance.
  • Treatment involves addressing the underlying condition with lifestyle modifications and, if necessary, topical treatments like keratolytics or retinoids.

Tinea Versicolor (Option B)

  • Caused by a fungal infection (Malassezia species).
  • Presents as hypopigmented or hyperpigmented scaly macules/patches, not velvety lesions.
  • Typically has a scaly appearance, especially after sun exposure.

Seborrheic Keratosis (Option C)

  • A benign skin lesion that appears as well-demarcated, warty, or "stuck-on" plaques.
  • Common in older adults.
  • Does not have the velvety texture characteristic of Acanthosis Nigricans.

Atopic Dermatitis (Option D)

  • Also known as eczema, it appears as dry, itchy, scaly, and inflamed patches of skin.
  • Typically affects flexural surfaces (e.g., behind knees, elbows) rather than intertriginous areas.
  • Velvety hyperpigmented patches are not a feature of atopic dermatitis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy's father noticed agonal respiration at 5 AM while he was asleep. He was rushed to the ER where an ECG was performed as given. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Brugada Syndrome

Explanation:

  • Based on the given scenario and ECG findings (ST elevation in V1-V3), the diagnosis is Brugada Syndrome- a rare, inherited cardiac disorder that predisposes individuals to life-threatening arrhythmias, often occurring during sleep. The presence of agonal respiration at night strongly suggests a ventricular arrhythmia, a hallmark of Brugada Syndrome.
Brugada Syndrome

About

A rare, inherited disease that predisposes patients to potentially fatal cardiac arrhythmias, characterised by right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevations in the right precordial leads (V1-V3) on ECG.

Clinical features
  • Symptoms range from asymptomatic to sudden cardiac death, often during sleep.
  • Syncope in 80% of patients with ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
  • Other symptoms: Palpitations, dizziness, and fever history may trigger symptoms.

ECG findings
  • Type I: Coved ST elevations >2 mm with inverted T wave.
  • Type II: Saddleback-shaped ST elevation >2 mm.
  • Type III: Saddleback-shaped ST elevations <2 mm.
  • Patients with a normal ECG and high-risk factors may need a drug challenge test to reveal ST elevations in leads V1 to V3.

Drug challenge test
  • Drugs used in the challenge test:
    • Class IA antiarrhythmics (Procainamide, Ajmaline).
    • IC antiarrhythmics (Flecainide, Propafenone).
  • Brugada ECG findings can also emerge from Cocaine use or Tricyclic antidepressant toxicity.
  • Electrolyte abnormalities like Hyperkalemia and Hypercalcemia can reveal ST elevations in the right precordial leads.
  • A normal drug challenge test in pediatric patients may need to be repeated after puberty due to hormonal influences.
  • The "Full Stomach Test" can also help expose ST elevations by increasing vagal tone.
  • Additional diagnostic options include genetic testing for SCN5A mutations and invasive electrophysiology.

Treatment
  • Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (ICD) for high-risk patients.

Incorrect Options:

Early repolarization syndrome (Option A) is a genetic condition presenting with life-threatening arrhythmias and J-point elevation in ECG. This is not the given scenario here.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Option C) is an autosomal dominant cardiac myocyte disease and presents with shortness of breath and chest discomfort. It does not present with agonal respiration at night and is not the given scenario.

Atrial fibrillation (Option D) is a type of cardiac arrhythmia that presents with an irregularly irregular rhythm in the ECG. This is not the given ECG picture.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man came with complaints of fever and cough for 3 days. On examination, creatinine is 1.5 and BUN is 45. Chest-x ray shows infiltrates in the right lung and patchy infiltrates in the left lung. A nasopharyngeal swab shows only Rhinovirus. The patient is shifted to the ICU. Which antibiotics are suitable for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin

Explanation:

  • The scenario here is severe pneumonia signified by admission to the ICU; hence, the best treatment modality is beta-lactam + macrolide, i.e., Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin.

Treatment for Lobar Pneumonia

  • Treatment depends on severity; assess if inpatient or outpatient management is needed.
  • CURB-65 Score: Used to stratify patients with the following factors:

CURB-65

Symptom

Score

(C) Confusion

1

(U) Urea: BUN >19mg/dL (>7 mmol/L)

1

(R) Respiratory rate ≥30/min

1

(B) Blood Pressure - Systolic BP ≤90 mmHg or diastolic BP ≤60 mmHg

1

(65) Age ≥65 years

1
  • Hospitalisation Criteria:
    • CURB-65 score 0: Outpatient treatment
    • Score 1 or 2: Indicates hospitalization
    • Score ≥3: Indicates ICU admission and more intensive therapy.
  • Empiric Therapy:
    • Outpatient:
      • No comorbidities: Monotherapy with macrolides (Azithromycin, Clarithromycin).
      • With comorbidities (chronic lung/heart disease, diabetes, smoking, HIV): Newer fluoroquinolones (Levofloxacin, Moxifloxacin, Gemifloxacin) or a combination of beta-lactam (e.g., amoxicillin) and a macrolide.
    • Inpatient Non-ICU:
      • Newer fluoroquinolones (Levofloxacin, Moxifloxacin) alone or a combination of beta-lactam (e.g., Ampicillin, Ceftriaxone) and a macrolide.
    • Inpatient ICU:
      • Combination of macrolide (Azithromycin) with beta-lactam (e.g., Ampicillin-sulbactam, Ertapenem, Cephalosporins) or a newer fluoroquinolone (Levofloxacin).
      • If risk of aspiration, consider Ampicillin-sulbactam or Ertapenem; for Pseudomonas infection, use anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam (e.g., Piperacillin-Tazobactam) with anti-pseudomonal fluoroquinolone (e.g., Ciprofloxacin).
      • For MRSA, add Vancomycin or Linezolid.
  • Duration of Therapy: Typically 5 to 7 days, extended if clinical response is delayed.
  • Influenza Treatment: All hospitalized patients testing positive for influenza should receive Oseltamivir, regardless of illness onset.

Incorrect Options:

Amoxicillin with clavulinic acid (Option A): Inadequate for this patient due to the severity of his illness and the risk of resistant organisms. Monotherapy with amoxicillin does not provide sufficient coverage for his condition, especially considering the possibility of Pseudomonas and MRSA.

Azithromycin (Option B): Not appropriate for this patient due to the severity of his condition, indicating he requires more intensive treatment. Azithromycin is preferred for outpatient therapy, suitable for lower-risk patients without significant comorbidities.

Piptaz + Ciprofloxacin (Option D): Piptaz (Piperacillin/Tazobactam) is a combination which is a beta lactam antibiotic. Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic. However, as mentioned above this is not suitable for the condition of the patient here as a macrolide is necessary along with a Fluoroquinolone or a beta-lactam to treat severe pneumonia.

questions.text: What medication can be administered to a patient who experiences altered consciousness, sweating, rapid heartbeat, persistent erection, and increased saliva production, with a blood pressure reading of 150/90 mm Hg after visiting a temple with their grandmother?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prazosin

Explanation:

  • The patient might be suffering from a scorpion sting cardiotoxicity as per his symptoms and the best choice of medication here is Prazosin.

Treatment of scorpion sting:

  • Identification of the scorpion species is essential for determining treatment, as stings from non-lethal species typically only require basic care.
  • Non-lethal stings: Most stings cause local discomfort and can be managed at home with ice packs, analgesics, or antihistamines. Patients should return to the emergency department if cranial-nerve or neuromuscular symptoms develop.
  • Severe envenomations: Aggressive supportive care and careful use of antivenom can prevent deaths from more dangerous stings.
  • Initial measures: Keeping the patient calm, applying pressure dressings, and using cold packs can reduce venom absorption.
  • Treatment for symptoms: Continuous IV infusion of midazolam can control agitation and muscle movements, but close monitoring is needed due to the risk of respiratory arrest, especially when sedatives or narcotics are used.
  • Management of complications:
    • Hypertension and Pulmonary oedema: Managed with Nifedipine, Nitroprusside, Hydralazine, or Prazosin.
    • Bradycardia: Managed with atropine.
  • Antivenin: FDA-approved antivenin (C. sculpturatus IgG F(ab')2 in horse serum) is available in some countries and can rapidly reverse cranial-nerve dysfunction and muscular symptoms when administered intravenously.

Incorrect Options:

Anti-snake venom (Option A) is a specific treatment used for snakebite envenomation and is not indicated in the given scenario.

Adrenaline (Option B) is commonly used in emergencies to treat severe allergic reactions and cardiac arrest.

Steroids (Option C), such as corticosteroids have anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. They are generally used in allergic reactions, autoimmune disorders, and asthma. However, these are not preferred in the given scenario.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male comes with recurrent blisters and oral ulcers for 3 years. The histology is as shown. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pemphigus vulgaris

Explanation:

The above clinical features and HPE findings in this patient suggest the diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris (PV), which most commonly has antibodies against Desmoglein 3.

Pemphigus vulgaris:

  • PV is the most common chronic autoimmune blistering disease caused by antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins.
  • They are characterized by the presence of flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid present on normal skin or an erythematous base.
  • The blisters rupture producing painful erosion.
  • Mucosal involvement is a very important and one of the distinguishing features of PV.
  • Histopathology:
    • Intraepidermal cleavage with acantholysis (detached keratinocytes) primarily localized to the suprabasal region
    • Separation of basal keratinocytes along the basement membrane zone, resulting in an appearance that resembles a "row of tombstones"

The target antigens for PV are most commonly Desmoglein 3 and sometimes Desmoglein 1. The image below shows the common target antigen in Intraepidermal Immunobullous Disorders.

Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option B)

  • Associated with celiac disease and characterized by intensely pruritic, grouped vesicles typically on extensor surfaces.
  • Shows granular IgA deposits on immunofluorescence, not intercellular IgG.

Bullous pemphigoid (Option C)

  • Causes subepidermal blisters and does not commonly present with oral ulcers.
  • Immunofluorescence shows linear IgG and C3 at the dermal-epidermal junction.

Linear IgA disease (Option D)

  • Characterized by linear IgA deposits at the basement membrane zone.
  • Typically causes subepidermal blistering, not intraepidermal, and oral ulcers are less common.

questions.text:
In a patient with HIV, the incorrect statement regarding prophylaxis for various organisms is:

(PCP-Pneumocystis pneumonia, MAC-Mycobacterium avium complex)

choices.text: Prophylaxis for PCP is indicated when CD4 count is <200 cells/µL

Prophylaxis for MAC is indicated when CD4 count is <50 cells /µL
Prophylaxis for cryptococcus is indicated when the CD4 count is >150 cells/µL

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prophylaxis for cryptococcus is indicated when the CD4 count is >150 cells/µL

Explanation:

  • Prophylaxis for cryptococcus is indicated when the CD4+ count is < 250/μL.

questions.text: What contributes to the increase in blood volume during a woman’s term pregnancy?

choices.text: Increased fluid retention by the kidneys

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Both options A & B

Explanation:

Physiology of increased blood volume in pregnancy

  • The blood volume expands rapidly, reaching its maximum of 40–50% above the nonpregnant level at 30–34 weeks, ensuring an adequate supply of nutrients and oxygen to support the developing fetus and maternal physiological changes during pregnancy.

Role of aldosterone and estrogen:

  • The increase in blood volume is associated with enhanced sodium (Na) retention driven by hormonal changes like increased aldosterone levels during pregnancy.
  • There is an increased demand for blood flow to support the growing fetus and maternal tissues during pregnancy.
  • The increased aldosterone production promotes the reabsorption of sodium and water in the distal tubules and collecting ducts, enhances GFR, contributing to the expansion of blood volume.
  • Estrogen levels rise significantly during pregnancy.
  • First detectable at 9 weeks (0.05 ng/ml) and increases gradually to about 30 ng/ml at term.
  • Estrogen plays a role in upregulating the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS), further influencing sodium and water retention in the kidneys.

Aldosterone (Option C), as mentioned earlier, enhances sodium and water retention. However, with an increased production of ADH during pregnancy, plasma levels remain unchanged due to increased metabolic clearance by placental vasopressinase, limiting its impact on the increase in blood volume during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old multigravida comes to the emergency at night with an inversion of the uterus following the delivery of the baby when the nurse waited till the delivery of the placenta. Her BP is 110/70 mmHg, and pulse rate is 90 bpm. What should be the management in this case?

choices.text: Manually remove the placenta and reposition the uterus
Reposition the uterus inside without removing the placenta
Shift to the operating theatre and reinsert the uterus under general anesthesia

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Reposition the uterus inside without removing the placenta

Explanation:

In cases of uterine inversion with the placenta still attached, the immediate priority is to reposition the uterus without removing the placenta to prevent further hemorrhage and uterine contraction, which would complicate repositioning.

The management of uterine inversion should follow the following steps:

  • Immediate call for assistance (obstetric and anaesthesia personnel)
  • Blood is brought to the delivery room to use when needed
  • Two large bore IV lines are secured, and crystalloids are given to treat hypovolemia till the blood is brought
  • The woman is evaluated for emergency general anaesthesia
  • Stop tocolytics
  • Start oxytocin
  • Give antibiotics

 

The steps of management of uterine inversion according to certain factors are as follows:

Condition

Method

  • Inverted uterus not contracted and retracted completely
  • The placenta has already separated

Replace the uterus by pushing the inverted fundus using your palm and fingers

The placenta is still attached
  • Reposition the uterus with the placenta in situ
  • Tocolytics may be used for uterine relaxation
  • If they fail, general anaesthesia (inhalational) is used
  • The uterus is replaced, and the placenta removed

Failed uterine reposition with attached placenta

The placenta is peeled off, and repositioning is attempted again

Failed manual repositioning

Surgical repositioning (Huntington’s procedure)

 

 

Manually removing the placenta and repositioning the uterus (Option A) will lead to increased haemorrhage and faster contraction of the uterus, making it difficult to replace the uterus. Hence, this is not the preferred step.

Shift to the operating theatre (OT) and reinsert the uterus under general anaesthesia (Option C): General anesthesia and surgical repositioning are reserved for failed manual repositioning attempts.

Start oxytocin infusion (Option D): If oxytocin infusion is continued, the uterus will contract and lead to difficulty in its repositioning, so tocolytics are used to relax the uterus, and then once the repositioning is completed, oxytocin infusion and bimanual compression are started to aid uterine contraction.

questions.text:
A patient was being treated in ICU for sepsis.

The initial ABG shows pH= 6.9, pO2= 80 mm Hg. pCO2= 55 mmHg, HCO3 = 10 meq/L. A repeat ABG after 2 hours shows pH=7.1, pCO2= 20 mmHg, pO2= 140 mm Hg, and HCO3= 10 meq/L. Which is most plausible to explain the change seen in the ABG report?

choices.text: Excessive air and less heparin in the ABG sample
Excess air and more heparin in the ABG sample
Less air and more heparin in the ABG sample
Less air and less heparin in the ABG sample

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Excess air and more heparin in the ABG sample

Explanation:

  • The change in the pH without a change in the bicarbonate level indicates excess heparinization.
  • The increased pO2 shows excess air.

Effects of excess heparin:

  • Heparin is a sulfated mucopolysaccharide with acidic properties.
  • The excess of heparin in the ABG syringe can have the following effects:
  • Effect on pH:
    • If the pH is normal or alkaline (high) to begin with, acidemia increases i.e., the pH will fall on contact with the acidic heparin.
    • If the pH is very acidic to begin with, acidemia decreases i.e., the pH will rise as the mildly acidic heparin reduces the greater acidity of the blood.
  • Delusional effect:
    • The PaO2 and PaCO2 can also be falsely lowered by dilution.

questions.text: n counselling a 39-year-old woman who is G6P2A3 with a history of two previous lower segment Caesarean Sections (LSCS) complicated by placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), which aspect would NOT typically be included in the consent for surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Risk of bowel injury

Explanation:

In cases of PAS, the primary concern is the abnormal attachment of the placenta to the uterine wall, and the risk of invasion into adjacent structures, such as the bladder and sometimes bowel. While bladder involvement is relatively common, direct bowel injury is less frequently emphasized in counselling. The primary risks usually revolve around bleeding, the potential need for a hysterectomy, and the possibility of bladder injury.

Management of placenta accreta spectrum

Placenta Accreta Type

Management

Partial Placenta Accreta

 
  • Remove as much placenta as possible
  • Use oxytocics to control bleeding

Total Placenta Accreta
  • Complete family: Perform hysterectomy
  • Incomplete family:
    • Leave the placenta for autolysis within the uterus and administer antibiotics
    • Consider uterine artery embolisation or Methotrexate therapy

Placenta Percreta with Bladder Invasion

Perform hysterectomy with partial cystectomy.

 

Possible complications of PAS surgery:

  • Blood loss and need for immediate blood transfusion
  • Placental ingrowth to the bladder causes bleeding on attempting manual removal
  • Postoperative venous thromboembolism

The need for blood transfusion (Option B) is due to significant bleeding, which is a substantial risk in cases of PAS due to abnormal placental attachment.

The risk of requiring a hysterectomy (Option C) is a crucial aspect to discuss in counselling, as PAS cases often involve difficulty separating the placenta from the uterine wall, leading to potential complications that may necessitate a hysterectomy.

The risk of bladder injury (Option D) is a significant consideration in PAS cases. Abnormal placental attachment can lead to invasion into the bladder wall, increasing the risk of injury during attempts to separate the placenta from the uterine wall.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with complaints of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and cramps. An endoscopy is done and she is diagnosed with ulcerative colitis. She currently has 3-4 episodes of bloody stools per day. What is the appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sulfasalazine

Explanation:

  • Sulfasalazine is commonly used in the treatment of ulcerative colitis (inflammatory bowel disease).

Sulfasalazine

Anti-inflammatory Properties:

  • Sulfasalazine is composed of two components: Sulfapyridine and 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA).
  • The 5-ASA component is responsible for the drug's anti-inflammatory effects.
  • It inhibits the production of inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes, which play a role in the inflammation seen in ulcerative colitis.

Immunomodulatory Effects:

  • Sulfasalazine also has immunomodulatory effects, which help to regulate the immune response in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • By modulating the activity of immune cells such as macrophages and T cells, sulfasalazine can reduce inflammation.

Antibacterial Activity:

  • Sulfasalazine's sulfapyridine component has antibacterial properties.
  • It acts by disrupting the metabolism of certain bacteria, particularly those in the gut microbiota.
  • By targeting bacteria, sulfasalazine may help to restore balance to the gut microbiome.

Local Action in the Colon:

  • Sulfasalazine is administered orally, and its 5-ASA component is not absorbed systemically to a significant extent.
  • Instead, it remains largely in the colon, where it exerts its anti-inflammatory effects directly on the inflamed tissue.
  • This targeted action reduces the risk of systemic side effects commonly associated with corticosteroids or other systemic immunosuppressive agents.

Maintenance Therapy:

  • Sulfasalazine is often used as maintenance therapy in ulcerative colitis.
  • It helps prevent flare-ups and maintain remission over the long term.

Symptomatic Relief:

  • In addition to its disease-modifying effects, sulfasalazine can provide symptomatic relief from the symptoms of ulcerative colitis, such as diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and rectal bleeding.

Incorrect Options:

Budesonide (Option A) is used in cases of exacerbation of ulcerative colitis, especially mild to moderate cases.

Azathioprine (AZA) (Option C) is a medication used in the management and treatment of active rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and the prevention of kidney transplant rejection.

Bezlotoxumab (Option D) is indicated to reduce the recurrence of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) in patients who are receiving antibacterial drug treatment for CDI and are at high risk for CDI recurrence.

questions.text: A 34-year-woman at 30 weeks of gestation is experiencing vaginal bleeding and pain abdomen. She has drenched her clothes and has experienced reduced fetal movements. On examination, her cervix was 6cm dilated and 50% effaced. Her BP was 150/100 mmHg, PR= 100 bpm. Her abdomen corresponded to 34 weeks, and she had a tense and tender uterus with regular contractions and no fetal heart sounds. Her urine protein was 2,+ and there is no active bleeding. What is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Antihypertensives + ARM (artificial rupture of membranes)

Explanation:

The diagnosis here is of abruptio placenta. Since the patient is already in labour in the given scenario, the ideal step is ARM along with antihypertensives, as her BP is 150/100 mmHg (NICE criteria).

 

Vaginal delivery is favoured in:
  1. Limited placental abruption.
  2. FHR tracing is reassuring.
  3. Facilities for continuous fetal monitoring are available.
  4. The prospect of vaginal delivery is soon.
  5. Placental abruption with a dead fetus.

Cesarean section is favoured in: (Option B)
  1. Bleeding continues, and the placental abruption is greater than in Grade 1.
  2. Severe abruption with a live fetus.
  3. An amniotomy could not be done due to an unfavourable cervix.
  4. The prospect of immediate vaginal delivery is remote despite attempts.
  5. Amniotomy failed to control bleeding.
  6. Amniotomy failed to arrest the process of abruption, evidenced by rising fundal height or the appearance of adverse features (e.g., fetal distress, falling fibrinogen level, oliguria).

Tocolytics (Option C), which are medications to inhibit uterine contractions for expectant management of the pregnancy (<35 weeks), are not typically used in this scenario where fetal demise is suspected and the labour is to be initiated.

Observation (Option D) is not the treatment modality suitable here as the woman has evidence of fetal demise and is only at 30 weeks of gestation. Hence, there is no point in expectant management of the pregnancy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with a low-risk pregnancy presents at 39 weeks + 6 days with labour pains. Her vitals are stable. On PV, her cervix is 3cm dilated and 60% effaced. The fetal head is at -3 station and membranes are felt as a bag of worms beneath the head. What is the appropriate course of management?

choices.text: Rupture of membranes and confirm cord prolapse
Proceed with emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Proceed with emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)

Explanation:

The situation in this scenario is cord presentation, and since the baby is term and the cervix is not fully dilated, the best management for this case is to proceed to cesarean section as definitive management.

  • Cord presentation involves the umbilical cord being felt below the presenting part without membrane rupture.
  • Both cord prolapse and cord presentation are obstetric emergencies, and the management is immediate delivery by emergency LSCS.
  • The presenting part can be elevated to relieve cord compression (positional or with fingers if possible) till delivery is started or if the patient needs to be transferred.

Management of cord prolapse is based on:

  • Baby's status (living or dead)
  • Baby's maturity
  • Degree

Living baby

Definitive treatment

 

Cesarean Section (Best option for mature, living babies)

If immediate Safe Vaginal Delivery Possible:
  • Head Engaged: Complete delivery with forceps (ventouse is less ideal).
  • Breech Presentation: Complete delivery by breech extraction.

If immediate Safe Vaginal Delivery Not Possible

 
  • Minimise cord pressure until definitive treatment or transfer to a suitable hospital.
  • Stop any ongoing oxytocin infusion.
  • Bladder Filling: Use a Foley catheter to fill the bladder with 400–750 mL fluid—empty the bladder before cesarean delivery.
  • Postural Treatment: Use an elevated Sims position with a pillow or wedge
  • Cord Replacement: Place the cord back into the vagina to reduce vasospasm.

Baby Dead

 

Allow labour to proceed for spontaneous delivery.

 

 

Rupturing the membranes (Option A) in this situation can lead to cord prolapse, which is a serious obstetric emergency. It is not advisable to intentionally rupture the membranes without a clear assessment and appropriate management plan.

Oxytocin (Option B) is not the immediate solution in the presence of a prolapsed cord. The focus should be on relieving pressure on the cord and expediting delivery through emergency LSCS rather than initiating labor augmentation.

Wait and watch (Option D) is not an option here since this case can proceed to cord prolapse and further complications endangering the baby.

questions.text: All of the following can result in non-immune fetal hydrops except.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) ABO incompatibility

Explanation:

ABO incompatibility is not a cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis as it causes immune-type hydrops fetalis.

Causes of Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis

Chromosomal abnormality (Option D ruled out)
  • Trisomies (13, 18, 21)
  • Turner syndrome

Congenital cardiac lesions (M/C)
  • Congenital heart block
  • Supraventricular tachycardia

Congenital abnormalities
  • Diaphragmatic hernia
  • Renal abnormality
  • Cystic hygroma.

Haematological
  • Beta-thalassemia
  • G6PD deficiency
  • Leukaemia
  • Alpha-thalassemia (2nd most common) (Option B ruled out)

Infections
  • Parvovirus (Option C ruled out)
  • Rubella
  • Toxoplasma

Placental and umbilical cord pathology
  • Twin-to-twin transfusion
  • Chorioangioma
  • Umbilical vein thrombosis

Maternal diseases

  • Uncontrolled diabetes
  • Severe anaemia
  • Thyrotoxicosis

	HbsAg = Negative

What is the diagnosis?

questions.text: A second gravida has Rh-negative pregnancy and her ICT titer at 28 weeks is 1:4. What is the next step in her management?

choices.text: No interventions are needed; deliver at term and then administer anti-D

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Repeat ICT after 4 weeks

Explanation:

In the given scenario, the indirect Coomb’s test (ICT) titer is positive but less than the significant value of 1:16 so ICT is repeated every 4 weeks throughout the entire pregnancy, and once the value is found to be critical (≥ 1:16), the test is not repeated anymore.

 

The steps to be followed in this and similar scenarios are given below:

 

300mcg of anti-D (Option A) is given when the ICT titer is negative. The given scenario has a positive ICT even though it is not critical, so she cannot be given anti-D immunoglobulin and has to be retested.

MCA Doppler (Option B) is not the right step since ICT is not ≥ 1:16, which is the critical value for further evaluation with MCA and fetal USG, among other investigations.

No interventions are needed; delivery at term and then administering anti-D (Option D): It is not the right step in the management of this case since the ICT is positive and hence cannot be given anti-D.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl child with primary amenorrhea and signs of virilisation. She has prepubertal development of breasts and pubic hair and is tanner stage 2. She has a blind-ended vagina and clitoromegaly with normal testosterone levels. Her genotype is 46 XY. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 5-alpha reductase deficiency

Explanation:

The presentation of primary amenorrhea with virilisation, clitoromegaly, blind-ended vagina, and Tanner stage 2 pubic hair development, alongside a 46 XY genotype, suggests 5-alpha reductase deficiency.

 

Definition:

5-alpha reductase deficiency is a condition with a deficiency in the enzyme 5-alpha reductase, which converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT).

Features:

  • DHT is crucial for the development of male external genitalia.
  • Individuals with this deficiency typically have normal testosterone levels because the enzyme defect doesn't affect testosterone production.
  • At birth, they are often assigned female because they have ambiguous genitalia or appear female externally.
  • During puberty, testosterone levels increase, leading to virilization (e.g., clitoromegaly)
  • They usually have a blind-ending vagina and often prepubertal breast development because DHT is important for male genital development but not for pubic hair development, which relies on testosterone.

 

17 hydroxylase deficiency (Option A) leads to impaired production of both sex steroids and cortisol, with accumulation of precursor steroids, leading to increased mineralocorticoid activity (hypertension and hypokalemia). Patients have ambiguous genitalia or female external genitalia due to low androgen levels, and the characteristic features include hypertension and hypokalemia. Normal testosterone levels would not be expected in 17 hydroxylase deficiency, which makes this option incorrect.

Swyer syndrome (Option B) is a type of pure gonadal dysgenesis where individuals have a 46 XY karyotype but develop as females with streak gonads. They present with primary amenorrhea and underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics (such as prepubertal breasts) and do not develop pubic hair due to a lack of sex steroid production, which is not the case given here.

Complete AIS (Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome) (Option D) involves resistance to androgens in individuals with a 46 XY karyotype and typically have normal breast development due to aromatization of androgens to estrogens, no pubic or axillary hair (because of androgen resistance), and a blind-ending vagina. The presence of pubic hair and prepubertal breasts is not consistent with complete AIS

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has the lowest occurrence of perinatal transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Rubella

Explanation:

Rubella/ German measles is transmitted via nasopharyngeal secretions; hence, perinatal transmission is not seen in this case.

Characteristics

It is an RNA togavirus

Transmission

Nasopharyngeal secretions

Maternal features

  • Mild febrile illness
  • Generalized maculopapular lesion beginning on the face and then spreading to the trunk and extremities
  • Arthralgia or arthritis
  • Head and neck lymphadenopathy
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Spontaneous abortions
  • Devastating fetal infections

Fetal features

  • 13 to 14 gestation: 50% incidence of an affected fetus
  • End of 2nd trimester: 25%
  • After 20 weeks: Defects are rare

Diagnosis

  • Urine analysis
  • Blood analysis
  • Nasopharyngeal secretions
  • CSF analysis
  • ELISA: Specific IgM antibody

Management and prevention

  • Droplet precautions for 7 days after onset of rash
  • Postexposure passive immunization with IVIG within 5 days of exposure
  • MMR vaccine to non-pregnant women of childbearing age
  • Targeted USG to determine fetal anomalies in infected mothers
  • Vaccination of all susceptible hospital personnel

 

Hepatitis B (Option A) transmission transplacentally is uncommon but vertical transmission is seen by exposure to blood or other bodily fluids during birth. All pregnant mothers are screened at the beginning of the pregnancy, and if found positive, the newborns are given hepatitis B immunoglobulin with a hepatitis B recombinant vaccine series.

In HSV (Option B), Fetal infection can occur by shedding of virus from the lower genital tract during vaginal delivery or rupture of membranes. Neonatal infection, when symptomatic, can present with chorioretinitis, mental retardation, microcephaly, seizures, and occasionally death.

CMV (Option D) is a DNA virus transmitted by sexual, respiratory droplets and transplacental route. Infection can affect the fetus throughout gestation and cause microcephaly, intracranial calcification, chorioretinitis, mental retardation, nonimmune hydrops, stillbirth, IUGR, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, and sensorineural deafness. Transmission is more common in the third trimester and during delivery.

questions.text: A patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) presented to the ER with hypotension. She was on medication for RA but abruptly stopped them. On examination, her HR = 110 bpm, BP is 80/40 mm Hg, blood sugar = 50 mg/dl, Na = 130 meq/L and K = 6.0 meq/L. What should be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hydrocortisone

Explanation:

  • The scenario here is of Addisonian crisis (or adrenal crisis) that was triggered due to the abrupt cessation of medications for rheumatoid arthritis (glucocorticoids like prednisone). This is treated with intravenous hydrocortisone.

Clinical features of adrenal crisis
  • Circulatory shock
  • Severe hypotension
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Muscle cramps
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Unexplained fever

Precipitating factors:

  • Other illnesses
  • Surgery
  • Infection

Management of adrenal crisis:

  • Correct volume depletion
    • IV saline for correcting blood pressure and pulse
  • Replace glucocorticoids
    • IV hydrocortisone succinate 100 mg stat and 100 mg QID for first 12-24 hrs
    • Parenteral hydrocortisone 50-100 mg IM QID till the patient can take it orally
  • Correct metabolic abnormalities
    • Acute hypoglycemia: IV 10% glucose
    • Hyperkalemia: Usually corrected with volume replacement, otherwise needs specific treatment
  • Identify and treat the underlying cause
    • Acute precipitating factors like infection
    • Adrenal or pituitary pathology

Incorrect Options:

Fast IV fluids (Option A) is one of the steps in management to correct the blood pressure and pulse but it is not the definitive treatment for Addisonian crisis which needs to be managed with IV hydrocortisone.

Dopamine infusion (Option C) is not a definitive treatment for adrenal crisis and is used to treat low blood pressure, low heart rate, and cardiac arrest.

Soda bicarbonate (Option D) is not indicated for adrenal crisis.

questions.text:
What is the wrong match?


	
		
			
			a. Uterine Prolapse
			
			
			1. Hysterectomy
			
		
		
			
			b. Vault prolapse
			
			
			2. Sacrospinous fixation
			
		
		
			
			c. Rectocele
			
			
			3. Posterior colpoperineorrhaphy
			
		
		
			
			d. Cystocele
			
			
			4. Colposuspension
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) d-4

Explanation:

The surgical treatment for cystocele is anterior colporrhaphy and not colposuspension.

 

Cystocele

Clinical features
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Pelvic discomfort
  • Anterior vaginal wall prolapse
  • Bulge shows transverse rugosities and impulse on coughing

Management

Surgical: (recommended for women >40 years)

  • Anterior Colporrhaphy: (most preferred)
    • weakened tissue between the bladder and vagina is repaired.
  • Mesh Repair:
    • synthetic mesh is used for additional support.
    • Risk of recurrence, mesh erosion and infection
  • Sacral Colpopexy:
    • Mesh is attached from the top of the vagina to the sacrum to lift the prolapsed organs.
    • High risk of recurrence and complications
  • Vaginal Hysterectomy:
    • Considered in cases where uterine prolapse coexists with cystocele.

Conservative:

  • Recommended in young women with prolapse following childbirth for the initial 4-6 months
  • Pelvic floor exercises
  • Lifestyle modifications: Avoid heavy lifting and constipation
  • Pessary insertion (in patients unfit for surgery)

 

Hysterectomy (Option A) involves the removal of the uterus and is a common treatment for uterine prolapse, especially when conservative measures fail to provide relief and in women older than 40 years.

Sacrospinous fixation or sacrospinous colpopexy (Option B) can fix the vaginal vault to sacrospinous ligaments. Vault prolapse is a delayed complication of hysterectomy. This is the preferred treatment for vault prolapse.

The surgical treatment of rectocele is posterior colporrhaphy or colpoperineorrhaphy (Option C). Protrusion of the rectum with the posterior vaginal wall is called rectocele.

questions.text: The image below represents the presence of HER2 neu cells in a patient with breast carcinoma. What agent is used to produce this characteristic discolouration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Diaminobenzidine

Explanation:

  • 3,3′-Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is a commonly used chromogen in immunohistochemistry (IHC) to detect HER2 overexpression in certain breast cancers.
  • It serves as a substrate for a peroxidase enzyme coupled to a primary or secondary antibody.
  • It is oxidised and converted to an insoluble polymer, precipitating as a dark brown pigment, which allows visualisation of the target molecule.

 

FITC (Fluorescein Isothiocyanate) (Option A) is a fluorescent dye that is used in fluorescence microscopy to detect specific antigens but does not produce a brown colour. It would instead produce a green fluorescence.

Phycoerythrin (Option B) is another fluorescent dye often used in flow cytometry and fluorescence microscopy but does not produce a brown colouration. It fluoresces red-orange and is used for labelling antibodies.

Cyanate dye (Option C) is commonly used in fluorescence-based applications such as fluorescent labelling of biomolecules in biological and biochemical research. These dyes are known for their high sensitivity and photostability.

questions.text: A 70-year-old diabetic man presents after a fall. He is having a high fever, cough and breathing difficulty and appears confused. CXR shows lobar consolidation. Labs show elevated BUN and creatinine. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Discharge home on Amoxicillin with Clavulanic acid

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inpatient management with Levofloxacin

Explanation:

  • The scenario here is of a patient with severe pneumonia with a CURB-65 score of 3 and a comorbidity (diabetes). Hence the modality of treatment would be inpatient management with levofloxacin (respiratory fluoroquinolones).

Status

Regimen



 

No comorbidities or risk factors for antibiotic resistance

Combination therapy with Amoxicillin + either Macrolide or Doxycycline

OR

Monotherapy with Doxycycline

OR

Monotherapy with a Macrolide


 

With comorbidities ± Risk factors for antibiotic resistance

Combination therapy with:

Amoxicillin /clavulanate or a Cephalosporin +

Macrolide or Doxycycline

OR

Monotherapy with respiratory fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin)

Incorrect Options:

Inpatient management with Ceftriaxone (Option B) alone is not enough and will need a combination of Macrolide or Doxycycline with it.

Discharge home with Amoxicillin and Clavulanic acid (Option C) is not a choice for severe pneumonia as given in this scenario.

Discharge home on Azithromycin (Option D) alone is not enough and needs a combination of Amoxicillin /Clavulanate (or Cephalosporins) with it. This is not suitable for severe cases.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements


	Statement 1-Contemplation - A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking
	Statement 2 - Precontemplation - A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to their health
	Statement 3- Maintenance phase- A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then
	Statement 4-Action phase- A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Statements 1 and 3 are correct:

Transtheoretical Model of Change (also known as the Stages of Change Model)

  • It is a comprehensive model that describes an individual's journey through different stages of behavior change.

  • Developed by Prochaska and DiClemente, this model is relevant in addiction, smoking cessation, and lifestyle changes.

  • The model comprises five stages:

Precontemplation

(Statement 2 ruled out)

  • The individual is not considering a change in behaviour in the foreseeable future.

  • They may be unaware or in denial about the need for change.

Contemplation

(Statement 1)

  • The individual recognises the problem and is considering change but is not yet ready to take action.

Preparation

  • The individual is intending to take action shortly (usually within the next 30 days)

  • May have started taking small steps toward change.

Action

(Statement 4 ruled out)

  • The individual has recently made changes (within the last 6 months)

  • Actively working to maintain those changes.

Maintenance

(Statement 3)

  • The individual has sustained their behaviour change for more than 6 months

  • Working to prevent relapse.

questions.text: What is the underlying reason for the lack of fructose in seminal fluid?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Both of the above

Explanation:

Fructose, a significant energy source for the sperm, is produced by the seminal vesicles and ejaculated in the semen. Hence, any obstruction of the ejaculatory duct or the absence of seminal vesicles can lead to a decreased concentration of fructose in the semen.

The absence of fructose can be seen in:

  • Congenital absence of seminal vesicle
  • Obstruction of ejaculatory duct or vas deferens or seminal vesicle
  • Inflammation of the ejaculatory duct, vas deferens, or seminal vesicle leading to obstruction
  • Congenital absence of the vas deferens

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive man presents with neck rigidity and papilledema. His CSF sample showed a capsulated organism positive for India ink staining. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Delay antiretroviral therapy by 4-6 weeks after the initiation of antifungal treatment
Brain imaging shows changes in > 80 % of patients

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Delay antiretroviral therapy by 4-6 weeks after the initiation of antifungal treatment

Explanation:

  • The patient has signs and symptoms of meningitis, which, along with the positive India ink stain leads to the diagnosis of Cryptococcal meningitis, which is a CNS complication of HIV occurring due to opportunistic infection by Cryptococcus neoformans.

 

Fungal Meningitis in AIDS

  • The leading cause of meningitis in AIDS patients is primarily Cryptococcus neoformans (C. neoformans), with C. gattii accounting for up to 12% of cases.
  • Cryptococcal meningitis is common in patients with CD4+ T-cell counts <100/μL, especially in untreated AIDS patients.

Symptoms:

  • Subacute meningoencephalitis with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs
  • Seizures and focal neurologic deficits are rare
  • Elevated intracranial pressure (Option A)

CSF Findings:

  • Mild increase in WBCs and protein
  • Low glucose
  • Elevated opening pressure

Diagnosis:

  • CSF: Positive India ink examination
  • Cryptococcal antigen detection in CSF
  • Blood cultures may also be positive
  • A biopsy may be needed for CNS cryptococcoma or distinguishing from immune reconstitution syndrome
  • MRI: Soap bubble appearance is seen in less than 30% of cases (Option D)

 

Treatment:

  • Initial: IV Amphotericin B with Flucytosine for at least 2 weeks. (Option C)
  • Continued with Amphotericin until CSF culture is negative, followed by Fluconazole (400 mg/d) for 8 weeks and then 200 mg/d until CD4+ T-cell count >200/μL for 6 months.
  • Repeated lumbar punctures may be needed to manage elevated intracranial pressure.

 

Immune Reconstitution Syndrome:

  • Occurs after initiating effective ART, leading to worsening of pre-existing opportunistic infections or autoimmune conditions.
  • Types of IRIS:
    • Paradoxical IRIS: Exacerbation of known pre-existing infections or neoplasms.
    • Unmasking IRIS: Emergence of previously undiagnosed conditions.
    • Immune Reconstitution Disease (IRD): Refers to IRIS related to opportunistic infections or autoimmune diseases.
  • Symptoms:
    • Lymphadenitis
    • Prolonged fever
    • Pulmonary infiltrates
    • Hepatitis
    • Increased intracranial pressure
    • Uveitis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Graves’ disease
  • Mechanism: Related to type IV hypersensitivity reactions due to immune recovery as HIV RNA levels drop and immune suppression is reversed.
  • Management:
    • Severe cases may require immunosuppressive drugs (e.g., glucocorticoids) alongside specific antimicrobial therapy.
    • Due to the risk of IRIS (immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome), ART should be deferred by 4-6 weeks after the initiation of antifungal treatment.

 

Other Causes:

  • Other fungi like C. immitis and H. capsulatum, as well as amoebas like Acanthamoeba and Naegleria, can cause meningitis in HIV-infected individuals.

questions.text: What further test should be conducted for a 60-year-old male patient who has presented with widespread lymph node enlargement, elevated white blood cell count, and smudge cells observed on peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Flow cytometry from peripheral blood

Explanation:

  • The given clinical presentation of a 60-year-old male with lymph node enlargement, elevated WBC, and smudge cells (characteristic cells) on the peripheral smear strongly suggests Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL).
  • Flow cytometry is a highly sensitive technique used to identify the specific cell surface markers on the abnormal lymphocytes in CLL.
  • It helps distinguish CLL from other types of lymphoma and leukaemia.
  • Flow cytometry markers of CLL include CD 5+, CD10-, CD19+, CD20+, CD 23+ and CD 200+


Cytogenic studies (Option A), including Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization

  • (FISH), are helpful in identifying specific genetic mutations associated with CLL, which have prognostic implications. However, flow cytometry is a more immediate and critical step for diagnosis, as it directly assesses the immunophenotype of the cells.

Bone marrow biopsy (Option B) might be performed later to evaluate marrow involvement or disease progression, but it is not the first-line investigation for CLL. Given the peripheral smear findings, Flow cytometry helps to assess the immunophenotype of the lymphocytes.

X-ray crystallography (Option D) is a technique used to determine the atomic and molecular structure of crystals. It is irrelevant in the context of diagnosing CLL.

questions.text: Where is the SRY region located in the body?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Short arm of Y chromosome

Explanation:

The SRY gene/region is the sex-determining gene/ region present on the short arm of the Y chromosome.

SRY gene

  • Present in the distal region of the short arm of the Y chromosome.
  • Significant in determining the male sex and expresses at the 5th to 6th week of development.
  • When this gene is not expressed, ovarian development takes place in XX karyotype.
  • Mutation of the SRY gene leads to Swyer syndrome.
    • Patients with Swyer syndrome have a karyotype of 46XY, but the Mullerian system develops.
    • These people are phenotypically female with female external and internal genitalia.
    • Gonads are usually streak ovaries with only gonadal stroma, but the vagina, uterus, and fallopian tubes are all formed.

questions.text: A phlebotomist is asked to collect blood samples for a patient undergoing multiple tests. Which of the following is the correct order of blood collection to avoid contamination of the samples based on the additives in the collection tubes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Light blue → red → lavender → grey

Explanation:

  • The correct order here is Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey
  • In blood collection, it's crucial to follow the correct order to prevent contamination between tubes with different additives.
  • The correct order of drawing the blood in vacutainers is
    • Blood culture → Light blue → Red or Yellow → Green → Lavender → Pink → Grey

Vacutainer colour

Additive

Uses

Blood culture

Broth media (aerobic/anaerobic)

For detecting bacterial and fungal infections

Light blue

Trisodium citrate

For coagulation tests

Red or Yellow

No additive (Red) / Gel separator (Yellow)

For serum collection (serology, chemistry)

Green

Heparin

For plasma collection (chemistry tests)

Lavender

EDTA

For haematology tests (e.g., CBC, blood smears)

Pink

 

EDTA

For blood bank tests (e.g., crossmatch, blood type

Grey

Potassium Oxalate + Sodium Fluoride

For glucose, lactate, and alcohol tests

questions.text: Hormone Replacement Therapy is truly associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Decreased risk of colon cancer

Explanation:

The true association of hormone replacement therapy is with a decreased risk of colon cancer.

Hormone replacement therapy

  • This is used for the treatment of menopausal symptoms
  • They are usually estrogen and occasionally in combination with progesterone
  • HRT decreases the risk of colon cancer due to the protective effects of estrogen
  • Hence, the incidence of colon cancer is rare amongst women of reproductive age group compared to men of the same age group

Indications of HRT:

  • Therapeutic:
    • Symptomatic menopausal women
    • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • Prophylactic:
  • Patients at high risk for menopausal complications like cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, stroke, colon cancer, etc
  • Premature menopause: Spontaneous following surgery or cancer therapy

 

Breast cancer risk (Option A) is increased by hyperestrogenism. Breast cancer following HRT is usually low-grade and shows a good prognosis.

Estrogen replacement (Option B) can increase the risk of well-differentiated endometrial carcinoma. The addition of progesterone to estrogen reduces the risk of endometrial cancer.

After menopause, bone density decreases every year, leading to osteopenia and, eventually, osteoporosis (Option C). Osteoporosis would usually result in fractures of vertebrae, femur and wrist. HRT using estrogen protects against osteoporosis and decreases the risk of fractures.

questions.text: A patient on amitriptyline was discovered unconscious at home and potentially suspected of TCA toxicity. Which of the following features is less commonly associated with TCA toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hypothermia:

  • Amitriptyline is a Tricyclic Antidepressant (TCA) that can cause hyperthermia as a side effect rather than hypothermia.

Side effects of Tricyclic antidepressants (TCA):

Mechanism of side effect

Side effect

H1 receptor blockade
  • Sedation, weight gain

Anticholinergic action on muscarinic receptors
  • Hyperthermia (Option C)
  • Dry eyes/mouth
  • Mydriasis (C/I in glaucoma) (Option D ruled out)
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Tachycardia
  • Confusion (Option B ruled out)

Increase in serotonin in the brain
  • Seizure threshold reduction

Alpha 1 adrenergic receptor antagonism
  • Postural hypotension

Sodium channel block
  • Arrhythmia/QT prolongation (Option A ruled out)
  • Bradycardia in heart block due to overdose

TCA poisoning

  • Poisoning with TCAs is frequent, usually self-attempted for suicide, and may endanger life.
  • Manifestations are Excitement, delirium and other anticholinergic symptoms, as seen in atropine poisoning, followed by muscle spasms, convulsions and coma. Respiration is depressed, body temperature may fall, low BP, and prominent tachycardia. ECG changes and ventricular arrhythmias are common.

 

Treatment

  • Primarily supportive with gastric lavage, respiratory assistance, fluid infusion, maintenance of BP and body temperature.
  • Acidosis must be corrected by bicarbonate infusion.
  • Diazepam may be injected I.V. to control convulsions and delirium.
  • Most important is treating cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/ lidocaine may be used. The class IA and IC antiarrhythmics and digoxin depress cardiac conduction; therefore, they are contraindicated.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with high-grade fever for the past week. On examination neck stiffness and Kernig's sign were positive. CSF analysis showed lymphocytosis protein - 8 g/L, glucose - 20 mg/dl while RBS = 140 mg/dl. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tubercular meningitis

Explanation:

  • The low glucose, high protein, and lymphocytosis in the cerebrospinal fluid all point to the diagnosis of tubercular meningitis.


Tuberculous Meningitis

Symptoms and Clinical Features:
  • Headache, slight mental changes, and low-grade fever can develop over weeks, often accompanied by malaise, anorexia, and irritability.
  • More severe cases present with confusion, lethargy, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium.
  • Disease progression: evolves over 1–2 weeks, longer than bacterial meningitis.
  • Cranial nerve palsies, especially ocular nerves, are common due to inflammation at the base of the brain.
  • May result in coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension if untreated.
  • Cerebral ischemia can result from the involvement of cerebral arteries.
  • Tuberculoma (space-occupying lesion) may cause seizures and focal neurological signs.

CSF Findings:
  • Elevated leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL, predominantly lymphocytes).
  • High protein content (1-8 g/L).
  • Low glucose concentration.

Investigation of Choice:
  • Culture of CSF (gold standard, takes 4-8 weeks, positive in ~50%).
  • Smear for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) (low sensitivity, positive in 10-40%).
  • PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA (variable sensitivity).

Imaging:
  • CT/MRI may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.
  • Tuberculomas appear as contrast-enhanced ring lesions on imaging.

MRI showing ring-enhanced lesions- tuberculoma

Treatment:
  • Empirical therapy is often initiated based on suspicion.
  • Initial drug regimen: Isoniazid, Rifampin, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol, and Pyridoxine.
  • Duration: 6–12 months depending on response.
  • Dexamethasone (12–16 mg/day) for 3 weeks, tapered for 3 more weeks (recommended for HIV-negative patients).
  • Tuberculoma may require a biopsy for diagnosis.

 

Type

Opening Pressure

Predominant Cell Type

Protein

Glucose

Gross Appearance

Bacterial Meningitis

(Option C)

Elevated

Polymorphonuclear Neutrophils (PMNs)

Elevated

Decreased

Turbid

Fungal/Tubercular Meningitis

Elevated

Lymphocytes

Elevated

Decreased

Straw-colored (TB meningitis)

Viral Meningitis

(Option B & D)

Normal or Slightly Elevated

Lymphocytes

Normal or Slightly Elevated

Normal

Normal or Turbid

questions.text: In cases of gonadal sex reversal syndrome with an XX karyotype, what is the most common underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Translocation

Explanation:

In cases of gonadal sex reversal syndrome with an XX karyotype, the most common underlying cause is a translocation.

  • Translocation refers to the rearrangement of chromosomal material between non-homologous chromosomes.
  • Sex reversal syndrome, also known as disorder of sex development (DSD), occurs when there is a discrepancy between an individual's chromosomal, gonadal, and phenotypic sex.
  • In the context of gonadal sex reversal syndrome with an XX karyotype, a translocation involving the SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene can result in its presence on an X chromosome.
  • The SRY gene is responsible for initiating male development, so translocating to an X chromosome can lead to the development of testes instead of ovaries in individuals with an XX karyotype.

questions.text: Which of the following for Sickle cell anaemia is correct?

choices.text: Low mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

Explanation:

  • Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a hemoglobinopathy characterized by the presence of abnormal haemoglobin, known as haemoglobin S (HbS).
  • Under low oxygen conditions, HbS polymerizes, causing RBCs to assume a sickle shape.
  • Sickle-shaped RBCs are more rigid and less deformable, leading to high mechanical fragility, making them more likely to rupture under stress.
  • Unlike normal RBCs, sickle-shaped RBCs have low osmotic fragility, meaning they are less prone to hemolysis in hypotonic solutions.

questions.text: A patient was taking ampicillin for an upper respiratory tract infection. Then he started having watery diarrhoea for the past 3 days. Which is the drug of choice to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fidaxomicin

Explanation:

  • The overuse of antibiotics like ampicillin leads to diarrhoea and further, a condition called pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridium difficile and is treated with Fidaxomicin.

 

Clostridioides Difficile Infection (CDI)

  • A colonic disease caused by C. difficile, linked to antibiotic use disrupting normal gut microbiome.
  • It results in diarrhoea and severe cases, of pseudomembranous colitis (PMC).

Etiology & Epidemiology:

  • C. difficile is a spore-forming, anaerobic bacterium.
  • Most commonly acquired in hospitals, nursing homes, and after antibiotic use.
  • High-risk antibiotics: Clindamycin, Ampicillin, Cephalosporins, and Fluoroquinolones (Option C).
  • CDI is common in healthcare settings and can also occur in the community without prior antibiotic use.

Pathogenesis:

  • Ingestion of spores leads to toxin production (Toxin A and Toxin B) causing gut damage, diarrhoea, and PMC.
  • Toxin B is the more important virulence factor.

Diagnosis:

  • Based on diarrhoea (≥3 unformed stools/day for ≥2 days).
  • Toxin detection in stool (via PCR or enzyme immunoassays).
  • Endoscopy can detect PMC in advanced cases.

Treatment:

  • First-line:
    • Oral Vancomycin or Fidaxomicin
    • Metronidazole is an alternative for mild cases. (Option A)
  • Hydration and avoiding antiperistaltic agents are recommended.
  • For severe cases, Oral Vancomycin is preferred, especially if the patient is seriously ill.
  • IV Vancomycin is ineffective.


Bezlotoxumab (Option D) is a monoclonal antibody against C.difficile toxin B used in recurrent pseudomembranous colitis as an adjunct with vancomycin, fidaxomicin or metronidazole. It is not the first-line treatment for this condition.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with a bleeding disorder following autosomal dominant inheritance. She gave the history of her father and sister having the same bleeding disorders. What is the most likely disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Von Willebrand disease

Explanation:

  • Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder caused by defective or deficient von Willebrand factor (vWF).
  • It follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, affecting both males and females, with a 50% chance of passing the disorder to offspring.

 

  • Von Willebrand disease is clinically and molecularly heterogeneous, with three identified types, each exhibiting a variety of phenotypes.

vWD type 1

vWD Type 2

vWD Type 3

  • Autosomal dominant.
  • The most common type.
  • Mild to moderate vWF deficiency.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • Point substitutions prevent the vWF protein from maturing or cause it to leave the plasma quickly.

 
  • Autosomal dominant.
  • Qualitative defect.


Types: 2A, 2B, 2M, 2N

  • 2A (Most common) - Decrease in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9 Missense mutations cause faulty multimer formation → the most active forms of vWF, i.e. large- and intermediate-sized multimers are absent.
  • 2B - Increase in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9
  • 2M - VWF-dependent platelet adhesion is decreased. VWF binding to platelets is impaired. Type 2M VWD typically has mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding
  • 2N - There is a marked decline in the binding affinity for factor VIII. The level of factor VIII is lower when compared to the VWF: Ag. This led to misdiagnosis as haemophilia A.
  • Autosomal recessive.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • Produced by frameshift mutations or deletions affecting both alleles (autosomal recessive), which produce little or no vWF.
  • Factor VIII levels are also lowered because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the blood, and the resulting bleeding condition is severe.

 

 

Hemophilia A (Option B) is an X-linked recessive disorder that mainly affects males, with females being carriers. This makes it an unlikely diagnosis for this patient, who has a family history involving females.

Christmas disease (Option C) is an X-linked recessive disorder; hence, this condition is primarily seen in males, and it is less likely to be the cause of an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

Factor X deficiency (Option D) is a rare bleeding disorder that can be inherited in autosomal recessive patterns, which causes the clotting process to take longer than normal.

questions.text: Serum transferrin saturation level is low. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Iron Deficiency Anemia

Explanation:

  • Serum transferrin saturation is a key marker of iron status in the body.
  • Low serum transferrin saturation indicates low iron stores, which is commonly seen in iron deficiency anaemia.

 

Investigations for IDA

Iron Study

Interpretation in Iron Deficiency Anemia

Serum Ferritin

Low (< 30 ng/mL) indicates depleted iron stores.

Serum Iron (Fe)

Low levels are seen.

Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)

Increased TIBC reflects the increased capacity of transferrin to bind iron in response to low iron stores.

Transferrin saturation

Is decreased, which refers to the percentage of transferrin that is bound to iron

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW)

Increased RDW is often seen in iron deficiency anaemia

Bone Marrow Aspiration and Iron Staining

Confirmatory test

 

Type of Anemia

Serum Iron

Transferrin saturation

Serum Ferritin

TIBC

Sideroblastic Anemia

(Option C ruled out)

High

High

High

Low

Iron Deficiency Anemia

Low

Low

Low

High

Hemochromatosis

(Option B ruled out)

High

High

High

Low

Pernicious anaemia (Option D) is an autoimmune condition that occurs when the body can't absorb enough vitamin B12. It does not primarily affect iron metabolism, and transferring saturation levels would not be low in this condition.
