questions.text: A 23-year-old female with 6 years of infertility has a BMI of 33 and facial hair. Investigations reveal she has PCOS and spills from bilateral tubes. She and her husband are trying to conceive. What would be the best management plan for this lady?

choices.text: Metformin + Weight reduction + Ovulation induction with clomiphene
Weight reduction + Metformin +Ovulation induction with urinary gonadotropins
Weight loss + Folic acid, try for spontaneous induction. If failed, move to induction of ovulation

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Weight loss + Folic acid, try for spontaneous induction. If failed, move to induction of ovulation

Explanation:

In this scenario, since the woman is trying to conceive, she is given folic acid, advised weight loss exercises, and to try for spontaneous induction.

If spontaneous conception does not occur, then induction of ovulation can be considered.

Conservative management:

  • Fairly regular cycles and mild hyperandrogenism: Need not be treated
  • Obese women with PCOS: Lifestyle changes (diet and exercise)

Drugs used to treat Infertility in PCOS:

Letrozole (preferred over clomiphene citrate)

  • Aromatase inhibitors
  • No antiestrogenic action on the endometrium and cervix, thus yielding a better pregnancy rate.
  • Induces Mono Follicular stimulation, thus avoiding multiple pregnancies
  • No hyperstimulation syndrome
  • Side effect - drowsiness

Clomiphene citrate

  • Unlike letrozole, it has anti-estrogenic action on the endometrium and cervix, thereby decreasing the fertility rate.
  • It can cause hyperstimulation Syndrome in <1% of patients.
  • It induces ovulation in 80% of the cases, and 40-45% conceive.
  • Co-administration of dexamethasone leads to better outcomes.
  • In resistant cases, Tamoxifen 80-160 mg daily for 5 days was tried.

Metformin

  • It is used as an insulin sensitiser.
  • Reduces the insulin levels, delays glucose absorption and production of glucose in the liver
  • It also improves the peripheral utilisation of the glucose. Reduces the free and total testosterone, and increases SHBG (sex hormone-binding globulin).
  • Contraindicated in hepatic and renal disease

 

Nowadays, instead of Metformin, some gynaecologists prefer using N-acetyl cysteine with micronutrients. This reduces the homocysteine level and improves fertility outcomes.

Metformin, weight reduction, and ovulation induction with clomiphene (Option A) are advised in cases of PCOS with insulin resistance. Metformin is a biguanide insulin sensitizer agent that is used off-label for PCOS to help restore cyclic menstruation, lower hyperandrogenism, and help in weight loss. However, the first line of management for PCOS is weight loss and exercise to manage complications like infertility, CVD, and diabetes.

Weight reduction + Metformin + ovulation induction with urinary gonadotropins (Option B), as mentioned above, is used if there is insulin resistance. Urinary gonadotropins are used for the treatment of clomiphene citrate-resistant PCOS, which is not the given scenario.

Metformin + Finasteride + Ovulation induction (Option C) is a combination used for PCOS with diabetes and hirsutism. Finasteride blocks the conversion of testosterone to DHT and, being an antiandrogen, should not be given to a woman trying to conceive as it can affect the male fetus.

questions.text: After class switching, a particular class of antibody is produced, but IgM and IgD are expressed concomitantly on the surface of a B cell due to which of the following phenomena?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Alternate RNA splicing

Explanation:

  • B cells express both IgM and IgD antibodies simultaneously due to alternative RNA splicing.
  • This mechanism allows the same heavy chain gene to be spliced in different ways, resulting in the production of both IgM and IgD isotypes.
  • Although IgM and IgD are derived from the same heavy chain gene, the splicing process generates distinct versions of the RNA transcript, one for IgM and one for IgD.
  • Both antibodies share the same antigen-binding specificity but differ in their constant regions, which determine their respective isotypes.

Allelic exclusion (Option A) ensures that only one allele of the immunoglobulin gene is expressed in a B cell at a time, maintaining clonal specificity, but it does not account for the co-expression of IgM and IgD.

Somatic hypermutation (Option C) takes place after antigen exposure and enhances the affinity of antibodies, but it does not play a role in the simultaneous expression of IgM and IgD.

Affinity maturation (Option D) is a process that improves antibody affinity during the immune response, but it does not generate multiple antibody classes concurrently.

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of high-output cardiac failure, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cor pulmonale

Explanation:

  • Cor pulmonale is a change in the structure and function of the right ventricle developing as a result of a pulmonary disorder leading to pulmonary hypertension. This is not associated with high-output cardiac failure but with right ventricular hypertrophy.

Causes of high-output cardiac failure

Category

Aetiology

Pathophysiology




 

Metabolic

Hyperthyroidism

Increased thyroid hormone increases contractility, heart rate, and systemic metabolism, causing reduced systemic vascular resistance and eventually cardiomyopathy.

Myeloproliferative disorders

Increased cellular metabolism and turnover, leading to higher metabolic demand and decreased systemic vascular resistance.







 

Myocardial

Sepsis

Inflammatory response leads to vasodilation and high cardiac output; initially hyperdynamic phase with low systemic vascular resistance.

Thiamine deficiency (Beriberi) (Option B)

Thiamine deficiency causes systemic vasodilation and direct myocardial effects, resulting in high venous return and cardiomyopathy.

Chronic lung disease

Chronic hypoxia and hypercapnia reduce systemic arterial resistance, causing chronic volume overload and right-sided heart failure.





 

Peripheral vascular

Arteriovenous fistulas (AVF) (Option D)

Shunt from artery to vein bypasses the arteriolar and capillary bed, increasing venous return to the heart, and requiring increased cardiac output.

Liver cirrhosis

Impaired clearance of vasoactive substances and bacterial translocation lead to decreased systemic vascular resistance and high-output failure.

Obesity

Excessive vasodilation due to adipokines and altered myocardial metabolism contribute to high-output cardiac failure.







 

Other

Erythroderma

Vasoactive changes that may lead to high-output cardiac failure (less defined).

Carcinoid syndrome

Tumor secretion of vasoactive substances can cause vasodilation and reduced systemic vascular resistance.

Mitochondrial disorders

Altered cellular metabolism and energy production lead to increased demand and potential high-output failure.

Acromegaly

Increased growth hormone can lead to increased tissue demand and altered vascular resistance.

Paget disease of bone

Increased bone turnover leads to AVF formation, contributing to high-output cardiac failure.

Conditions

Stress, exercise, fever, pregnancy

Temporary increases in metabolic demand or vasodilation, though not direct causes of high-output cardiac failure.
 

Anemia (Option C)

The attempt to compensate for reduced oxygen delivery by increasing cardiac output leads to high-output cardiac failure later on.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with painless ulcers on the vulva; she gives a history of having multiple sexual partners. From the given options, what is the next best step to arrive at a diagnosis based on these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) VDRL

Explanation:

History of multiple sexual partners suggests a possibility of sexually transmitted disease, and the most common cause of painless genital ulcer is syphilis. The test for syphilis is the Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test.

  • Syphilis is caused by a spirochete called Treponema pallidum.
  • Painless genital ulcers can be caused by several STIs, including syphilis (M/c), donovanosis, and lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).

 

Investigations for syphilis:

  • Serological tests: Nontreponemal and treponemal-specific tests

Non-treponemal tests

Treponemal-specific tests

  • VDRL test
  • RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin test)
  • FTA-ABS
  • TP-PA
  • Both these tests measure IgM and IgG antibodies against cardiolipin.
  • False positives:
    • Recent vaccination
    • Febrile illness
    • Pregnancy
    • IV drug abusers
    • SLE
    • Ageing
    • Cancer

They remain positive for life after the infection.

 

While NAT (Option B) can be used to detect various STIs, such as HIV, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C, it is not typically the first-line diagnostic test for syphilis. VDRL is more commonly used for screening and initial diagnosis of syphilis.

Vaginal swab and culture (Option C) can be used for fungal and bacterial infections with vaginal discharge. This option may be appropriate for diagnosing other genital infections, such as bacterial vaginosis or candidiasis, but it is not the most suitable test for diagnosing syphilis.

The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) (Option D) is a technique for amplifying many copies of a specific DNA sequence. It is used in many bacterial and viral infections, including syphilis. However, it is not the first line of investigation.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male with 400 ml urine output per 24 hrs. On histology, he had RPGN with Pauci immune glomerulonephritis with crescents. What is the main etiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ANCA

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of RPGN with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis and crescents on histology strongly suggests an ANCA-associated vasculitis.
  • Pauci-immune means that there are few immune complexes present in the glomeruli, which is typical of ANCA-associated vasculitis.
  • ANCA are commonly associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s), microscopic polyangiitis, and Churg-Strauss syndrome, which can lead to pauci-immune RPGN.

 

Type I RPGN (Anti-GBM antibody-mediated)

Type II RPGN (Immune complex-mediated)

Type III RPGN (Pauci-immune) (M/C type)

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Goodpasture syndrome- the presence of Anti GBM. (Option A ruled out)

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  3. Lupus (SLE) nephritis - ANA positive (Option D ruled out)
  4. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  5. IgA nephropathy

Includes:

  1. ANCA-associated
  2. Idiopathic
  3. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  4. Microscopic polyangiitis

IF finding:

Linear/ribbon pattern (Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3)

IF finding:

Lumpy Bumpy/ Granular/ Starry Sky/Garland Pattern (granular antibody deposits)

IF finding:

No deposits

Electron microscopy: RPGN causes Rupture and wRinkling of GBM

 

 

Anti PLA2R (Option C) antibody is primarily associated with membranous nephropathy, which presents with nephrotic syndrome, not RPGN. The histological findings do not align with membranous nephropathy, which typically shows thickening of the glomerular basement membrane without hypercellularity on light microscopy and a "spike and dome" appearance of subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy.

questions.text: A pregnant female with bipolar disorder came to the outpatient department in the third trimester. She has had 4 episodes in the past and is stable on lithium 750 mg/day since 1 year, during which time she has not had any episodes. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop lithium and let her be drug-free

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Decrease lithium dosage:

  • In this scenario, a dose reduction of lithium may be considered, particularly as the patient approaches her expected delivery date. Adjusting the lithium dose during this period is important to prevent potential toxicity in the newborn.

Treatment of Bipolar Disorder (BD) in Pregnancy:

  • The safety of pharmacotherapeutic agents for treating bipolar disorder must be considered in terms of the following:
    • Teratogenicity
    • Poor neonatal adaptation
    • Long-term neurobehavioral sequelae
Mood Stabilizers

Medication

Potential Fetal/Newborn risk

Clinical Recommendation

Lithium

 
  • Low risk of Ebstein’s anomaly: 1 in 1000 with first-trimester exposure
  • No evidence of behavioural or cognitive problems in children exposed to lithium till 5 years of age
  • Fetal echocardiography
  • Frequent serum lithium monitor because of fluid shifts over pregnancy
  • Should be well hydrated to reduce chances of lithium toxicity

Valproic acid

 
  • Increased rate of congenital malformations.
  • Linked to neurodevelopmental disorders in children with in-utero exposure
  • Must be avoided in favor of safer agents
  • Before conception, women with BD preferably to be shifted to another safer prophylactic agent
  • High-dose folic acid supplementation (4 mg/day) is advised before conception

Carbamazepine

 
  • Congenital malformations: Neural tube defect, cleft palate, fingernail hypoplasia.
  • Risk of bleeding diathesis in neonates due to Vitamin K deficiency
  • If possible, use in pregnancy should be avoided.
  • High-dose folic acid supplementation (4 mg/day) advised prior to conception
  • Oral Vitamin K (20mg/day) supplementation in the last month of pregnancy in women taking carbamazepine
  • Parenteral Vitamin K (1mg IM) supplementation for newborn shortly after birth.

Lamotrigine

 
  • Risk of major congenital malformations.
  • No significant neurobehavioral sequelae.
  • Preferred safer agent to use in pregnancy.
  • Dose may be increased due to enhanced clearance rates across pregnancy stages.
Other Drugs for Bipolar Disorder Safe in Pregnancy
  • First Generation Antipsychotics (FGA): Haloperidol, Trifluoperazine
  • Second Generation Antipsychotics (SGA): Olanzapine, quetiapine, aripiprazole
  • Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRI): Fluoxetine, escitalopram, sertraline, fluvoxamine

Option A - Stop lithium and let her be drug-free: Rapid discontinuation can lead to the recurrence of the patient's manic symptoms. This may lead to a worsening of overall outcomes.

Option C - Increase lithium Dosage: If the patient is well-controlled on the current dose and there are no signs of relapse, increasing the dose is generally not necessary and could expose the fetus to higher levels of lithium.

Option D - Switch to Valproate: The patient is currently in her third trimester, and her symptoms are effectively managed with lithium. The teratogenic effects of lithium are usually observed in the first trimester of pregnancy, and it is relatively safe for use in the third trimester (with routine monitoring). There is no need to change her mood stabiliser to valproate at present.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of cough, night sweats, and fever. A lung biopsy demonstrates the following histological findings. What is the most likely cytokine involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Interferon-γ

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with cough, night sweats, and fever, along with the histological finding of granulomas and multinucleated giant cells, is highly indicative of a granulomatous condition like Tuberculosis (TB), which is typically driven by the immune response, specifically by the cytokine interferon-γ (IFN-γ)
  • T-lymphocytes release IFN-γ when exposed to M. tuberculosis antigens, which activate macrophages, enhancing their ability to kill intracellular bacteria.
  • Despite IFN-γ activation of macrophages, the bacteria are often not completely eliminated, and they can survive inside the macrophages, evading complete eradication.
  • This results in a chronic infection, leading to continued replication of M. tuberculosis and the formation of granulomas.
  • The granuloma acts as a protective structure around the bacteria, but in some cases, it can break down, leading to active disease and further spread of the infection.

Complement C5a (Option B) is a chemotactic factor in the complement system. It helps attract neutrophils and other immune cells to the site of infection. However, it does not directly contribute to granuloma formation or the activation of macrophages needed for multinucleated giant cell formation.

Histamine (Option C) is involved in the acute inflammatory response, causing vasodilation and increasing vascular permeability. It does not play a direct role in the formation of granulomas or the differentiation of macrophages into giant cells.

Bradykinin (Option D) is part of the acute inflammatory response, not the chronic inflammatory response seen in granulomatous diseases. It does not play a role in granuloma formation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old farmer from Tamil Nadu presented with fever, myalgia, headache and cough. On physical examination, a lesion is seen on the chest. Lung auscultation shows extensive bilateral rales. Blood investigation showed positive IgM for scrub typhus. What would be the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Doxycycline with Azithromycin

Explanation:

  • Based on the patient's clinical presentation, presence of eschar, and positive IgM for scrub typhus, the diagnosis is confirmed as scrub typhus. Recent guidelines recommend IV doxycycline with Azithromycin as combination therapy has shown better outcomes than monotherapy, making it the preferred treatment choice.

Causative agent
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi, an intracellular bacterium.

 

Transmission

  • Bites of infected larval stage mites (chiggers).
  • These are often found in rural areas, forests, and grasslands.


 

Clinical features

  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Muscle pain
  • Eschar: Blackish scab at the site of the chigger bite
  • Rash
  • Lymphadenopathy

 

Diagnosis

  • Serology: Detection of antibodies in blood
  • PCR: Molecular detection of the bacterium












 

Management

Recent update:

  • According to a recent update, combination therapy with IV doxycycline and Azithromycin is more effective than monotherapy.

Doxycycline: (Option A)

  • First-line treatment for scrub typhus.
  • Administered at 100 mg IV or orally, twice daily for 7 to 14 days.
  • Concerns about potential doxycycline resistance in some cases.

Azithromycin:

  • Alternative to Doxycycline, especially if resistance is suspected.
  • Shorter treatment duration
  • Effective penetration into key immune cells (polymorphonuclear leukocytes and macrophages) enhances efficacy.

Rifampicin:

  • A second-line option, not first-line.
  • Risk of inducing resistant tuberculosis so should be used cautiously after ruling out active tuberculosis.

 Option B and C are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following will increase in size on electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Alpha 2 globulin

Explanation:

  • Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia, and the electrophoresis shows decreased albumin levels and increased levels of alpha-2 globulin.
  • The increase in alpha-2 globulin is due to an increase in macroglobulin, which is a larger protein, and its increase in the bloodstream serves as a compensatory mechanism in nephrotic syndrome to counteract the loss of albumin.

Gamma globulin (Option A) does not increase significantly. An increase in gamma globulins is seen in conditions like multiple myeloma or chronic inflammatory conditions, not in nephrotic syndrome.

Beta globulin (Option C) increases, but this increase is typically modest compared to the marked rise in alpha-2 globulins.

Albumin (Option D) is the major protein that decreases in size on electrophoresis in nephrotic syndrome due to its significant loss in the urine, leading to hypoalbuminemia.

questions.text: A 21 year old boxer wanted to improve the vision . Which of the following surgery is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) RK

Explanation:

Radial Keratotomy (RK) involves making radial incisions in the cornea to flatten it and correct myopia. It is no longer recommended due to its unstable results and the risk of complications, especially in young, active individuals.

For a 21-year-old boxer, RK is contraindicated because it compromises the structural integrity of the cornea, increasing the risk of corneal weakening and potential rupture due to trauma, which is a significant concern in contact sports.

 

Refractive surgeries for myopia

Incisional Method

Radial Keratotomy (RK)
  • Involves radial cuts in the cornea to flatten it, correcting myopia.
  • Used for low to moderate myopia (2-6 D).
  • No longer recommended due to the advent of safer procedures like LASIK.

Newer Methods

Photorefractive Keratectomy (PRK)

(Option B ruled out)
  • It uses an excimer laser to reshape the cornea by removing a thin corneal layer.
  • Suitable for correcting myopia up to -6 D.

Refractive Lenticule Extraction (SMILE):

(Option D ruled out)
  • A minimally invasive laser procedure where a small lenticule is removed to reshape the cornea.
  • Effective for myopia up to -10 D, with or without astigmatism.

Intercorneal Rings (ICR):
  • Rings are inserted into the cornea to flatten it and reduce refractive power.
  • Results can be unpredictable, with risks such as corneal inflammation, so is not recommended

Orthokeratology
  • A non-surgical and reversible method involving rigid contact lenses worn overnight to reshape the cornea.
  • Corrects myopia up to -5 D temporarily.

High Myopia Solutions

Clear Lens Extraction
  • Removal of the natural lens (without cloudiness) to correct very high myopia (-16 D to -18 D).
  • Less common now due to risks like retinal detachment.

Phakic Intraocular Lens (IOL) Implantation

 
  • Implantable lens placed without removing the natural lens.
  • Best for myopia exceeding -8 D, especially in patients unsuitable for laser surgery.

 

PRK, LASIK, and SMILE are safer alternatives for myopia correction and are well-suited for active individuals like athletes. These methods involve laser reshaping of the cornea with less risk of trauma-related complications than RK.

questions.text: What method is employed for the detection of autoantibodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Indirect Immunofluorescence

Explanation:

  • Indirect immunofluorescence is used to detect autoantibodies, particularly antinuclear antibodies (ANA), a hallmark of autoimmune diseases.
  • The test employs a single anti-human globulin fluorescent conjugate, making it versatile and reducing the need for multiple conjugates.

 

Type

Description

Limitation

Direct Immunofluorescence

 

Detects antigen directly using a fluorescent-labelled antibody.

(Option A ruled out)

Requires separate fluorescent conjugates for each antigen.

Indirect Immunofluorescence

It uses antiglobulin fluorescent conjugate to detect human antibodies, enhancing versatility.

Allows the use of a single anti-human conjugate.


ELISA (Option B) is widely used for quantifying specific autoantibodies, but it is not the first-line method for detecting autoantibodies broadly.

FISH (Option D) is a molecular cytogenetic technique used to detect and localize specific DNA sequences within the chromosomes. It is not for detecting autoantibodies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in very severe NPDR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neovascularization of disc

Explanation:

Neovascularization (such as on the disc) appears only in proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), which is a more advanced stage of diabetic retinopathy, involving the growth of new blood vessels. Therefore, neovascularization of the disc is not part of very severe NPDR.

 

Classification of Non-Progressive Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR)

Severity

Definition

Very mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms only

Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus hard exudates, cotton-wool spots, and/or mild retinal hemorrhages

Moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities or moderate retinal hemorrhages

Severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any one of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants
  • Venous beading in at least two
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant

Very severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any two of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants (Option C ruled out)
  • Venous beading in at least two (Option A ruled out)
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant (Option D ruled out)

Clinical Features:

Early NPDR or Background Diabetic Retinopathy

Severe NPDR or Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
  • Affects small retinal vessels.
  • Earliest sign: Microaneurysm
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Tiny hyperfluorescent dots.
  • Retinal hemorrhages: Both deep, i.e., in the inner nuclear or outer plexiform layer (dot and blot hemorrhage) and superficial, i.e., in nerve fiber layer (splinter or flame-shaped) hemorrhages
  • Hard exudates:
    • White or yellow waxy patches with well-defined margins, often at the posterior pole, in the outer plexiform layer.
    • FA: Hypofluorescence with dense exudates.
  • Edema is not marked.
  • Increased inner retinal hypoxia: Leads to multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Cotton-Wool Spots:
    • Also called soft exudates or nerve fiber infarcts.
    • Result from ischemia, not exudation.
    • Caused by obstruction of axoplasmic flow, leading to swelling and a white, fluffy appearance.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence due to local ischemia.
  • Venous Beading:
    • Indicates sluggish retinal circulation.
    • Typically adjacent to large areas of capillary nonperfusion. (Option D)
  • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA):
    • Dilated capillaries act as collateral channels.
    • Bypass capillary bed and is often seen adjacent to capillary nonperfusion.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence

questions.text:
Match the columns


	
		
			
			A. Autosomal dominant
			
			
			1. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
			
		
		
			
			B. X-linked recessive
			
			
			2. Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
			
		
		
			
			C. Autosomal recessive
			
			
			3. Cystic fibrosis
			
		
		
			
			D. Mitochondrial
			
			
			4. Myotonic dystrophy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

Explanation:

Autosomal dominant

Myotonic dystrophy

X-linked recessive

Duchenne muscular dystrophy

Autosomal recessive

Cystic fibrosis

Mitochondrial

Leber hereditary optic neuropathy

 

 

Modes of inheritance

Mode of Inheritance

Pedigree

Explanation

Diseases

Autosomal Dominant

  • Vertical transmission
  • Affected individuals in every generation
  • Male-to-male transmission
  • Equal male: female ratio
  • Huntington's disease
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Neurofibromatosis type
  • Myotonic dystrophy

 

 

Autosomal Recessive

  • Horizontal transmission
  • Skips generations
  • Consanguinity often seen
  • Equal male: female ratio
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Beta-thalassemia

 

X-Linked Dominant

 

 

  • No male-to-male transmission
  • Affected fathers pass the trait to all daughters
  • More severely affected males.

 
  • Orofaciodigital syndrome.
  • Incontinentia Pigmenti
  • Vitamin D-resistant rickets.

 

X-Linked Recessive

  • Primarily affects males.
  • No male-to-male transmission.
  • Unaffected carrier females.
  • Hemophilia A.
  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
  • Hunter Syndrome.

 

Mitochondrial (Option D)

  • Maternal transmission only.
  • Both sexes can be affected.
  • All offspring of the affected mother are affected.
  • Leigh Disease.
  • MELAS syndrome.
  • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy.

questions.text: HEADSS assessment is done for the?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Adolescents:

The HEADSS Assessment is a psychosocial interview tool used in healthcare for evaluating various domains in adolescents. It has the following parameters:

  • H - Home environment
    • Who lives with the young person? Where?
    • Do they have their own room?
    • What are relationships like at home?
    • What do parents and relatives do for a living?
    • Ever institutionalized? Incarcerated?
    • Recent moves? Running away?
    • New people in the home environment?
  • E - Education and Employment
    • School/grade performance--any recent changes? Any dramatic past changes?
    • Favourite subjects--worst subjects? (include grades)
    • Any years repeated/classes failed
    • Suspension, termination, dropping out?
    • Future education/employment plans?
    • Any current or past employment?
    • Relations with teachers, employers--school, work attendance?
  • A - Activities and peer-related activities
    • On your own, with peers (what do you do for fun?, where? when?)
    • With family?
    • Sports--regular exercise?
    • Church attendance, clubs, projects?
    • Hobbies--other activities?
    • Reading for fun--what?
    • TV--how much weekly--favourite shows?
    • Favorite music?
    • Does a young person have a car, and use seat belts?
    • History of arrests--acting out--crime?
  • D - Drug and substance use
    • Use by peers? Use by young person? (include tobacco, alcohol)
    • Use by family members? (include tobacco, alcohol)
    • Amounts, frequency, patterns of use/abuse, and car use while intoxicated?
    • Source--how paid for?
  • S - Sexuality
    • Orientation?
    • Degree and types of sexual experience and acts?
    • Number of partners?
    • Masturbation? (normalize)
    • History of pregnancy/abortion?
    • Sexually transmitted diseases--knowledge and prevention? Contraception? Frequency of use?
    • Comfort with sexual activity, enjoyment/pleasure obtained? History of sexual/physical abuse?
  • S - Suicidality
    • Sleep disorders (usually induction problems, also early/frequent waking or greatly increased sleep and complaints of increasing fatigue)
    • Appetite/eating behaviour changes
    • Feelings of 'boredom'
    • Emotional outbursts and highly impulsive behaviour
    • History of withdrawal/isolation
    • Hopeless/helpless feelings
    • History of past suicide attempts, depression, psychological counselling
    • History of suicide attempts in family or peers
    • History of recurrent serious 'accidents'
    • Psychosomatic symptomology
    • Suicidal ideation (including significant current and past losses)
    • Decreased affect on interview, avoidance of eye contact--depression posturing
    • Preoccupation with death (clothing, media, music, art).

questions.text:
Which of the following tumour markers are positive for seminoma?


	PLAP
	OCT3/4
	NANOG
	HCG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 3 and 4

Explanation:

  • Seminomas are characterized by specific tumour markers like
    • PLAP (Placental alkaline phosphatase)
    • HCG
    • LDH
    • Newer markers:
      • OCT ¾
      • NANOG
      • CD117
      • SALL4
  • Seminoma is the most common germ cell tumour of the testis.
  • A similar presentation in the ovary is called dysgerminoma, and germinoma is present in the pineal gland.
  • Incidence: Peak incidence in the fourth decade.
  • Gross:
    • Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis.

questions.text: Which indicator is best for identifying alcohol disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) GGT

Explanation:

  • Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) is a liver enzyme that is considered a best indicator for alcohol-related liver disease.
  • It is a liver enzyme that is primarily involved in the metabolism of glutathione, an antioxidant, and plays a role in detoxifying substances in the liver.
  • Chronic alcohol consumption can induce liver stress and damage, leading to elevated GGT levels.
  • While it is elevated in alcohol use, its elevation can also occur in several other conditions. Therefore, it is a non-specific marker of alcohol-induced liver damage.

Alcoholic liver disease LFT

AST/ SGOT

(Option B ruled out)
  • Non-specific ; ↑ (<300-400)
  • This is a liver enzyme that rises in conditions causing liver damage, including alcohol-induced liver injury, but it is also elevated in a variety of non-liver conditions, like muscle injury or cardiac events.

ALT/ SGPT

(Option A ruled out)
  • Specific for liver injury ; ↑ (<300-400)
  • This is another liver enzyme that primarily indicates liver cell injury, but it is less specific for alcohol-related liver disease compared to GGT.

AST/ALT ratio: ≥ 2: 1

Specific for ALD

ALP (Alkaline phosphatase)

Elevated in bile duct pathologies

GGT (γ-glutamyl transferase)

Non-specific marker of ALD

5’-Nucleotidase

Specific marker for bile duct pathologies

S.Bilirubin

(Option D ruled out)

Usually normal/mildly ↑

S.Albumin

↓ in chronic liver disease (cirrhosis)

Carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT)

Best serum marker for alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text: What does the ECG depict in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Second-degree infra-nodal heart block

Explanation:

  • Given ECG shows progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs, which indicates Mobitz type I block, which is a type of second-degree heart block.

 

Second-degree heart block

Dropped beats occur because some impulses from the atria fail to be transmitted to the ventricles.

Types

Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach)

Mobitz Type II

Description
  • Progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs.
  • Cycle repeats itself.
  • PR interval remains constant.
  • Some P waves are not conducted.

Clinical Features
  • Often physiological; can occur in young athletes.
  • May not cause symptoms.
  • Caused by His-Purkinje system disease.
  • Higher risk of asystole.

Management
  • Typically does not require treatment.
  • Monitor for changes; consider underlying heart disease.
  • May require treatment if symptomatic.
  • Consider temporary pacing.
  • Monitor closely due to the risk of progression.

 

First-degree heart block (Option A): The PR interval is prolonged but typically not greater than 0.50 seconds, i.e. > 0.20 seconds but < 0.50 seconds. ECG does not show any dropped beat.

AV dissociation (Option D) is seen in third-degree heart blocks (complete heart block) (Option C) due to complete failure of the conduction between atria and ventricles.

questions.text: A patient on a mood stabilizer has developed hyperammonemia and hepatitis /raised hepatic enzymes. Which of the following is likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Valproate:

  • Valproate can cause hepatotoxicity and hyperammonemia by inhibiting the urea cycle, leading to elevated transaminases and, in severe cases, hepatitis.

Mechanism of action

  • Sodium Channel Inactivation: Prolongs Na+ channel inactivation in a frequency-dependent manner, similar to phenytoin.
  • Calcium Channel Modulation: Weakly attenuates the T-type calcium currents, akin to ethosuximide.
  • GABA Enhancement: Increases GABA levels by:
    • Inhibiting GABA transaminase, leading to reduced degradation.
    • Possibly enhancing GABA synthesis from glutamic acid.
  • Glutamate Receptor Blockade: Blocks excitatory NMDA glutamate receptors, reducing excitatory neurotransmission.

Uses

  • Seizure Disorders: It is the DOC for atypical absence seizures, myoclonic seizures, and generalised tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS).
  • Mood Disorders: Valproate is effective in the treatment of mania and bipolar disorder.
  • Panic Attacks: It can be used off-label for the treatment of panic attacks.
  • Migraine Prophylaxis: Valproate is considered a second-line treatment for preventing migraines.
  • Mixed Seizure Syndromes: It is used in conditions such as Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • Severe Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy: Valproate is also used in Dravet syndrome

Adverse effects

  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, and indigestion.
  • Neurological: Tremor, sedation, dizziness, and ataxia.
  • Hepatic: Hepatotoxicity (mainly in children <2 years of age).
  • Hematologic: Thrombocytopenia and other blood dyscrasias.
  • Metabolic: Weight gain, hyperammonemia, and pancreatitis.
  • Teratogenicity: Risk of congenital malformations, such as neural tube defects (spina bifida oculta), if used during pregnancy.
  • Others: Hair loss (alopecia) and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Valproate is a CYP enzyme inhibitor that inhibits CYP2C9, which can lead to increased levels of drugs metabolised by this enzyme, such as phenytoin and warfarin.

Option A - Lithium can cause adverse effects like tremors, alopecia, acne, weight gain, seizures and sinus node dysfunction, hypothyroidism, ataxia, tinnitus, diarrhea, seizures, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI), and Ebstein’s anomaly (cardiovascular defect called tricuspid atresia, which has a teratogenic effect when administered to pregnant women). It is not typically linked to hyperammonemia or hepatitis.

Option C - Carbamazepine can cause hepatotoxicity but does not cause hyperammonemia. It has adverse effects like hepatotoxicity, neurotoxicity (Sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, and ataxia), coma, convulsions, cardiovascular collapse, water retention and hyponatremia, Steven Jones syndrome, agranulocytosis, aplastic anaemia, thrombocytopenia, hypersensitivity reactions and teratogenicity.

Option D - Topiramate causes impairment of attention, sedation, ataxia, word-finding difficulties, poor memory, weight loss, paresthesias, and renal stones. It does not cause hepatotoxicity or hyperammonemia.

questions.text:
A male patient who is a known case of COPD presents to the emergency department with dyspnea. The arterial blood gas report is as follows:

pH: 7.28

pCO2: 60 mmHg

HCO3: 28 meq/L

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inadequately compensated respiratory acidosis

Explanation:

  • pH 7.28 is decreased, suggestive of acidosis, the pCO2 = 60mmHg which is elevated, hence the acidosis is likely respiratory.
  • The bicarbonate is 28 meq/L implying that compensation is partial (partial compensation/inadequate compensation)

This is a case of inadequately compensated respiratory acidosis because:

  • In acute respiratory acidosis, HCO3- will ↑ by 1 mEq/L for every 10 mmHg ↑ in pCO2
  • In chronic respiratory acidosis, HCO3- will ↑ by 4 mEq/L for every 10 mmHg ↑ in pCO2
    • In this patient, ABG shows:
  • pH: 7.28
  • PaCO2: 60 mmHg
  • HCO3-: 28 mEq/L
  • Normal PaCO2: 38-42 mm Hg

Thus, the difference in PaCO2 = 60 - 42 = 18 mm Hg

As this patient has COPD which is the most likely cause of respiratory acidosis in this patient, it is chronic respiratory acidosis

  • We know for every 10 mmHg ↑ in PCO2, HCO3- should ↑ by 4 mEq/L
    • For 1 mmHg ↑ in PCO2, HCO3- should ↑ by 4/10 mEq/L
    • Thus for 18 mm Hg ↑ in PCO2 , HCO3- should ↑ by 7.2 mEq/L
  • In this patient HCO3- should be approx 33 mEq/L, but it is only 28 mEq/L, hence it is only partially compensated respiratory acidosis

 

Incorrect Options:

Fully compensated respiratory acidosis (Option B): If this was the condition, the HCO3- should have been approximately 33.

Fully compensated respiratory alkalosis (Option C) is incorrect since the ABG in the given scenario is respiratory acidosis.

Inadequately compensated metabolic alkalosis (Option D) is incorrect since the ABG in the given scenario is respiratory acidosis.

questions.text: Following instrument is used to measure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Proptosis

Explanation:

The instrument used to measure proptosis is called an exophthalmometer, such as the Hertel or Luedde exophthalmometer. This tool helps assess the degree of ocular protrusion and is particularly useful in diagnosing conditions like proptosis caused by orbital tumors or other space-occupying lesions.

 

Proptosis

  • Proptosis refers to the abnormal protrusion of the eyeball, while exophthalmos specifically describes protrusion of the eyeball.
  • Causes:
    • Retrobulbar lesions (most common cause).
    • Shallow orbit (less common).
    • The optic nerve allows significant forward displacement of the globe (25mm length), causing proptosis without excessive nerve stretching.
  • Types of Proptosis:
    • Axial proptosis: Caused by space-occupying lesions within the muscle cone (e.g., cavernous hemangioma, optic nerve tumors).
    • Combined proptosis and dystopia: Due to extraconal lesions (e.g., lacrimal gland tumor) causing displacement in the coronal plane (dystopia).
    • Dystopia: Displacement of the globe in the coronal plane, either horizontal or vertical. Measured using the midline (nose) for horizontal or a vertical scale for vertical displacement.
  • Measuring Severity:
    • Use a plastic rule, Luedde™ exophthalmometer, or a binocular exophthalmometer (Hertel) for accurate measurements of ocular protrusion.
    • Readings >20 mm or a difference of 2–3 mm between eyes suggests proptosis.
    • Palpebral aperture dimensions and any lagophthalmos should be noted.
  • Pseudoproptosis: A false impression of proptosis due to:
    • Facial asymmetry.
    • Enlarged globe (e.g., high myopia, buphthalmos).
    • Lid retraction or contralateral enophthalmos.

Clinical evaluation of proptosis

  • Differentiate proptosis from pseudoproptosis
    • Pseudoproptosis (the false impression of proptosis) may be due to facial asymmetry, enlargement of the globe (high myopia, buphthalmos), lid retraction or contralateral enophthalmos.
  • Asymmetrical proptosis is readily detected by looking down at the patient from above and behind
  • Globe location: If it is misplaced superiorly, inferiorly, medially, laterally, or straight out (axially) by an exophthalmometer.
    • An exophthalmometer is used to quantify the distance from the orbital rim to the corneal surface of each eye in order to assess the symmetry of globe protrusion. Readings >20 mm are indicative of proptosis and a dierence of 2–3 mm or more between the two eyes is suspicious regardless of the absolute values. (Option B)
    • Hertel's exophthalmometer: In adults.
    • Luedde exophthalmometer: In children.
    • Naugle exophthalmometer: Non-axial proptosis

 

Squint (Option B), also known as strabismus, refers to a misalignment of the eyes, where the eyes do not point in the same direction. The condition is measured using ocular alignment tests (like the Hirschberg test or the Cover test), not an exophthalmometer.

Ptosis (Option C) refers to the drooping of the upper eyelid. The severity of ptosis is usually assessed by observing the degree of eyelid droop, often with the help of a marginal reflex distance (MRD) test or by measuring the distance from the upper eyelid to the corneal light reflex. This is not measured using an exophthalmometer.

Diplopia (Option D), or double vision, refers to the perception of two images of a single object. This condition is typically evaluated through visual field tests, ocular motility testing, and cover tests, not with an exophthalmometer.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension, developed features of heart failure and expired. The post-mortem cardiac biopsy slide is given below.



What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Restrictive cardiomyopathy

Explanation:

  • The image given here is of amyloid deposits (pink hyaline) in the myocardium causing myocardial stiffening and restriction leading to restrictive cardiomyopathy.

Restrictive Cardiomyopathy

  • Characterized by abnormal diastolic function, often with mildly reduced contractility and ejection fraction (usually 30–50%).

Causes

  • Infiltrative diseases:
    • Amyloidosis (Most common cause)
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Hemochromatosis
  • Fibrotic conditions:
    • Radiation therapy
    • Scleroderma
    • Endomyocardial fibrosis
  • Storage diseases:
    • Glycogen storage diseases (types II, III)
    • Fabry's disease

Pathophysiology

Abnormal Diastolic Function
  • The primary abnormality in restrictive cardiomyopathy is impaired diastolic filling due to the stiffened ventricular walls.
  • Elevated end-diastolic pressures in both ventricles without significant chamber dilation.

Bilateral Atrial Enlargement

The non-compliant ventricles lead to increased pressures, resulting in dilation of both atria.

Right-Sided Heart Failure

The stiff ventricles result in increased filling pressures, particularly affecting the right side, causing peripheral oedema, ascites, and jugular venous distention.

Amyloid Infiltration (in amyloidosis)

Amyloid fibrils (pink hyaline deposits) accumulate between myocytes, leading to myocardial stiffening and restrictive physiology.

Cardiac amyloidosis (Congo red stain)

Fibrosis

In conditions like radiation-induced cardiomyopathy or endomyocardial fibrosis, stiffening of the myocardium occurs due to scarring, further impairing ventricular filling.


Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option A) can be due to many causes broadly classified as infective, noninfective, toxic, and metabolic causes. The biopsy shows myocyte shape variation, inflammation, interstitial fibrosis, signs of cardiotoxicity (depending on the cause), etc. This is however not the given scenario.


Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Option C) is a genetic disorder and the histological examination shows enlarged cardiomyocytes with eosinophilic cytoplasm and box-shaped nuclei, normal myocardium in patches, interstitial fibrosis, microvascular ischemia, intercalated discs and desmosomes.


Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (Option D), or stress cardiomyopathy, is a transient condition characterized by left ventricular apical ballooning often triggered by emotional or physical stress, mimicking acute coronary syndrome without coronary obstruction. The given image does not represent Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations corresponds to the image given below?

choices.text: Cobalt blue- Tryptan blue - Corneal ulcer
Cobalt green- Rose bengal stain- Corneal ulcer
Cobalt blue- Fluorescein stain- Corneal ulcer
Cobalt blue- Lissamine green- Corneal ulcer

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cobalt blue- Fluorescein stain- Corneal ulcer

Explanation:

The combination of cobalt blue light and fluorescein stain is the gold standard for evaluating corneal ulcers, making Option C the correct answer. This setup allows for optimal visualization of corneal defects and provides clear diagnostic information.

 

Fluorescein sodium

  • Fluorescein penetrates poorly into the lipid layer of the corneal epithelium, and therefore, it does not stain normal cornea. Although fluorescein is a very effective stain for the diseased cornea, it is more difficult to detect fluorescein staining of the conjunctiva because of the poor scleral contrast. Fluorescein absorbs light in the blue spectrum (490 nm) and emits yellow-green light of a higher wavelength (530 nm), therefore staining can be more readily viewed if a cobalt blue or yellow (blue-free) filter is used. This combination is particularly useful for detecting corneal defects and ulcers.

 

Cobalt blue- Tryptan blue - Corneal ulcer (Option A):

  • Cobalt blue is a filter that is commonly used in conjunction with fluorescein stain, as it enhances the fluorescence of fluorescein, making it easier to detect corneal defects. It absorbs light in the blue spectrum (around 490 nm) and helps the fluorescein stain emit a bright yellow-green fluorescence when illuminated. Tryptan blue is not the preferred or standard stain for detecting corneal ulcers. While it can stain the corneal tissue, it does not provide the clear fluorescence that fluorescein does when combined with a cobalt blue filter. While cobalt blue is useful in conjunction with certain dyes, tryptan blue is not an ideal choice for assessing corneal ulcers.

 

Cobalt green- Rose bengal stain- Corneal ulcer (Option B):

Rose bengal

  • Rose bengal is a derivative of fluorescein and is used to detect ocular surface damage. It was initially theorized that rose bengal stains dead and devitalized tissue, but it is now thought to stain any part of the ocular surface which is not protected by an overlying tear film, specifically in areas lacking membrane-associated mucins.

 

Cobalt blue- Lissamine green- Corneal ulcer (Option D):

Lissamine green

  • It has a high affinity for staining dead and degenerated cells, including mucous strands. The dye appears to stain areas where there are disrupted intercellular junctions. Use of a green (red-free) filter shows the stained areas to appear black in color. As it is better tolerated than rose bengal, it is the preferred dye for staining the bulbar conjunctiva.

questions.text: Iritis is least associated with all of the following diseases:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

Explanation:

Iritis, also known as Anterior uveitis, is an inflammatory condition of the eye, including the iris and ciliary body.

Although SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs, iritis is less commonly seen in SLE compared to the other conditions listed. It more often causes other ocular manifestations, like dry eyes or retinal changes.

Systemic Associations and Masquerades of Iritis (Anterior Uveitis)

  • Infectious Causes:
    • Herpes Infections: Varicella Zoster, Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
    • Tuberculosis (TB)
    • Syphilis
    • Leprosy
  • Non-Infectious Causes:
    • With Systemic Association:
      • Sarcoidosis
      • Behçet's Disease (Option B ruled out)
      • HLA-B27 Associated Arthritis
      • Psoriatic Arthropathy (Option C ruled out)
      • Inflammatory Bowel Disease: Ulcerative Colitis (UC) > Crohn's Disease (Option D ruled out)
    • Without Systemic Association:
      • Drug-Induced: Pilocarpine, prostaglandin analogues
  • Masquerade Syndromes:
    • Definition: Conditions that mimic the symptoms of anterior uveitis but are not primarily inflammatory in nature.
    • Neoplastic Masquerades:
      • Lymphomas
      • Anterior Segment Melanoma
      • Retinoblastoma
      • Metastasis
    • Non-Neoplastic Masquerades:
      • Intraocular Foreign Body
      • Old Retinal Detachment
      • Pigment Dispersion Syndrome
      • Coats' Disease

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis based on the observed blanching of vascularity following the administration of 10 % phenylephrine, as depicted in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nodular episcleritis

Explanation:

The patient has painless redness of the eye which blanches (as shown in the image) following the application of 10% phenylephrine, suggesting episcleritis- Nodular episcleritis

Episcleritis

Definition

Episcleritis refers to inflammation of the loose connective tissue between the sclera and the conjunctiva

Etiology

Idiopathic

Systemic diseases - gout, rosacea, psoriasis, and connective tissue diseases.

Hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous tubercular or streptococcal toxins.

Infectious episcleritis - herpes zoster virus, syphilis, Lyme disease, and tuberculosis.

Clinical features
  • Common in young females
  • Acute onset redness
  • Discomfort - gritty/foreign body sensation
  • Mild to no pain
  • Resolves spontaneously
  • Recurrence is common

Clinical types
  1. Simple episcleritis: Sectorial (occasionally diffuse) inflammation of episclera. The engorged episcleral vessels are large and run in a radial direction beneath the conjunctiva
  2. Nodular episcleritis: Pink or purple flat nodule surrounded by injection, usually situated 2-3 mm away from the limbus. The nodule is firm, tender can be moved separately from the sclera and the overlying conjunctiva also moves freely.

Diagnosis

10% Topical phenylephrine blanches overlying conjunctival vessels and inflamed episcleral vessels.

Differential diagnosis
  • Conjunctivitis, which is more superficial; blanching occurs with 2.5% phenylephrine
  • Phlyctenulosis (Option C ruled out)
  • Inflamed pinguecula
  • Scleritis, which is deeper and more painful; does not blanch with 10% phenylephrine (Option B ruled out)

Treatment

  • Topical NSAIDs
  • Topical mild corticosteroid eye drops
  • Topical artificial tears,
  • Cold compresses applied to the closed lids may offer symptomatic relief from ocular discomfort.
  • Systemic NSAIDs

Scleral ectasia (Option D) refers to a thinning and bulging of the sclera, often associated with conditions like keratoconus. It is not an inflammatory condition, and it would not cause the blanching of vascularity seen with phenylephrine. The clinical presentation of scleral ectasia typically involves corneal changes rather than inflammation of the episclera.

questions.text:
In a baby born with meconium-stained liquor, which of the following are recommended as per Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines?

1. Intrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder

2. Intratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby

3. Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby

4. PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 3, 4

Explanation:

  • For a baby born with meconium-stained liquor, the management approach is based on whether the baby is vigorous or non-vigorous.

Statement 3 (Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby): If the baby is vigorous (good tone, good breathing), gentle suction of the nose and mouth is done. The baby can then be kept with the mother for bonding.

Statement 4 (PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps): If the baby is non-vigorous (poor tone, no or poor breathing), the initial steps of resuscitation are performed, and positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is administered if the baby does not respond to initial stimulation.

 

Statement 1 (Intrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder): This step is not recommended according to the guidelines. Routine suctioning before the delivery of the shoulder may not prevent meconium aspiration syndrome and is not part of the recommended procedure.

Statement 2 (Intratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby): Routine tracheal suctioning is also not recommended for a non-vigorous baby. Only when the baby shows signs of airway obstruction or if they do not improve after PPV should further suctioning or intervention be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following has the least risk of perinatal transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rubella

Explanation:

  • Rubella (German measles) has the least risk of perinatal transmission among the options provided. Although rubella can cause significant intrauterine transmission, especially in the first trimester of pregnancy, its overall risk of perinatal transmission is lower compared to other infections.

 

Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS)

 

Causative Agent

Rubella virus

Transmission

Vertical transmission from mother to fetus during pregnancy; highest risk during the first trimester

Risk Period

Highest fetal risk occurs when the mother contracts rubella in the first trimester

Classical Triad

1. Sensorineural deafness

2. Cataracts

3. Congenital heart disease (commonly patent ductus arteriosus)

Other Clinical Features
  • Salt and pepper retinopathy (speckled retinal appearance)

 

  • Blueberry muffin lesions (bluish-red nodular lesions)
  • Microcephaly
  • Micrognathia
  • Developmental delay
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Jaundice
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

Diagnosis

Clinical findings and laboratory tests (rubella-specific IgM antibodies, rubella virus RNA detection)

Management

No specific antiviral treatment; prevention through rubella vaccination (MMR) before pregnancy

Complications
  • Developmental delay and cognitive deficits
  • Neurological sequelae (e.g., seizures)
  • Ophthalmic (e.g., cataracts)
  • Cardiac defects (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus)

Prevention

MMR vaccination prior to pregnancy is crucial to avoid CRS

Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) (Option A) can be transmitted to the newborn in utero, intrapartum, or perinatally. It causes severe complications, such as skin vesicles, eye findings (chorioretinitis, keratoconjunctivitis), and neurological sequelae (microcephaly/hydranencephaly) if acquired early, or skin, eye, mouth disease, encephalitis, or disseminated disease if acquired intrapartum.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (Option B) is the most common congenital infection with perinatal transmission, and it is associated with a variety of complications including hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. Long-term sequelae include hearing loss.

Hepatitis B (Option D) has a significant risk of perinatal transmission, especially in cases with high viral load (HBeAg-positive mothers). Neonates infected with hepatitis B can develop chronic infection, which can lead to long-term liver complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with right upper quadrant discomfort and grade Il steatohepatitis of the liver. He has a history of regular intake of 2-3 alcoholic drinks daily and has a BMI of 29. What will be the most appropriate advice to the patient?

choices.text: Lifestyle modification + vitamin E + Ursodeoxycholic acid

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lifestyle modification + Regular exercise

Explanation:

  • The treatment of choice in this case of alcoholic hepatitis is lifestyle modification (stop alcohol intake) and regular exercise.


Management of Alcoholic Liver Disease (ALD):

Steatosis

Only lifestyle modifications:

  • Alcohol abstinence
  • Dietary changes
  • Exercise

Steato-Hepatitis

  • Oral Prednisolone 32 mg/day for 4 weeks
  • Check S.Bilirubin levels 1 week after starting steroids
  • Other drugs: N-acetyl cysteine, Pentoxifylline, anti-TNFα agents

Cirrhosis (Organ failure/ Portal hypertension)
  • Liver transplant

 

Incorrect Options:

Lifestyle modification + Vitamin E + Ursodeoxycholic acid (Option B) and Lifestyle modification + Pioglitazone (Option C) are treatment modalities for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis and not for alcohol hepatitis.

Lifestyle modification (Option D) like stopping alcohol intake is helpful but would be more efficient with exercise and dietary changes.

questions.text: A stroke patient presents with an inability to identify objects but can determine the colour, texture, and shape of objects. Which of the following lobes is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Temporal lobe

Explanation:

  • The inability to identify objects and the ability to determine the colour, texture, and shape of objects refer to visual agnosia, which is caused by lesions involving the temporal lobe.

Features of Left Temporal Lobe Stroke

Features of Right Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Impaired language and memory: Difficulty with spoken language and remembering verbal information.
  • Fluent (Wernicke’s) aphasia: Fluent speech with incorrect words, affecting language comprehension.
  • Poor visual memory and spatial awareness: Difficulty recognizing visual patterns and spatial information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Inability to recognize faces, including familiar ones.

General Features of Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Poor memory: Difficulty recalling memories and learning new information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Trouble recognizing faces and objects.
  • Fluent aphasia: Specifically in left-sided strokes, affecting speech fluency but with incorrect word use.
  • Visual perception difficulties: Challenges with interpreting the visual field and surroundings.
  • Trouble processing sound: Inability to differentiate or process sounds correctly.
  • Visual agnosia: Inability to recognize visually presented objects despite otherwise normal visual field, acuity, colour vision, brightness, discrimination, language, and memory.
  • Emotional and behavioural changes: Varying behaviours due to damage to the amygdala, such as aggression, passiveness, or difficulty interpreting facial cues.

Incorrect Options:

Lesions in a patient's Frontal lobe (Option A) can lead to certain symptoms such as trouble with learning, deficits in visual-motor function, executive dysfunction and problems with attention (planning, focusing, and inhibition).

Parietal lobe (Option B): Right - Damage to this area can cause visuospatial deficits (e.g., the patient may have difficulty finding their way around new, or even familiar, places).

Parietal Lobe, Left: Damage to this area may disrupt a person's ability to understand spoken and/or written language.

Unilateral Occipital lobe (Option D) lesion causes contralateral homonymous hemianopia. It is a visual field defect on the same side of both eyes contralateral to the site of the lesion - lesions of the occipital lobe due to the posterior cerebral artery infarct cause homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.

questions.text: Comment on the lung disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bronchiectasis

Explanation:

  • The scooped-out pattern on expiration is a classic finding in obstructive diseases like bronchiectasis, which often presents in smokers with chronic symptoms like the patient.

The types of flow-volume loops:

Flow volume curve loop types and examples:

Loop Type

Expiratory Curve

Inspiratory Curve

Example Conditions

Normal

Symmetrical, peaked

Symmetrical, rounded

Healthy lungs

Obstructive

Scooped (concave)

Normal

COPD, asthma, bronchiectasis

Restrictive

Narrow, peaked

Narrow, peaked

Pulmonary fibrosis, pleural effusion, ARDS

Fixed Upper Airway Obstruction

Flattened (box-like)

Flattened (box-like)

Tracheal stenosis, a large goiter

Variable Extrathoracic Obstruction

Normal

Flattened

Vocal cord dysfunction, laryngeal tumour

Variable Intrathoracic Obstruction

Flattened

Normal

Tracheomalacia, bronchogenic tumor


Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are restrictive lung diseases, and the flow volume shifts to the right in restrictive lung diseases. In restrictive lung diseases, the lungs have decreased compliance, which limits their ability to expand fully during inhalation. As a result, lung volumes (decreased vital capacity) are smaller during each respiratory cycle.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male with central chest pain, shortness of breath and palpitations came to the emergency department. An ECG was taken, which showed NSTEMI. Which of the following is the right treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aspirin + Clopidogrel + LMWH

Explanation:

  • NSTEMI is caused due to a platelet-rich thrombus and so, a dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin + Clopidogrel) is to be done (not thrombolysis) along with an anticoagulant like low molecular heparin (Enoxparin).

Management of NSTEMI-ACS

  • Management of NSTEMI involves evaluating patients with a low likelihood of ischemia in emergency settings, continuous ECG monitoring, stress testing, and serum troponin assessments, while those who meet criteria for NSTE-ACS are admitted for further monitoring and medical treatment aimed at stabilizing their condition and preventing future events.

Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: Aspirin
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: Clopidogrel

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: Enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: Bivalirudin.
  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: Fondaparinux.

Invasive management
  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve.
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularization includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are inadequate for the treatment of NSTEMI as it requires a dual platelet therapy with an anticoagulant.

questions.text: Which of the following is not responsible for teratogenicity due to thalidomide?

choices.text: Release of reactive oxygen species and free radicals

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Inhibition of IL2, IL4, IL5

  • The teratogenic effects of thalidomide are primarily linked to oxidative stress, suppression of angiogenesis, and cereblon binding.
  • Immunomodulatory effects, such as inhibition of IL2, IL4, and IL5, are unrelated to its teratogenicity.
  • Thalidomide is known for its ability to inhibit angiogenesis, which is the formation of new blood vessels.
  • It acts by inhibiting the production of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF), both of which play crucial roles in angiogenesis.
  • It is a hypnotic drug that was taken early in pregnancy for morning sickness, which lead to an epidemic phocomelia (seal limb), in which limbs are malformed.

The properties of thalidomide, like the release of reactive oxygen species and free radicals (Option A), Suppression of angiogenesis (Option B) and Cereblon binding (Option C) can lead to teratogenicity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the culture taken in a suspected case of infective endocarditis is correct?

choices.text: Two samples from peripheral lines 30 minutes apart
Three samples from peripheral lines 1 hour apart
One sample only from the peripheral line
Two peripheral samples, two days apart

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Three samples from peripheral lines 1 hour apart

Explanation:

  • The culture taken in a suspected case of infective endocarditis must be by three or more samples from the peripheral line taken over at least 1 hour apart.

Modified Duke’s Criteria - Major criteria
 

Positive blood cultures
  • Identification of a typical organism from two cultures, or persistent positive cultures drawn more than 12 hours apart.
  • Three or more positive cultures that have been taken over at least 1hour apart. (Option B)
  • A single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or a phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800.
 

Evidence of endocardial involvement
  • Positive echocardiographic findings such as vegetations, abscesses, or new valvular regurgitation.
  • Oscillating intracardiac masses or partial dehiscence of a prosthetic valve.
  • Additional diagnostic tools like FDG-PET/CT or EKG-gated cardiac CT angiograms also meet major criteria for prosthetic valve endocarditis. (Added by the European Society of Cardiology)

questions.text: Which of the following is a new drug approved by the FDA for the treatment of Rett syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trofinetide

Explanation:

  • Trofinetide is the newly FDA-approved drug for the treatment of Rett syndrome, a rare neurodevelopmental disorder primarily affecting females.
  • Trofinetide is a synthetic analog of the amino-terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1), designed to reduce neuroinflammation and support synaptic function.
  • It is believed to work by inhibiting inflammatory cytokine production, reducing overactivation of microglia and astrocytes, and enhancing IGF-1 signaling in the brain, which is crucial for normal development and response to injury.

 

Rett Syndrome

  • Neurological disorder mostly affecting girls.
  • Caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene.
  • Characterized by normal early development, followed by loss of motor skills, speech, and purposeful hand movements.

 

Development and Symptoms

  • Early Development: Normal for the first 6-18 months.
  • Loss of Skills: After early development, motor skills, speech, and purposeful hand movements are lost.
  • Repetitive Hand Movements: Common signs include hand-wringing, clapping, or tapping.
  • Motor Dysfunction: Loss of coordination, walking problems, and abnormal gait.
  • Cognitive Impairment: Intellectual disability and delayed language development.
  • Seizures: Commonly occur in many cases.

Diagnosis: Genetic Testing to detect mutations in the MECP2 gene.

Management:

Symptom Management

  • Antiepileptic drugs (e.g., valproic acid, lamotrigine) for seizures.
  • SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors)
  • Torfenetide: An investigational drug targeting MECP2 gene abnormalities to potentially enhance neurological function.
  • Motor Support
  • Speech Therapy
  • Behavioral Therapy

Olcegepant (Option A): A calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) antagonist that was considered for migraine treatment but was discontinued.

Lasmiditan (Option B): A 5HT1F receptor-selective agonist used for treating migraine.

Erenumab (Option D): A CGRP-blocking antibody used for treating migraines.

questions.text: Osimertinib is used in NSCLC with mutation due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) T790M mutation

  • Osimertinib is used in NSCLC (non-small cell lung cancer) with T790M mutation.
  • It is a third-generation epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) primarily used in NSCLC (non-small cell lung cancer).
  • It is specifically effective against NSCLC that harbours the T790M mutation in the EGFR gene.
  • The T790M mutation is commonly associated with resistance to first-generation EGFR TKIs like gefitinib and erlotinib.
  • Osimertinib works by selectively inhibiting mutant forms of EGFR, including those with the T790M mutation while sparing wild-type EGFR, which helps reduce toxicity.
  • Clinical trials have demonstrated the efficacy of osimertinib in patients with NSCLC who have developed resistance to previous EGFR TKIs due to the T790M mutation.

 

ROS1 mutation (Option A): Osimertinib is not indicated for NSCLC with ROS1 mutations. ROS1 rearrangements are a distinct molecular subtype of NSCLC and targeted therapies like crizotinib, ceritinib, and entrectinib are more commonly used in this case.

T890M mutation (Option B): There is no known mutation referred to as T890M. The correct mutation associated with osimertinib efficacy is T790M.

M790T mutation (Option D): Similarly, there is no known mutation termed M790T. The correct mutation is T790M.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought in with a history of chronic cough and foul-smelling stools. His sibling, who had similar complaints, died a few years back. Sweat chloride test and CFTR gene studies were done. CFTR gene codes for proteins involved in the transport of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cl-

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario described is highly suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF), a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) gene. This gene encodes a chloride channel that plays a crucial role in the transport of chloride ions (Cl-) across epithelial cell membranes, particularly in the sweat glands, respiratory airways, and pancreatic ducts.

 

Cystic fibrosis

 

Genetic Basis
  • Gene: CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator)
  • Location: Chromosome 7q31.2
  • Common Mutation: ΔF508
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive

Pathophysiology

 

  • CFTR Dysfunction: Defective chloride transport, increased sodium absorption, dehydrated mucus
  • Metabolic: (Hypokalemia) Due to excessive loss of potassium through sweat and impaired renal potassium handling
  • Respiratory: Airway obstruction, bacterial colonization, bronchiectasis, respiratory failure
  • Gastrointestinal: Pancreatic duct obstruction, malabsorption, Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome
  • Sweat Glands: Salty sweat
  • Reproductive:

Infertility in males: Congenital absence of the vas deferens in males leading to azoospermia and infertility.

Infertility in females: Defective CFTR in the cervix leads to the production of thick, dehydrated cervical mucus that blocks the cervical os, impairing sperm entry and reducing fertility.

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory: Chronic productive cough, recurrent infections, bronchiectasis
  • Gastrointestinal: Steatorrhea, malabsorption, meconium ileus, failure to thrive
  • Genitourinary: Infertility (males), delayed puberty
  • Other: Digital clubbing, salt-loss syndromes (Contraction alkalosis)

Diagnosis

Diagnostic Criteria

Requirement 1: Any ONE of the following

 

  • Clinical Features: Presence of typical features
  • Family History: A sibling with diagnosed cystic fibrosis
  • Newborn Screening: Positive result indicating risk for CF
  • IRT Screening: Elevated Immunoreactive Trypsinogen (IRT) for pancreatic insufficiency

Requirement 2: At least ONE of the following

Laboratory Evidence:

 

  • Sweat Chloride Test: Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations on separate days ≥60 mMol/L (Pilocarpine iontophoresis method)
  • CFTR Mutations: Identification of two CFTR mutations
  • Nasal Potential Difference: Abnormal measurement

Microbes
  • <18 years: Staphylococcus aureus
  • >18 years: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

  • Burkholderia cepacia: High mortality, low incidence

Management Strategies
  • Airway Clearance: Chest physiotherapy, percussion, postural drainage
  • Infection Control: Antibiotics, CFTR modulators
  • Nutritional Support:
  • High-calorie diet,
  • Pancreatic Enzyme Replacement Therapy
  • Vitamin supplementation (A, D, E, K)
  • Other: Insulin for CFRD, bone health management

Advanced Therapies
  • CFTR Modulators: Ivacaftor, lumacaftor, Trikafta
  • Trikafta: Elexacaftor-Tezacaftor-Ivacaftor (≥2 years old), improves lung function, reduces sweat chloride

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with bilateral symmetrical tenderness in the joints of her hands and wrists. She also complains of early morning stiffness of > 1 hour. On examination, no erythema or redness was found. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rheumatoid arthritis

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation suggests Rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which typically presents with symmetrical polyarthritis, primarily affects the small joints of the hands, particularly the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.

 

  • Symmetrical joint involvement is a hallmark of RA, distinguishing it from other forms of arthritis.

Joint involvement in different types of arthritis:

Characteristic

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)

Osteoarthritis (OA)

(Option A)

Psoriatic Arthritis

(Option B)

Gout

(Option C)

Reactive Arthritis

Joint Involvement Pattern

Symmetrical involvement of small joints (MCP, PIP)

Asymmetrical involvement, especially DIP joints

Asymmetrical involvement, often DIP joints

Typically involves a single joint (e.g., big toe)

Asymmetrical involvement, often larger joints

Morning Stiffness

Lasts over 1 hour

Resolves within 30 minutes

Varies, often significant

Rarely significant

Variable often follows infection

Key Symptoms

Swelling, tenderness, deformities (e.g., ulnar deviation)

Pain and stiffness with use

Dactylitis, nail changes

Sudden, severe pain and swelling

Joint pain following an infection

Affected Joints

MCP, PIP, wrists, knees

Knees, hips, hands (DIP, PIP)

MCP, PIP, and can include spine and tendons

Typically big toe (1st MTP joint)

Larger joints (e.g., knees, ankles)

Radiographic Findings

Soft tissue swelling, joint space narrowing

Osteophytes, joint space narrowing

Erosions, possible nail changes

Erosions and tophi possible

Similar to RA but typically larger joints

questions.text: A child presents with breathlessness. On chest x-ray, the following object is seen. Identify the object.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Button battery

Explanation:

  • Button batteries, particularly when ingested or aspirated by children, are a serious medical emergency.
  • On chest X-ray, a button battery typically appears as a circular object with a characteristic double ring sign (due to the metal casing and the central core).
  • If lodged in the airways or gastrointestinal tract, it can lead to severe complications such as mucosal damage, chemical burns, or even perforation.
  • This is a well-known radiological finding in pediatric cases.

Radiological Features of Foreign Body Ingestion

Foreign Body

AP View

Lateral View

Key Feature

Coin in Esophagus

Circular opacity

Slit-like appearance

Common in children, lodges at cricopharyngeal junction

Coin in Trachea

Slit-like appearance

Circular opacity

High risk of airway obstruction

Button Battery in Esophagus

Circular opacity with halo sign

Double contour ring

Can cause tissue necrosis, urgent removal needed

 

Coin (Option B): While a coin may appear on chest X-ray and be ingested or aspirated, it lacks the characteristic double ring appearance of a button battery. Coin ingestion can also cause blockage or discomfort but is less dangerous in comparison to button batteries.

Ball (Option C): Balls, especially small ones, can be ingested or aspirated, but they typically don't present with the distinct radiological appearance that button batteries do. Balls might also be seen on X-ray but lack the same level of concern for chemical or electrical burns.

Bottle cap (Option D): Bottle caps can be ingested or aspirated as well, but they do not present with the specific double ring sign of a button battery. While they can cause obstruction, they are generally less hazardous than button batteries.

questions.text: The perinatal transmission of infection shows the spectrum of anaemia, possibly myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the causative agent.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Parvovirus B19

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation described, including anemia, myocarditis, high output cardiac failure, and ascites, in the setting of hydrops fetalis, points to Parvovirus B19 infection.
  • Parvovirus B19 is the causative agent of erythema infectiosum (also known as Fifth disease), and its perinatal transmission can cause serious complications.

 

Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)

Causative Agent

Parvovirus B19

Age Group

Predominantly 5 to 15 years (70% of cases)

Incubation Period

4–28 days

Transmission

Respiratory droplets; transmission rate 15–30% among close contacts

Clinical Features

Prodromal Phase: Low-grade fever, headache, mild URTI symptoms

Rash: "Slapped-cheek" erythema on face, spreading as a lacy pattern to trunk and extremities

Management

Self-limiting disease

Complications
