Aplastic Crisis: Severe anemia due to erythropoiesis suppression in chronic hemolytic anemia

arthropathy: Arthritis/arthralgia, more common in adults

Fetal Infection: Nonimmune fetal hydrops, stillbirth risk

Other Manifestations: Papular purpural gloves and socks syndrome, myocarditis

 

Childhood Exanthems: The "First to Sixth" Diseases

 

Order

Disease

Pathogen

Clinical Features

First Disease

Measles

Measles virus (Paramyxoviridae)

High fever, Koplik spots, maculopapular rash spreading cephalocaudally (head to trunk and limbs).

Second Disease

Scarlet Fever

Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A)

Sandpaper-like rash, strawberry tongue, pharyngitis.

Third Disease

Rubella

Rubella virus (Togaviridae)

Mild fever, maculopapular rash starting on face, posterior auricular lymphadenopathy.

Fourth Disease

Duke’s Disease

Staphylococcus aureus or unknown

Rare; characterized by mild rash and fever.

Fifth Disease

Erythema Infectiosum

Parvovirus B19

"Slapped cheek" rash, lacy erythematous rash on trunk and limbs, mild fever.

Sixth Disease

Roseola Infantum/ Exanthem subitum

Human Herpesvirus 6/7 (HHV-6/HHV-7)

High fever followed by maculopapular rash after the fever subsides.

 

Treponema pallidum (Option A): This is the causative agent of syphilis, which can cause congenital syphilis, It presents with early signs like mucocutaneous lesions, snuffles, hepatosplenomegaly, and skeletal abnormalities, or late manifestations like Hutchinson's triad (notched teeth, deafness, interstitial keratitis).

CMV (Option B): Cytomegalovirus can cause a variety of congenital infections, but it is more commonly associated with SNHL, microcephaly, and chorioretinitis.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option D): This parasite can cause congenital toxoplasmosis with symptoms like hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcifications.

questions.text: What is the treatment for HER-2-positive trastuzumab-resistant breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lapatinib

  • Lapatinib is given in cases of trastuzumab-resistant HER-2 positive breast cancer.
  • It is an oral tyrosine kinase inhibitor that targets both HER-2 and EGFR (epidermal growth factor receptor).
  • It is approved for the treatment of HER-2 positive breast cancer, either as monotherapy or in combination with trastuzumab.

Mutation Target

Drug

Generation/Type

Explanation

HER1 (EGFR) - Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer

Erlotinib, Gefitinib

(Option D)

Given in EGFR (+)ve lung cancer, pancreatic cancer.

 

Afatinib, Dacomitinib

Osimertinib

Given in resistant cases of Afatinib & Dacomitinib.

Given in T790M mutation in EGFR receptor.

 

Mobocertinib

MAB Approved

Blocks EGFR.

HER2+ve - Breast Cancer

Lapatinib

 

Given in Trastuzumab-resistant cases.

 

Neratinib, Tucatinib

 

Used in HER2 (+)ve breast cancer.

Sorafenib (Option B) is a multi-kinase inhibitor primarily used for the treatment of advanced kidney cancer and liver cancer. While it has shown activity against various kinases involved in tumor growth and angiogenesis, it is not a standard treatment for trastuzumab-resistant breast cancer.

Vemurafenib (Option C) is a targeted therapy used for the treatment of metastatic melanoma with a specific mutation (BRAF V600E). It is not indicated or effective in the treatment of HER-2 positive breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of metabolic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) LDL

Explanation:

  • HDL is the component of metabolic syndrome and not LDL.

NCEP: ATPIII 2001 and Harmonizing Definition Criteria for the Metabolic Syndrome

NCEP: ATP III 2001

Harmonizing Definition

Three or more of the following:

  • Central obesity (Option C): Waist circumference > 102 cm (males), > 88 cm (females)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: Triglyceride level ≥150 mg/dl or specific medication
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dl for men and <50 mg/dl for women or specific medication
  • Hypertension (Option D): BP systolic ≥130 mmHg & diastolic ≥85 mmHg or specific medication
  • Fasting plasma glucose level (Option B) ≥100 mg/dl or specific medication or previously diagnosed type II diabetes

Three of the following:

Waist circumference (cm)

Women

Waist circumference (cm)

  • ≥94 (South Asian)
  • ≥ 80 (South Asian)

  • Blood pressure >130 mm systolic or >85 mm diastolic or previous diagnosis or specific medication

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of a parathyroid adenoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tc99-Sestamibi scan

Explanation:

  • A Tc99-Sestamibi scan is the investigation of choice for diagnosing a parathyroid adenoma.

  • This nuclear medicine scan uses a radiolabeled compound, Tc99m-sestamibi, which is preferentially absorbed by overactive parathyroid tissue, helping in localizing the adenoma.

  • It is highly sensitive and effective in detecting parathyroid adenomas, especially when combined with other imaging techniques such as ultrasound or CT.

Diagnosis of Parathyroid Adenoma

A parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland that can cause primary hyperparathyroidism due to excess production of parathyroid hormone (PTH). The most common symptoms are related to hypercalcemia, such as kidney stones, osteoporosis, and fatigue. Imaging is crucial to identify the adenoma, which guides the surgical treatment.

Imaging in Parathyroid Adenoma

Investigation

Findings

Role in Diagnosis

Tc99-Sestamibi Scan

Increased uptake in adenoma with delayed washout

Gold standard for localization

Sestamibi SPECT

(Option B ruled out)

3D imaging improves localization

Used when localization is unclear

Ultrasound (USG)

(Option C ruled out)

Hypoechoic, well-defined lesion near thyroid

First-line for initial screening, but less sensitive than Sestamibi

CT (4D-CT preferred) (Option D ruled out)

Enhances vascular lesion detection

Used when other modalities fail

questions.text: Which of the following is true about therapeutic index of a drug?

choices.text: Denotes safety and efficacy in population
Denotes safety and efficacy in individual
Ratio of median lethal dose in 50% of population to median effective dose in 50% of population
Denotes safety and efficacy after experiments in humans

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Denotes safety and efficacy in population

  • The therapeutic index of a drug denotes safety and efficacy in a population.
    • The Therapeutic Index (TI) is a measure used to assess a drug's safety. It represents the relationship between the dose of a drug that produces therapeutic effects (efficacy) and the dose that produces adverse effects (toxicity), i.e., it indicates the range between the therapeutic dose and the toxic dose of a drug.

TI= median toxic dose/median effective dose ; (TD50/ED50)

 

  • The therapeutic window is the range of drug concentrations that can safely and effectively treat the disease.
  • If the TI window for a drug is narrow, it requires frequent monitoring.
  • E.g., Warfarin, Theophylline, Digoxin, Lithium (Warning These Drugs are Lethal)

Denotes safety and efficacy in individual (Option B): It denotes safety and efficacy in population not individual.

Ratio of median lethal dose in 50% of population to median effective dose in 50% of population (Option C): It is the relationship between the dose of a drug that produces therapeutic effects (efficacy) and the dose that produces adverse effects (toxicity), i.e., between effective and toxic dose, not the lethal dose.

Denotes safety and efficacy after experiments in humans (Option D): Therapeutic index has nothing to do with the experiments.

questions.text: Which of the following is a new drug approved for Rett syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Trofinetide

  • Among the options provided, the drug approved for Rett syndrome is Trofinetide.
  • Trofinetide is a synthetic peptide used to treat Rett syndrome.
  • It is a synthetic analog of glycine-proline-glutamate, a naturally occurring peptide. The exact mechanism by which trofinetide exerts therapeutic effects is unknown; trofinetide may exhibit anti-inflammatory and trophic effects.
  • It has shown promising results in clinical trials, with improvements observed in certain aspects of Rett syndrome symptoms.

Folinic acid (Option B), also known as leucovorin, serves multiple roles in medicine. It is utilized alongside 5-FU in treating different cancers.

  • Additionally, it acts as an antidote to folic acid antagonists like methotrexate.
  • It serves as both an antidote and a modulating agent for chemotherapy, providing support for this class of medications.
  • It is not specifically approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome.

L-carnitine (Option C) is a naturally occurring substance that plays a role in energy metabolism. It is commonly used as a dietary supplement and may benefit certain medical conditions, particularly those related to mitochondrial dysfunction. However, L-carnitine is not specifically approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome.

Naltrexone (Option D) is a medication primarily used to treat opioid addiction and alcohol dependence. It works by blocking the effects of opioids in the brain. It is not helpful for the treatment of Rett syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presents with dull, aching pain and tortuous veins in both lower limbs. Which test would be appropriate for evaluating superficial femoral vein (SFJ) competence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Brodie Trendelenburg test

Explanation:

The Brodie-Trendelenburg test/ Trendelenburg I test is done to determine the patency of the saphenofemoral junction.

  • Procedure:
    • The patient is asked to lie in the supine position.
    • The leg is elevated, the vein is emptied by “milking,” and a tourniquet is tied just below the saphenofemoral junction.
    • The patient is asked to stand up quickly.
    • The tourniquet is released.

  • Observation:
    • When there is rapid filling of blood from above, this signifies saphenofemoral incompetence.

 

Other tests for varicose veins:

  • Modified Perthe’s test (Option C):
    • For DVT
    • After elevating the limb and emptying the veins, a tourniquet is applied at the SFJ and the patient is asked to walk around for a few minutes.
    • If the dilated veins become more prominent, it signifies deep venous obstruction.
  • Three tourniquet test: for specific perforator
  • Fegan’s test for perforator (Option A):
    • On standing, the line of varicosity is marked, and then the veins are emptied in the supine position.
    • The examiner palpates along the marked line and notices any pits or gaps in the deep fascia that signify perforator incompetence at that site.
  • Pratt’s test for perforator: Applying pressure to the calf muscle; if it feels tense and causes pain, it may indicate acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
  • Morrisey’s cough impulse test for SFJ incompetence:
    • The patient is asked to turn their face away from the examiner and cough while the examiner keeps a finger at the SFJ, and an expansile cough impulse is felt.
    • Signifies SFJ incompetence.
  • Ian-Aird test for SFJ incompetence.

 

Homan’s test (Option B) is a test for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) rather than venous insufficiency. It involves dorsiflexing the foot and assessing for pain in the calf, which may suggest a clot.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions is live vaccination not contraindicated?


	DiGeorge syndrome
	Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome
	Ataxia telangiectasia
	Complement deficiency
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 4 only

Explanation:

  • Live vaccines are typically contraindicated in conditions associated with impaired T-cell immunity, as individuals with such deficiencies are at risk for severe infections due to their inability to mount an adequate immune response to live pathogens. This includes DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia telangiectasia.
  • In contrast, patients with complement deficiencies have normal T-cell and B-cell functions. They may have an increased susceptibility to certain bacterial infections, particularly those caused by Neisseria species, due to defective complement-mediated immunity. However, their adaptive immune system, which is responsible for responding to vaccines, remains intact. Therefore, live vaccinations are generally not contraindicated in complement deficiency.

DiGeorge syndrome (1) involves a defect in the development of the thymus, leading to T-cell deficiency and impaired cell-mediated immunity. As a result, live vaccines should be avoided due to the increased risk of severe infections.

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (2) is caused by mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP), leading to T-cell dysfunction. Live vaccines are contraindicated in these patients because of their compromised immune system.

Ataxia telangiectasia (3) results from mutations in the ATM gene, impairing DNA repair mechanisms and leading to T-cell deficiency. Live vaccines are avoided due to the risk of severe infection.

questions.text:
Nada's Minor Criteria include


	Systolic murmur Grade 3
	Diastolic murmur
	Abnormal second heart sound
	Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 3 and 4

Explanation:

  • Nada's criteria is a diagnostic tool used to identify congenital heart disease (CHD) in children.
  • Nada's Criteria for Congenital Heart Disease
  • Presence of one major criterion or two minor criteria suggests the likelihood of CHD.

 

Major Criteria

Minor Criteria

Systolic murmur of Grade 3 or more

Systolic murmur less than Grade 3

Any diastolic murmur

Abnormal second heart sound (S2)

Cyanosis

Abnormal ECG

Congestive cardiac failure

Abnormal chest X-ray findings

Abnormal blood pressure (BP)

questions.text:
An 18-month-old child with a 3-day history of watery diarrhea and vomiting presented with altered sensorium. Which of the following are differential diagnoses?


	Severe dehydration
	Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)
	Cerebral Venous Thrombosis
	Hyponatremia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, 4

Explanation:

  • In a child presenting with diarrhea, vomiting, and altered sensorium, the differential diagnosis should focus on conditions associated with metabolic derangements, dehydration, and potential neurological complications.

 

Severe Dehydration (1):

  • Prolonged diarrhea and vomiting can lead to hypovolemia and electrolyte imbalances, resulting in altered sensorium.
  • This is one of the most common causes of altered mental status in children with diarrheal illness.

 

Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT) (3):

  • Severe dehydration increases the risk of thrombosis due to hemoconcentration.
  • CVT can present with seizures, altered sensorium, and focal neurological signs.

 

Hyponatremia (4):

  • Excessive water intake or inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (ADH) release in response to dehydration can cause dilutional hyponatremia.
  • Symptoms include seizures, lethargy, and altered sensorium.

 

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) (2):

  • This condition is typically associated with bloody diarrhea, which is absent in the clinical presentation.
  • HUS is caused by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli and usually occurs several days after an initial diarrheal illness.

questions.text:
Which condition is most likely based on the image findings?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Choledocholithiasis

Explanation:

The MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) image reveals dilation of the common bile duct (CBD) along with filling defects, representing gallstones within the duct.

  • Filling defects on MRCP indicate an obstruction in the bile ducts, commonly caused by gallstones (choledocholithiasis) or other blockages. These defects appear as areas where the bile duct does not fill properly or has reduced signal intensity.
  • Symptoms of choledocholithiasis typically include jaundice, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Treatment often involves endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with sphincterotomy and stone extraction.

 

Incorrect Options:

Stricture (Option A): A bile duct stricture appears as narrowing or constriction of the bile duct caused by inflammation, scarring, or tumours obstructing the duct. While it can mimic choledocholithiasis on imaging, it does not show the characteristic filling defects seen in choledocholithiasis.

Cholecystitis (Option C) is the inflammation of the gallbladder, usually due to gallstones blocking the cystic duct. MRCP typically shows gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and gallstones in the gallbladder but not changes in the bile ducts, so it wouldn't cause CBD dilation or filling defects.

Cholangiocarcinoma (Option D) is a malignant tumour of the bile duct epithelium. On MRCP, it can cause bile duct dilation and strictures and may also show intraductal masses or nodules. However, the pattern of obstruction caused by a tumour differs from the filling defects seen with choledocholithiasis, as these defects are caused by gallstones, not a mass.

questions.text: The causative agent of this condition is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pure red cell aplasia

Explanation:

  • The condition described is erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, caused by Parvovirus B19. This virus is strongly associated with pure red cell aplasia, especially in certain high-risk groups.

 

Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)

 

Causative Agent

Parvovirus B19

Age Group

Predominantly 5 to 15 years (70% of cases)

Incubation Period

4–28 days

Transmission

Respiratory droplets; transmission rate 15–30% among close contacts

Clinical Features

Prodromal Phase: Low-grade fever, headache, mild URTI symptoms

Rash: "Slapped-cheek" erythema on face, spreading as a lacy pattern to trunk and extremities

Management

Self-limiting disease

Complications

Aplastic Crisis: Severe anemia due to erythropoiesis suppression in chronic hemolytic anemia

Arthropathy: Arthritis/arthralgia, more common in adults

Fetal Infection: Nonimmune fetal hydrops, stillbirth risk

Other Manifestations: Papular purpural gloves and socks syndrome, myocarditis

 

Childhood Exanthems: The "First to Sixth" Diseases

Order

Disease

Pathogen

Clinical Features

First Disease

Measles

Measles virus (Paramyxoviridae)

High fever, Koplik spots, maculopapular rash spreading cephalocaudally (head to trunk and limbs).

Second Disease

Scarlet Fever

Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A)

Sandpaper-like rash, strawberry tongue, pharyngitis.

Third Disease

Rubella

Rubella virus (Togaviridae)

Mild fever, maculopapular rash starting on face, posterior auricular lymphadenopathy.

Fourth Disease

Duke’s Disease

Staphylococcus aureus or unknown

Rare; characterized by mild rash and fever.

Fifth Disease

Erythema Infectiosum

Parvovirus B19

"Slapped cheek" rash, lacy erythematous rash on trunk and limbs, mild fever.

Sixth Disease

Roseola Infantum/ Exanthem subitum

Human Herpesvirus 6/7 (HHV-6/HHV-7)

High fever followed by maculopapular rash after fever subsides.

 

Gingivostomatitis (Option A): Commonly caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1), not Parvovirus B19.

Molluscum contagiosum (Option C): Caused by a poxvirus, presenting with dome-shaped, umbilicated papules.

Kaposi sarcoma (Option D): Associated with Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), typically seen in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about lithium?

choices.text: It can cause fine tremors in the therapeutic range
It is not absorbed in the stomach

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It can cause fine tremors in the therapeutic range

Explanation:

Lithium can cause fine tremors in therapeutic doses.

Adverse effects of Lithium:

  • Alopecia and acne
  • Weight gain
  • Seizures and sinus node dysfunction (leading to AV block)
  • Hypothyroidism (hyperthyroidism in rare cases)
  • High doses can cause coarse tremors, ataxia, tinnitus, diarrhea, and seizures.
  • Ebstein’s anomaly: A cardiovascular defect called tricuspid atresia, which has a teratogenic effect when administered to pregnant women.
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI)
  • Fine tremors (most common adverse effect)
  • ECG changes: T-wave flattening
  • Leukocytosis
  • Loose stools (diarrhea)

It is not absorbed in the stomach (Option B): This statement is incorrect. Lithium is readily absorbed in the gastrointestinal tract after oral administration.

Approved for absence seizure (Option C): This statement is incorrect. Lithium is not commonly used for the treatment of absent seizures (also known as absence seizures). It is primarily indicated for bipolar disorder and certain other psychiatric conditions. Drugs used for absence seizures include valproate, lamotrigine, and ethosuximide (especially in < 2 years of age).

Lithium is not teratogenic (Option D): Lithium, commonly used to treat bipolar disorder, is teratogenic and poses a risk to the developing fetus during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester, where it is associated with an increased risk of cardiac malformations such as Ebstein's anomaly.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a history of fever, conjunctival congestion, and erythematous desquamation of the skin. A 2D echocardiogram shows coronary aneurysms. What is the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IVIG

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation—fever, conjunctival congestion, strawberry tongue, and erythematous desquamation—along with coronary aneurysms on echocardiography, is highly suggestive of Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome). The first-line treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) combined with aspirin, aimed at reducing inflammation and preventing coronary artery complications.

Kawasaki Disease (KD)

 

Etiology and Pathophysiology
  • Higher incidence in children of Asian descent.
  • Vasculitis affecting medium-sized arteries, especially coronary arteries.

Pathology

Acute Phase (Days 1-10):

  • Neutrophilic inflammation of blood vessels.
  • Infiltration of inflammatory cells, vessel wall swelling and damage.

 

Subacute Phase (Weeks 2-4): Risk of fusiform aneurysm formation as inflammation subsides.

 

Convalescent Phase (Weeks >4 weeks): Resolution of inflammation; potential scarring and thickening of arterial walls leading to stenosis.

Clinical Features

 
  • Fever: For at least 5 days.
  • Extremities: Swelling, redness, peeling skin around nails, fingers, and toes.
  • Mucocutaneous: Bilateral conjunctivitis, red and cracked lips, "strawberry tongue," and pharyngeal congestion.
  • Polymorphous Rash: Various forms (macular, papular, target-like lesions).
  • Cervical Lymphadenopathy: Unilateral, painful swelling of neck lymph nodes.

Diagnosis

Clinical Criteria:

 

Fever lasting at least 5 days.

 

At least 4 of the following:

 

5-“CREAM” features

 

  • C - Conjunctivitis, B/L non-purulent
  • R - Rash involving trunk
  • E- Erythema & Edema of palms & soles along with desquamation
  • A - Adenopathy (usually unilateral, cervical)
  • M- Mucositis (Strawberry Tongue)

 

Laboratory Findings:

  • Elevated CRP and ESR.
  • Elevated WBC count.
  • Echocardiography coronary artery aneurysms.

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction.
  • Coronary Artery Aneurysms.
  • Coronary Artery Stenosis:

Differential Diagnosis

Bacterial Infections (e.g., Scarlet Fever, Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome): Fever, rash, mucosal involvement with additional features like sore throat or blistering.

Treatment
  • Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG): Reduces inflammation and lowers risk of aneurysms.
  • Aspirin: High doses initially to reduce inflammation and fever; then low-dose regimen for anti-platelet effects.

 

IVIG-Resistant KD:

  • Second dose of IVIG, corticosteroids, or other immunosuppressive medications (e.g., infliximab, cyclosporine).

 

Aspirin (Option A): Important in treatment but is not the first-line therapy alone. It complements IVIG to control inflammation and reduce thrombotic risks.

Clopidogrel (Option C): Antiplatelet agent used for specific coronary conditions but not a primary treatment for Kawasaki disease.

LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin) (Option D): Used in cases with significant thrombotic complications but not first-line therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Down's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Caudal regression

Explanation:

  • Among the provided options, caudal regression is not associated with Down syndrome. Caudal regression is a condition characterized by the abnormal development of the lower spine and limbs, and it is more frequently seen in infants of diabetic mothers rather than those with Down syndrome.

Down's Syndrome (Trisomy 21)

 

Cause
  • Trisomy 21 due to meiotic nondisjunction.
  • Less commonly caused by Robertsonian translocation (4%) or mosaicism (1%).

Incidence

1:800 to 1:1000 live births.

General Features

Craniofacial:

  • Intellectual disability, flat facial profile, upward-slanting eyes, epicanthic folds.
  • Small nose, flat nasal bridge, narrow palate, small teeth, protruding tongue.
  • Brachycephaly, flat occiput, dysplastic ears.

 

Extremities:

  • Short, broad hands, clinodactyly (5th finger), simian crease, sandal gap (wide space between toes).

Comorbidities

Cardiac: 40-60% have congenital heart defects (mainly AVSD, VSD, PDA, ASD).

Gastrointestinal: Duodenal atresia, Hirschsprung disease, annular pancreas.

Hematological: Increased risk of leukemia (acute lymphoblastic leukemia, acute myeloid leukemia).

Endocrine: Thyroid dysfunction (hypothyroidism), type 1 diabetes risk.

Neurological: Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease (APP gene on chromosome 21).

Musculoskeletal: Atlanto-occipital subluxation, short stature, hypotonia, growth delays, obesity risk.

Sensory: Hearing loss (conductive, often due to serous otitis media), ophthalmic problems (cataracts, strabismus, nystagmus).

Diagnosis

Prenatal:

  • Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS): Performed between 10-13 weeks.
  • Amniocentesis: Performed after 15 weeks.

Postnatal:

  • Characteristic features (e.g., craniofacial dysmorphisms).
  • Confirmatory Test: Karyotype analysis for trisomy 21.

Antenatal Screening

First Trimester: Increased nuchal translucency (>3 mm), elevated β-HCG, low PAPP-A.

Second Trimester: Triple Test (β-HCG, estriol, AFP), Quadruple Test (adds Inhibin-A).

Integrated Test: Combines maternal age, NT, PAPP-A, and Quadruple Test.

Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPS/NIPT): Cell-free fetal DNA testing (high sensitivity and specificity).

questions.text: What is the position of the appendix marked in red colour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retrocecal

Explanation:

  • The retrocecal position is one of the most common variations in the anatomical location of the appendix. In this position, the appendix is located behind the cecum, usually near the ileocecal valve.

Locations of the appendix and their presentations:

Location

Presentation

Retrocecal

May present with flank or back pain

Subcecal

Can mimic gynaecological disorders or urinary tract infection

Pre-ileal

May cause small bowel obstruction symptoms

Post-ileal

May cause small bowel obstruction symptoms

Paracecal

Can present with typical right lower quadrant pain

Subhepatic

Can be mistaken for cholecystitis

Pelvic

Can mimic symptoms of pelvic inflammatory disease or ovarian pathology

questions.text: A longitudinal, observational, and analytical study is also known as?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Cohort Study

Explanation:

The combination of a longitudinal, observational, and analytical study is known as a Cohort Study.

  • Design: Prospective study following a group of individuals with a common characteristic or exposure over time.
  • Longitudinal study is a type of study where outcomes are determined at fixed time intervals, can be retrospective (case control) or prospective (cohort srudy)
  • A cohort study is an observational analytical study that provides evidence supporting the existence of an association between exposure and outcome.

 

Classification of study designs:

Observation Studies

Experimental/intervential Studies

Descriptive

Analytical

Case reports

Ecological studies

Randomised controlled trials

Case series

Case-control studies

Field trials

Cohort studies

Community trials

Cross-sectional studies

Cross-Sectional Study (Option A):

  • Design: Observational studies that analyze data from a population at a single point in time.
  • Observational: Yes, it is observational, but it is not longitudinal.

Ecological Study (Option C):

  • Design: Examines the correlation between variables at the group level rather than the individual level.
  • Observational: Yes, it is observational, but it is not longitudinal.

Randomized Control Trial (RCT) (Option D):

  • Design: Experimental study where participants are randomly assigned to different groups (treatment and control).
  • Longitudinal: Yes, it is longitudinal as it involves follow-up over time.
  • Observational: No, it is an experimental design involving interventions.
  • Analytical: Yes, it is analytical, but it involves experimental manipulation.

questions.text: What is the most useful drug to treat Doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dexrazoxane

Explanation:

  • Dexrazoxane is used for the treatment of Doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.
  • It is a cardioprotective, iron-chelating agent.
  • It is used to prevent cardiotoxicity caused by the anthracyclines doxorubicin and daunorubicin.
  • It may also prevent anthracycline-derived DNA damage by interacting with topoisomerase II in cardiac cells.

Aprepitant (Option A) is a neurokinin 1 blocker used for late CINV (Chemotherapy-induced Nausea and Vomiting).

Deferoxamine (Option B) is incorrect as it is an iron chelator.

Amifostine (Option C) is incorrect as it is used to prevent cisplatin nephrotoxicity.

questions.text:
Match the following columns on Epidemiology Guidelines:


	
		
			
			A. Care
			
			
			1. RCT
			
		
		
			
			B. Consort
			
			
			2. Case report
			
		
		
			
			C. Prisma
			
			
			3. Observational study
			
		
		
			
			D. Strobe/Moose
			
			
			4. Systematic Review
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) A2-B1-C4-D3

Explanation:

Care:

  • Stands for Case Report.
  • It is a guideline that provides a framework for reporting case reports in medical and health-related fields.
  • Case reports describe and analyze individual cases or small groups of cases, providing valuable insights into rare diseases, unusual presentations of common diseases, and unexpected treatment outcomes.

Consort:

  • Stands for Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials.
  • It is a guideline designed to improve the transparency and reporting of randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
  • It provides a checklist and flow diagram to ensure that essential information about the design, conduct, analysis, and interpretation of RCTs is reported in a standardised and comprehensive manner.

Prisma:

  • Stands for Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses. It is a guideline that aims to improve the transparency and reporting of systematic reviews and meta-analyses.
  • PRISMA provides a checklist and flow diagram to ensure that researchers accurately report their systematic reviews and meta-analyses' methods, results, and interpretations.

Strobe/Moose:

  • STROBE stands for Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology, while MOOSE stands for Meta-analysis of Observational Studies in Epidemiology.
  • These guidelines provide recommendations for reporting observational studies, including cohort, case-control, and cross-sectional studies.
  • STROBE and MOOSE guidelines help researchers ensure that they report relevant information about the design, conduct, analysis, and interpretation of observational studies, thus enhancing the transparency and reproducibility of their findings.

questions.text: A surgeon examines a case of hernia and is able to retract the hernial sac but not its contents. Based on this examination, which type of hernia is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reduction en masse

Explanation:

  • Reduction en masse refers to the unintentional displacement or reduction of both the hernia sac and its contents into a deeper anatomical space, such as the preperitoneal or retroperitoneal space, which can occur during the attempted reduction of the hernia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Incarcerated hernia (Option A): In an incarcerated hernia, the lumen of the part of the colon within the hernial sac becomes obstructed by faeces. The fecal content, or scybalous material, can typically be indented with a finger, similar to putty. In this condition, the sac and its contents are firmly adhered to each other, meaning the contents are fixed within the sac. The hernia is always irreducible and often obstructed, though it may not necessarily be strangulated.

Sliding hernia (Hernia-En-Glissade) (Option C):

  • It occurs when a portion of the peritoneum that normally lines the abdominal cavity slides through the hernia defect, bringing a partially retroperitoneal organ.
  • It is more common in males, particularly the elderly and frequently occurs on the left side, where the sigmoid colon is the most common content, not the appendix.
  • The posterior wall of the hernia sac is formed by the viscera (commonly bowel), not the anterior wall.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Patients typically present with a reducible swelling in the groin or lower abdomen that worsens on standing due to gravity.
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation and incomplete bowel emptying are common, indicating bowel involvement.
  • Managed surgically by repairing or closing the defect, but associated with a higher risk of bowel injury due to the involvement of the viscera in the hernia sac.

Maydl’s Hernia:

  • It involves two or more bowel loops that become incarcerated or strangulated within the hernia sac.
  • The obstructed loop is present intraperitoneally and easily missed during surgery.

questions.text:
In biostatistics, formula given below stands for?

(σ) =√ [ Σ(x - μ²/Ν]
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Standard Deviation

Explanation:

  • The standard deviation is a measure of the dispersion or variability of a set of values.
  • It quantifies how much the values deviate from the mean. The formula for calculating the standard deviation involves taking the square root of the average of the squared differences between each value and the mean.
  • Standard deviation is considered the most comprehensive and widely used measure of dispersion in statistical analysis.

Measures of dispersion

Definition

Calculation

Standard deviation (Option A)

Measures the variation or dispersion of a set of values around the mean.

σ = √(∑(x− x̄)2 /n)

Range

The difference between the highest and lowest values in a dataset.

Range = Maximum value - Minimum value

Mean deviation

Measures the average absolute deviation of data points from the mean.

Mean deviation = ∑ X - x̄ / n

Variance (Option B ruled out)

Measures the average of the squared differences from the mean.

Variance = σ2

Sample Mean (Option C): The sample mean is the average value of a set of observations or data points. It is calculated by summing all the values in the sample and dividing the total by the number of observations. The sample mean is often used as an estimate of the population mean.

Median (Option D): It is calculated by arranging the variables in ascending order and taking up the middle value.

This applies when an odd number of variables are given, which is given by

The median is given for variables in even numbers by averaging the two middle variables.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication usually associated with the procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumothorax

Explanation:

  • The procedure shown in the image is central line placement. A potential complication of this procedure is pneumothorax, which occurs when air enters the pleural space, leading to the partial or complete collapse of the lung. This can happen when the central line needle or catheter is inserted into the subclavian or jugular veins.

The central venous catheter is used for fluid, medication, and nutrition administration.

  • The tip is located in the superior vena cava.
  • Order of preference: Subclavian vein > Internal jugular vein > Femoral vein
  • Inside OT: Internal jugular vein
  • Outside OT: Subclavian vein.
  • Complications: Catheter-related sepsis, pneumothorax.

 

Incorrect Options:

Aspiration (Option A) involves inhaling stomach contents or foreign material into the lungs. Although it can occur in various clinical situations, it is not typically associated with central line placement.

Torticollis (Option B), or wry neck, is a condition where the neck muscles involuntarily contract, causing the neck to twist to one side. This is not a complication directly related to central line placement.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (Option D) is a complication typically associated with surgeries or procedures involving the neck or chest, such as thyroid or thoracic surgery. It is not commonly linked to central line placement.

questions.text: A patient with hemophilia on antiretroviral therapy is brought in with altered mental status following complaints of nausea, vomiting and headache. Which of the following medications was he taking?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tipranavir

  • Tipranavir (Protease inhibitor) can cause altered mental status, headache, nausea, vomiting, and intracranial bleeding.

Protease inhibitors (PI): (-navir-)

MOA
  • Inhibits the assembly/packaging of viral proteins
  • Competitively inhibits the action of HIV aspartyl protease

Pharmacokinetics

All are CYP3A4 inhibitors: [Except Nelfinavir (CYP2C9)]

  • Increases toxicity of other drugs
  • Simvastatin: Risk of myopathy
  • Midazolam: Causes respiratory depression

Uses

HIV treatment and 2nd line Post-exposure prophylaxis

Drugs: RAFTISLAND
  • Ritonavir
    • Maximum CYP inhibition → inhibits metabolism of other PI
    • Low-dose ritonavir boosts other protease inhibitors (Lopinavir)
  • Amprenavir
  • Fos-amprenavir
  • Tipranavir
  • Indinavir
  • Saquinavir (least CYP inhibitor)
  • Lopinavir
  • Atazanavir (no dyslipidemia)
  • Nelfinavir
  • Darunavir (maximum bioavailability, taken with food)

Side effects

  • Lipodystrophy
  • Indinavir is a protease inhibitor associated with developing nephrolithiasis
  • Tipranavir can cause altered mental status, headache, intracranial bleeding and hepatotoxicity.
  • Ritonavir causes gastrointestinal disturbances, hyperlipidemia, hepatotoxicity.
  • Atazanavir causes Indirect hyperbilirubinemia (jaundice).
  • Darunavir causes rash, liver function abnormalities, gastrointestinal disturbances

Resistance
  • P-glycoprotein efflux transporter
  • Cross-resistance with other protease inhibitors.

Tenofovir (Option A) is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) commonly used in antiretroviral therapy. While it can cause side effects like nephrotoxicity and bone mineral loss, it is not associated with an increased risk of intracranial hemorrhage or bleeding disorders.

Saquinavir (Option B) is incorrect as it does not affect blood vessels.

Darunavir (Option D) is a protease inhibitor that may cause gastrointestinal disturbances and metabolic abnormalities. However, it does not have a strong association with intracranial hemorrhage or bleeding risks.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient presents with HER-2-positive breast cancer that has become resistant to trastuzumab treatment. The oncologist is considering the next line of treatment. Which of the following options would be the most appropriate choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lapatinib

Explanation:

  • Lapatinib is a dual tyrosine kinase inhibitor that targets both HER-2 and EGFR receptors, and it is commonly used in patients with HER-2-positive breast cancer that is resistant to trastuzumab. It works by blocking the signalling pathways that promote tumour growth.

Management of Stage IV HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer

Type

Description

Treatment

Systemic Therapy

Targeted Therapy: Specific for HER2-positive cancers

Trastuzumab, Pertuzumab, Lapatinib

Chemotherapy: Addresses systemic disease

Taxanes, Anthracyclines, Capecitabine

Hormonal Therapy: For hormone receptor-positive cases (not standalone for HER2-positive)

Tamoxifen, Aromatase Inhibitors (if combined)

Local Therapy

Palliative Surgery: Relieves significant symptoms from primary tumour growth

Mastectomy

Radiotherapy: Controls localised symptoms, especially bone metastases

_

Bone-targeted Therapy

Manages bone metastases and reduces skeletal-related events

Bisphosphonates, Denosumab

 

Incorrect Options:

Sorafenib (Option B) is a multikinase inhibitor that targets angiogenesis pathways involved in tumour growth. However, it lacks specificity for HER-2 positive breast cancer or trastuzumab resistance, making it ineffective for this condition.

Vemurafenib (Option C) is primarily used in melanoma with a BRAF V600E mutation; this drug is not suitable for HER-2-positive breast cancer and is not indicated in this case.

Erlotinib (Option D): Although effective in non-small cell lung cancer with EGFR mutations, erlotinib’s activity in HER-2-positive breast cancer is limited, making it an inappropriate treatment choice for this patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with MDR tuberculosis presents with fatigue, constipation, weight gain, and neck swelling. Which of the following drugs is implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ethionamide

  • The patient’s symptoms suggest hypothyroidism, which can be due to ethionamide.

Ethionamide:

  • It acts similarly to isoniazid, a first-line anti-TB drug (group C drugs in MDR TB treatment).
  • Works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acids, which are essential components of the bacterial cell wall of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • It is used to treat multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).
  • It can cause hepatotoxicity and disrupt thyroid function, leading to these adverse effects.
  • Side effects:
    • Nausea, vomiting, and loss of appetite
    • Hepatotoxicity
    • Neurological symptoms include peripheral neuropathy, dizziness, and confusion. These are treated with pyridoxine (Vitamin B6).
    • Erectile dysfunction
    • Hypothyroidism

Cycloserine (Option A) is associated with neurological and psychiatric side effects, such as depression, anxiety, psychosis, and seizures. It does not cause hypothyroidism or thyroid-related symptoms.

Streptomycin (Option C), an aminoglycoside, is primarily associated with ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity. It has no effect on thyroid function or related symptoms.

Pyrazinamide (Option D) is a first-line anti-TB drug linked to hyperuricemia and hepatotoxicity. It does not cause hypothyroidism or thyroid enlargement.

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient presents with a complaint of per rectal bleeding. The surgeon suspects a possible colorectal pathology and wants to determine the most appropriate investigation for this patient. Which of the following options would be the best choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Colonoscopy

Explanation:

  • Colonoscopy is the most appropriate investigation for a patient presenting with per rectal bleeding. It allows direct visualisation of the colon and rectum, helping to diagnose conditions such as colorectal cancer, diverticular disease, or inflammatory bowel disease, which could be causing the bleeding.

 

Incorrect Options:

CEA levels (Option B): While CEA levels can be useful for monitoring treatment response or detecting recurrence in patients with known colorectal cancer, they are not the primary diagnostic tool for the initial evaluation of per rectal bleeding.

CA-19-9 (Option C) is a tumour marker primarily associated with pancreatic and hepatobiliary malignancies, not colorectal pathology.

CECT (Contrast-enhanced CT scan) (Option D) may be used as an adjunct in specific cases or to assess extra-colonic findings, but it is not the first-line investigation for per rectal bleeding.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with pain in the calf muscles while walking. The pain subsides with rest. Which of the following is not typically seen in intermittent claudication?

choices.text: Cramping in the muscles during exercise
Pain starting on taking the first step
The most common cause is atheroma
The level of occlusion cannot be decided based on symptoms

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pain starting on taking the first step

Explanation:

  • Intermittent claudication typically involves cramping pain in the calf muscles during exercise (such as walking), which subsides with rest. The pain usually starts after walking for a certain distance and is relieved by rest, not immediately upon taking the first step.

 

Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication:

Grade

Description

Grade 0: Asymptomatic

No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise

Grade I: Mild claudication

Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade II: Moderate claudication

Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade III: Severe claudication

Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain

Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion

 

Incorrect Options:

Cramping in the muscles during exercise (Option A): Intermittent claudication is characterised by pain or cramping in the muscles during exercise, usually affecting the lower extremities.

The most common cause is atheroma (Option C): Atheroma, which is the accumulation of fatty plaques in the arteries, is the primary cause of intermittent claudication. The narrowing of the arteries due to atheroma restricts blood flow to the muscles during physical activity, resulting in pain.

Level of occlusion cannot be decided based on symptoms (Option D): The exact level of arterial occlusion cannot be determined by symptoms alone in intermittent claudication. Diagnostic tests, such as ankle-brachial index (ABI) or angiography, are needed to assess the location and extent of arterial blockage.

ABI/ABPI: ABPI (Ankle brachial pressure index) is measured supine by checking the systolic blood pressure in both upper and lower limbs (brachial, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis arteries). The higher value from each limb is used to calculate the ABPI. 

  • This index is calculated as:

ABI / ABPI = Systolic BP in the Ankle/ Systolic BP in the arm
  • Interpretations are as follows:

Value

Interpretation

0.1 - 0.4

Critical limb ischemia

0.5 - 0.9

Intermittent claudication

1.0 - 1.2

Normal

> 1.2

Calcified vessels (seen in patients with DM, End stage renal disease)

questions.text: Among the options provided, which one is NOT acknowledged as a potential complication resulting from a significant blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypernatremia

Explanation:

  • Hypernatremia is not typically a complication of blood transfusion.

Complications of massive blood transfusion:

  • Hypocalcemia: (Option A)
    • Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and other blood products are preserved with citrate, an anticoagulant.
    • Citrate binds to ionised calcium (Ca²⁺) in the recipient's blood, reducing the free calcium level - hypocalcemia.
    • Presents as muscle spasms, cardiac arrhythmias, and decreased myocardial contractility.
  • Metabolic Alkalosis:
    • Citrate is metabolised in the liver to bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻).
    • Rapid transfusion of citrate-containing blood products can overwhelm the liver’s ability to metabolise citrate, leading to an increase in bicarbonate levels.
    • This results in metabolic alkalosis
  • Hyperkalemia:
    • Stored blood undergoes hemolysis over time, releasing potassium from red blood cells into the plasma.
    • Transfusion of large volumes of stored blood can introduce a significant potassium load, causing hyperkalemia.
    • Presents with cardiac arrhythmias, especially in patients with pre-existing kidney dysfunction.
  • Hypothermia: (Option C)
    • Rapid transfusion of cold-stored blood products (typically kept at 1–6°C) can lower the patient’s core body temperature.
  • Coagulopathy:
    • Massive transfusion dilutes clotting factors and platelets, leading to dilutional coagulopathy.
    • Hypothermia and hypocalcemia exacerbate this by impairing the function of coagulation enzymes and platelets.
  • Hypokalemia: (Option B)
    • Post-transfusion, potassium that had leaked out of stored red blood cells can re-enter the cells in vivo.
    • This shift can lead to hypokalemia, especially if the patient has a strong cellular uptake of potassium.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with complaints of profuse, watery stools and an elevated WBC count of 16000 cells/mm3. He has been on treatment with amoxicillin for the past 1 week. What is the treatment of choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fidaxomicin

  • The above scenario is diagnosed as pseudomembranous colitis. The drug of choice is fidaxomicin, which is highly effective for treating severe pseudomembranous enterocolitis caused by Clostridioides difficile.
  • It specifically targets C. difficile, minimising disruption to the gut microbiome and reducing recurrence risk compared to broad-spectrum antibiotics like metronidazole or vancomycin.
  • Mechanism of action:

Fidaxomicin

↓

Binds to the sigma subunit of bacterial RNA polymerase

↓

Disrupts RNA synthesis in C. difficile

↓

Inhibits bacterial protein production

↓

Stops growth and reproduction of C. difficile

Metronidazole (Option A) can be used for severe diarrhea associated with C. difficile but it is not the drug of choice. It is used only if vancomycin or fidaxomicin is not readily accessible.

Ciprofloxacin (Option C): Fluoroquinolones such as ciprofloxacin can potentially cause pseudomembranous colitis.

Bezlotoxumab (Option D) is a monoclonal antibody used in recurrent pseudomembranous colitis. It is not the first-line treatment for this condition.

questions.text:
Which of the following are typically done in breast conservation surgery?


	Wide local excision
	Axillary node dissection
	Frozen section during surgery
	Post-operative radiotherapy (optional)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2, 3

Explanation:

  • In the context of Breast Conservation Surgery (BCS), Radiotherapy (RT) is Not optional but a necessary treatment component.
  • Breast Conservation Therapy (BCT) combines BCS and post-operative radiotherapy (RT). All patients undergoing BCS will receive radiotherapy, which is integral to the treatment. The equation for this therapy is BCS + RT = BCT.
  • Breast-conserving surgery (BCS), also known as lumpectomy, involves removing a breast tumour along with a small margin of surrounding healthy tissue while preserving the majority of the breast. The goal is to remove the cancerous cells while maintaining the breast's appearance and function.

Contraindications for Breast-Conserving Surgery (BCS):

Absolute Contraindications
  • First-trimester Pregnancy
  • Multicentric Disease
  • Diffuse Suspicious microcalcifications on mammogram
  • Extensive DCIS
  • Inflammatory Breast Cancer
  • Tumors for which Clear Margins are Unobtainable with Lumpectomy
  • Homozygous for ATM Mutation

Relative Contraindications
  • Prior Radiation Therapy to the Chest Wall or Breast
  • Active Connective Tissue Disease Involving the Skin (e.g., Scleroderma)
  • Extensive Positive Pathological Margins
  • Large Tumor Size Relative to Breast Size or Tumors Greater Than 5 cm
  • Known or Suspected Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (p53 Mutation)
  • Known or Suspected Genetic Predisposition to Breast Cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2)

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics acts by inhibiting the 50s ribosome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Linezolid

  • Linezolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor (oxazolidinones), that acts by binding to the bacterial 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S subunit, which prevents the formation of a functional 70S initiation complex, ultimately inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis.
  • It is a narrow-spectrum protein synthesis inhibitor that targets only gram-positive bacteria.

 

Linezolid

Aspect

Description

Mechanism of Action
  • It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S ribosomal subunit.
  • It interferes with the formation of the ternary N-formylmethionyl-tRNA (tRNAf-Met)-70S initiation complex, preventing the initiation of protein synthesis.

Spectrum of Activity
  • Gram-positive cocci (aerobic and anaerobic): MRSA, VRSA, VRE, Strep. viridans, Strep. pneumoniae
  • Other sensitive bacteria: Clostridia, B. fragilis, M. tuberculosis.

Common Uses
  • Uncomplicated and complicated skin and soft tissue infections Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAPs)
  • Bacteremia.

Side Effects
  • Mild abdominal pain, nausea and diarrhoea.
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Optic neuritis
  • Bone marrow suppression (monitor platelet count)
  • Caution is advised when used concurrently with MAO inhibitors due to the risk of serotonin syndrome.

Rifampicin (Option B) inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase:

Aztreonam (Option C) works by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Daptomycin (Option D) causes depolarisation of membranes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with a breast lump and is seeking medical evaluation. On examination, a palpable mass is detected in the breast. Which of the following conditions is not associated with the development of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Multiparity

Explanation:

  • Multiparity is not a risk factor for breast carcinoma.

Risk factors for breast carcinoma:

Risk factors

Relative risk
  • Female gender.
  • Increasing age.
  • Germline mutations of high penetrance.
  • Strong family history (>1 first-degree relative, young age, multiple cancers).
  • Personal history of breast cancer.
  • High breast density.

>4.0
  • Germline mutations of moderate penetrance.
  • High-dose radiation to the chest at a young age.
  • Family history (1 first-degree relative).

2.1-4.0
  • Early menarche (age <12 years)
  • Late menopause (age >55 years) (Option B)
  • Late first pregnancy (age >35 years).
  • Nulliparity.
  • Absence of breastfeeding.
  • Exogenous hormone therapy (Option C)
  • Postmenopausal obesity.
  • Physical inactivity.
  • High alcohol consumption (Option A)

1.1-2.0

Relative risk is the likelihood of developing invasive carcinoma compared to women without any risk factors.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with several purpuric skin lesions and is diagnosed with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Which of the following tyrosine kinase inhibitors can be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fostamatinib

  • Fostamatinib is approved for the treatment of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • It is a Tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in the management of chronic idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • The first line of drugs used to manage this condition is steroids. Fostamatinib is only used in patients who do not respond to first-line therapy.

Oprelvekin (Option A) is incorrect because it is an IL 11 analogue and it is used in thrombocytopenia induced due to anti-cancer drug therapy.

Eltrombopag (Option C) is incorrect as it is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist used in idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.

Romiplostim (Option D) ) is incorrect as it is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist used for the treatment of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Frykman and Goldberg's

Explanation:

  • Frykman and Goldberg's procedure is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse. Instead, it is an abdominal approach used for rectal prolapse repair. This procedure involves a transabdominal posterior rectopexy and resection of the redundant left colon.

Operative management of Rectal Prolapse:

  • Rectopexy is fixing the rectum to the sacrum by sutures or mesh after complete mobilisation of the rectum.

Aspect

Abdominal Rectopexy

Perineal Rectopexy

Types
  • Prosthetic or mesh rectopexy-anterior/ posterior- Well's, Ripstein
  • Suture rectopexy- Lahaut
  • Anterior Resection
  • Resection Rectopexy
  • Mucosal sleeve resection (Delrome's) (Option D)
  • Perineal recto sigmoidectomy (Altemeier's) (Option A)
  • Posterior fixation of the rectum of Lockhardt-Mummery
  • Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy
  • Anal encircling (Thiersch) (Option C)

Advantages
  • Fixation of the rectum provides adequate tension to prevent recurrence.
  • Minimally invasive options (laparoscopic or robotic) offer benefits in pain control, hospital stay, and recovery time
  • Lower operative morbidity and mortality, suitable for elderly or medically unfit patients.

 

Disadvantages
  • Requires extensive dissection and fixation, which may have higher morbidity (10%-33%).
  • Risk of mesh-related complications such as erosion, infection, bowel obstruction, and migration.
  • Higher recurrence rates compared to abdominal approaches

questions.text: All of the following drugs are used in the management of thyroid storm except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Aspirin

  • Aspirin is an antiplatelet drug that displaces thyroxine from thyroxine-binding globulin and increases free T3 and T4 levels ,which can be dangerous and worsen thyroid storm.

Management of thyroid storm:

  • Large doses of propylthiouracil (500–1000 mg loading dose and 250 mg every 4 h) should be given orally or by nasogastric tube or per rectum; the drug’s inhibitory action on T4 → T3 conversion makes it the antithyroid drug of choice.
  • If not available, methimazole can be used in doses of 20 mg every 6 h.
  • One hour after the first dose of propylthiouracil, stable iodide (5 drops SSKI every 6 h) is given to block thyroid hormone synthesis via the Wolff-Chaikoff effect (the delay allows the antithyroid drug to prevent the excess iodine from being incorporated into new hormone).
  • Propranolol should also be given to reduce tachycardia and other adrenergic manifestations (60–80 mg PO every 4 h, or 2 mg IV every 4 h). Although other β-adrenergic blockers can be used, high doses of propranolol decrease T4 → T3 conversion, and the doses can be easily adjusted.
  • Short-acting IV esmolol can be used to decrease heart rate while monitoring for signs of heart failure.
  • Additional therapeutic measures include glucocorticoids (e.g., hydrocortisone 300 mg IV bolus, then 100 mg every 8 h), antibiotics if infection is present, cholestyramine to sequester thyroid hormones, cooling, oxygen, and IV fluids.

Propranolol (Option A): Beta blockers are indicated to manage tachycardia in patients with thyroid storm.

Lugol’s Iodine (Option B) inhibits further release of thyroxine.

Propylthiouracil (Option C) inhibitsthe conversion of T4 to T3.

questions.text: What is the sign of the gallbladder seen in this USG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Phrygian cap sign

Explanation:

The image on the ultrasound (USG) shows the Phrygian cap sign, which is a common anatomical variation of the gallbladder.

  • A Phrygian cap is a congenital variant of the gallbladder characterised by a fold at the fundus that resembles a cap.
  • It is a benign condition and is typically asymptomatic, with its appearance being consistent with a cap-like structure on ultrasound.
  • It has no pathological significance and does not affect gallbladder function.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Murphy sign (Option B) is a clinical finding seen in acute cholecystitis, where pain and inspiratory arrest occur upon palpation of the gallbladder. It is not related to the anatomical variation seen in the USG image.

Claw sign (Option C) is a radiological feature seen in intussusception, not related to the gallbladder.

Omega sign (Option D) is a radiological finding observed in choledochal cysts, where the dilated common bile duct forms an "omega" or "figure-of-8" shape. It does not relate to the anomaly shown in the USG image.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of dysuria and intermittent back pain. On examination, there are no palpable abdominal masses or tenderness. An X-ray image of the abdomen is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) PTH adenoma

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is PTH adenoma. Parathyroid hormone (PTH) adenoma can cause hypercalcemia, which may lead to symptoms like dysuria and back pain. Radiologically, PTH adenoma may cause characteristic findings, such as kidney stones or calcifications due to calcium imbalance.

 

Causes of primary hyperparathyroidism :

  • The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary parathyroid adenoma ( most common on the inferior lobe of the right parathyroid). Double adenomas are rare (2-4%).
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia: enlargement of all 4 glands.
  • Parathyroid carcinoma

 

Manifestations of PHPT:

System

Manifestations

Reason

Renal system (stones)

  • Hypercalciuria
  • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Polydipsia, polyuria, nocturia
  • Excretion of excess serum calcium
  • Calcium deposition in renal parenchyma
  • Precipitation of calcium with phosphate or oxalate
  • Inhibition of ADH due to ↑ serum calcium.

Skeletal system
  • Osteoporosis
  • Subperiosteal resorption(radial aspect)
  • Tufting of distal phalanx
  • Brown tumour/ osteitis fibrosa cystica
  • Salt and pepper skull
  • Chondrocalcinosis
  • Pseudo gout
  • Joint pain
  • Calcium resorption
  • Deposition of hemosiderin in the lesion.

Abdomen

(abdominal groans)
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Constipation
  • Peptic ulcer disease: abdominal groans
  • Inhibitory effect of hypercalcemia on gastrointestinal (GI) smooth muscle contraction.
  • Spasm of sphincters
  • Increased gastrin

CNS

(psychiatric moans)
  • Confusion
  • Anxiety
  • Depression
  • Psychosis: psychic moans
  • Some mild memory loss
  • Depression of the nervous system

Muscular system
  • Weakness
  • Fatigue overtones
  • Decreased muscle activity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Wilms' tumour (Option B) is a type of kidney cancer that predominantly affects children. It typically presents as a renal mass on imaging studies, but this would not be the correct diagnosis based on the provided X-ray image.

 

Renal cell carcinoma (Option C) is the most common form of kidney cancer in adults. While it may show up in imaging studies, an X-ray alone is insufficient to conclusively diagnose renal cell carcinoma.

 

Lipoma (Option D) is a benign tumour made up of fatty tissue. On imaging, it typically appears as a well-defined soft tissue mass. However, based on the X-ray image provided, a lipoma would not be the most likely diagnosis.

MR vaccine administered intramuscularly along with oral vitamin A at 9 months

questions.text: 2 doctors were asked to report 100 X-rays and a Kappa value of 0.71; what is interpretation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Good

Explanation:

Interpretation of a Kappa value of 0.71 between two doctors reporting 100 X-rays is considered Good, indicating a reliable level of agreement between the observers.

The Kappa statistic is a measure of inter-rater agreement or reliability between two observers. It ranges from -1 to 1, where:

  • 1 indicates perfect agreement
  • O indicates agreement expected by chance
  • -1 indicates perfect disagreement.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in the floor of the mouth. Upon examination, the swelling appears as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ranula

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Ranula, a specific type of mucus retention cyst that develops on the floor of the mouth, typically caused by blockage or rupture of the ducts of the sublingual or submandibular glands. This leads to mucus accumulation and the formation of a cystic swelling.

Ranula

Definition

Ranulas are a type of extravasation mucocele caused by the rupture of the main duct or obstructed acini of the sublingual gland. They appear as bluish swellings on the floor of the mouth and resemble the belly of a frog.

Location
  • Commonly found in the anterior floor of the mouth.
  • When it extends through the mylohyoid muscle, it presents as a submental swelling known as a "plunging ranula."

Symptoms

Typically soft, fluctuant, and painless unless infected.

Diagnosis
  • Confirmed through Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
  • Ultrasound
  • Aspiration of thick, sticky saliva differentiates it from a lymphangioma.

Treatment
  • Removal of the sublingual gland is preferred.
  • Incision, drainage, and marsupialisation have low success rates. Although marsupialisation is often adequate, it has a higher recurrence rate compared to sublingual gland excision.
  • OK-432 injection
  • Botulinum toxin injections

Incorrect Options:

Cystic hygroma (Option A) is a congenital abnormality of the lymphatic system, usually presenting as a soft, cystic swelling in the neck area. It is not typically found on the floor of the mouth.

Dermoid (Option C) cysts are developmental cysts that contain various tissues, such as skin, hair follicles, and sebaceous glands. While they can occur on the floor of the mouth, they are not exclusive to this region.

Branchial cysts (Option D) are congenital cysts that form from remnants of the branchial apparatus. They are primarily found in the neck area and are not commonly seen on the floor of the mouth.

questions.text: After laparoscopic cholecystectomy, what should the expected urine output be in a patient with normal renal function?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/min

Explanation:

The normal urine output is around 1500 ml/day for a healthy adult, which roughly translates to 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour. (1x70(kg)x24(hours) ~ 1700 ml).

  • Minimum urine output to excrete end products of protein metabolism: 500ml/day
  • Ideal urine output in a normal 70kg adult: 1500 ml

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with perineural invasion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Adenoid cystic carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known for its tendency to invade along nerves (perineural invasion), which is a key feature of its aggressive nature.

Adenoid cystic carcinoma:

  • This type of cancer primarily affects the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands, with approximately half of the cases occurring in minor salivary glands, especially in the palate.
  • It is relatively rare in the parotid gland.
  • Clinical features:
    • Facial nerve palsy
    • Pain or numbness
    • High risk of distant metastasis, especially - lung.

Histopathology of adenoid cystic carcinoma:

  • Type: Unencapsulated, infiltrative biphasic neoplasm.
  • Cell Types: Variable proportions of epithelial and myoepithelial cells.
  • Patterns:
    • Cribriform: Cells around sharply punched-out cylindromatous spaces with basophilic matrix. It is the most common type and has a better prognosis.
    • Tubular: Bilayered tubules with a true lumen.
    • Solid: Sheets and nests of tumour cells without a lumen. Carries poor prognosis.
  • Nuclear Features: Small, angulated, hyperchromatic nuclei with scant cytoplasm.
  • Perineural Invasion: Common in adenoid cystic carcinoma.
  • High-Grade Transformation: Can occur
  • Immunohistochemistry:
    • Ductal cells: Positive for c-KIT.
    • Myoepithelial cells: Positive for p63 and SMA.

Incorrect Options:

Pleomorphic adenoma (Option B): This tumour generally does not show perineural invasion unless it undergoes a malignant transformation. Even in cases of malignancy, vascular invasion is more commonly seen than perineural invasion.

Mucoepidermoid tumour (Option C): While mucoepidermoid tumours can invade surrounding tissues, including nerves, perineural invasion is less common compared to adenoid cystic carcinoma.

Pancreatic cancer (Option D) can invade adjacent structures and spread to distant organs, but perineural invasion is not a characteristic feature of this type of cancer.

questions.text: All are anterior to the third part of the duodenum except?
questions.solution:

  • The fundus of the gallbladder, however, is located in the right hypochondrium, much higher than the third part of the duodenum, and thus is not anterior to it.

questions.text: What is the minimum platelet count necessary for most surgical procedures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 50,000 (10^9/L)

Explanation:

  • A platelet count of at least 50,000 (10^9/L) is generally considered the minimum for performing most surgical procedures safely, as it helps minimise the risk of bleeding.

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines (2015):

  • For invasive procedures or surgery: Platelet counts should be increased above 50,000/μL.
  • For patients at high risk of bleeding: A platelet count of 50,000-75,000/μL is considered appropriate.
  • For surgery at critical sites: A platelet count of > 100,000/μL is recommended.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of dysentery for 6 weeks complains of pain in the right upper abdomen. On ultrasound, a hypoechoic hyperdense lesion is seen in the liver. Based on the given image, identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Amoebic liver abscess

Explanation:

The ultrasound image shows a hypoechoic hyperdense lesion in the liver. Given the patient's clinical history of dysentery, the most likely diagnosis is an amoebic liver abscess.

  • Amoebic liver abscess is caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica, typically contracted through the ingestion of contaminated food or water.
  • On ultrasound, the abscess appears as a well-defined, hypoechoic lesion with variable internal echoes. Mild to moderate oedema in the surrounding liver parenchyma may also be seen.

Feature

Amebic Abscess

Pyogenic Abscess

Age

20–40 years

>50 years

Male-to-Female Ratio

≥10:1

1.5:1

Solitary vs Multiple

Solitary 80%

Solitary 50%

Location

Usually right liver

Usually right liver

Travel in Endemic Area

Yes

No

Uncommon (∼2%)

More common (∼27%)

Common

Common

Uncommon

Common

Uncommon

Common

Common

Common

No

Yes

Incorrect Options:

Pyogenic liver abscess (Option B): A pyogenic liver abscess, caused by bacterial infections like Escherichia coli or Klebsiella pneumoniae, usually presents as multiple hypoechoic lesions on ultrasound, rather than the single lesion shown here. Inflammation in the surrounding liver parenchyma may also be evident.

Hydatid cyst (Option C): Caused by the larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus, hydatid cysts typically appear as well-defined, anechoic, or hypoechoic lesions, often with multiple daughter cysts inside. The provided image shows a single hypoechoic hyperdense lesion, which is inconsistent with a hydatid cyst.

Hemangioma (Option D): Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumours that commonly occur in the liver. They usually appear as hyperechoic lesions with posterior acoustic enhancement on ultrasound. The lesion in the provided image, being hypoechoic and hyperdense, does not fit the typical characteristics of a hemangioma.

questions.text: What is the primary prognostic factor that significantly influences the outcome of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lymph node

Explanation:

The involvement of lymph nodes, particularly axillary lymph nodes, is the most important prognostic factor for breast cancer and significantly influences treatment decisions and overall survival.

  • In breast cancer, the status of the axillary lymph nodes is the most significant prognostic factor.
  • In metastatic breast cancer, the most important prognostic factor is the status of estrogen receptors (ER) and progesterone receptors (PR).

 

Disease factors that influence prognosis

Histologic Subtypes
  • Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC): Prognosis varies by grade and molecular markers.
  • Invasive Lobular Carcinoma (ILC): Intermediate prognosis.
  • Tubular and Mucinous Carcinomas: Best prognosis.
  • Basal-like Breast Cancer: Aggressive, triple-negative, no targeted treatments.
  • Other Subtypes: Medullary, cribriform, papillary, adenoid cystic, and metaplastic carcinomas vary in prognosis.

Tumor Size & Lymph Node
  • Pathologic staging (tumour size, lymph nodes) guides prognosis and treatment.
  • Larger tumours and positive lymph nodes = worse prognosis

Molecular Markers
  • Hormone Receptors (ER, PR): ER-positive = better prognosis, responsive to endocrine therapy.
  • HER-2 Status: HER-2 positive = aggressive but treatable with targeted therapies.

Patient factors that influence prognosis

Age

Younger, particularly premenopausal women, may have higher local recurrence rates post-surgery, but radiation therapy can reduce this risk.

BRCA Mutation

Generally more aggressive and associated with poorer prognosis.

Family History

A strong family history may indicate inherited susceptibility and potentially a worse prognosis.

Prior Breast Cancer History

Previous breast cancer can negatively influence the prognosis of a new diagnosis.

Lifestyle Factors

Obesity and inactivity are linked to increased recurrence risk and may affect overall prognosis.

Treatment Adherence

Non-compliance can worsen prognosis.

questions.text: During the examination of a patient with a hernia, a surgeon forcefully pushes the hernial sac back into the abdominal cavity without directly pushing back the contents first. What type of hernia has occurred as a result of this, which is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reduction en masse

Explanation:

  • Reduction en masse refers to a situation where the hernia sac is forcibly pushed back into the abdominal cavity without properly reducing or returning the herniated contents to their normal position.
  • This can occur when the hernia sac gets stuck or incarcerated within the abdominal wall opening.

Reduction en masse:

  • The condition reduction en masse is a complication associated with an inguinal hernia.
  • In this condition, the herniated sac is inside the abdominal wall but its contents are strangulated.
  • Clinical features:
    • Persistent pain in the lower abdomen
    • Localised or generalised peritonitis
    • Absence of appreciable hernia externally Intestinal obstruction and strangulation

Strangulated Hernia (Option A): This occurs when the blood supply to the herniated contents is cut off, leading to ischemia. It is different from reduction en masse as the hernia contents remain in the hernial sac.

Sliding hernia (Option C):

  • Happens when part of the stomach slides up through the diaphragm opening (hiatus) into the chest cavity, essentially sharing a wall with the hernia sac formed by the diaphragm, causing it to protrude alongside the esophagus
  • This is the most common type of hiatal hernia.

Maydl's hernia (Option D): This is a rare hernia where two loops of bowel are within the hernial sac, with the loop between them (inside the abdomen) being at risk of strangulation.

questions.text: The patient presented with ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, Horner's syndrome, and Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body. Which artery is involved in the syndrome based on clinical features?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, Horner's syndrome, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body is suggestive lateral medullary syndrome also called the Wallenberg syndrome.
  • The occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral medullary syndrome also called the Wallenberg syndrome.

 

Wallenberg syndrome:

  • Also known as Lateral medullary syndrome

 

Pathology:

  • Blockage of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.
  • It supplies areas behind the inferior olivary nucleus.
  • Damage to the lateral segment of the medulla posterior to the inferior olivary nucleus.

Clinical manifestation:

Anatomical location

Presenting clinical feature

Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of the soft palate, pharynx, and larynx

Vestibular nuclei
