Inferior cerebellar peduncle, spino cerebellar tracts, and part of cerebellum

Ipsilateral ataxia

Sympathetic fibres descend from the hypothalamus to cells in the lateral horn of spinal cord

Horner’s syndrome, comprising ptosis, enophthalmos, miosis, and anhydrosis

 

 

 

Superior cerebellar artery (Option B):

  • The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior portion of the cerebellum and parts of the midbrain.
  • While it can lead to symptoms like ataxia or vertigo, it doesn’t typically cause the specific signs described (ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, Horner's syndrome, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature in the body).

Basilar artery (Option C): NA blockage in the basilar artery can lead to locked-in syndrome or other pontine deficits

Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) (Option D): AICA strokes can cause symptoms like vertigo, ataxia, and facial weakness.

questions.text:
Assertion: RMP depends on proteins and phosphate ions.

Reason: Diffusion potential can be calculated using Nernst equation.

Choose the best statement regarding the assertion and reason.

choices.text: Both true, Reason is not the explanation of assertion
Both true, Reason is the explanation of assertion

questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option A) Both true, Reason is not the explanation of assertion

Explanation:

  • The assertion states that the resting membrane potential (RMP) depends on proteins and phosphate ions. This is true because the RMP is primarily maintained by the selective permeability of the cell membrane to different ions, such as potassium (K+), sodium (Na+), chloride (Cl-), and negatively charged proteins. These ions contribute to the electrical charge across the membrane and affect the RMP.
  • The Nernst equation calculates the Nernst potential (EMF) for a single, univalent ion (an ion with a +1 or -1 charge) at normal body temperature (37°C)

  • The Nernst potential magnitude depends on the ion concentration ratio across the membrane; larger differences result in higher potentials.
  • The diffusion potential contributes to the overall electrical potential difference across the membrane, including the RMP.
  • Therefore, both the assertion and the reason are true, but the reason does not explain the assertion.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is/are true regarding the mechanism by which PTH elevates blood calcium levels?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option D) All are true

Explanation:

PTH and Calcium regulation:

Factor

Description

Effect on Calcium Levels

PTH
  • A hormone secreted by the parathyroid glands in response to low extracellular calcium levels.

Increases

Bone Resorption

  • PTH stimulates osteoblasts, which signal osteoclasts to break down bone tissue, releasing calcium and phosphate into the bloodstream. (Option B)

Increases

Renal Excretion

  • PTH increases calcium reabsorption in the renal tubules, reducing calcium loss through urine. (Option A)
  • PTH decreases phosphate reabsorption in the kidneys.

Increases

Intestinal Absorption

  • PTH indirectly enhances calcium and phosphate absorption in the intestines.
  • This active form of vitamin D promotes the formation of calbindin, a calcium-binding protein, in intestinal cells.

Increases

Vitamin D
  • While not directly regulated by PTH, vitamin D plays a crucial role in calcium regulation. Vitamin D must be converted to its active form, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, in the kidneys. PTH is essential for this conversion. (Option C)

Increases

questions.text: Carbon monoxide causes which type of hypoxia?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Anemic Hypoxia

Explanation:

  • Anemic hypoxia results from insufficient or impaired hemoglobin thus leading to decreased oxygen transport and causing hypoxia.

Anemic Hypoxia

Definition: Normal PO2 of arterial blood but inadequate hemoglobin (Hb) to carry O2.

Causes:

  • Anaemia (decreased Hb concentration)
  • Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning
  • Altered Hb (e.g., Methemoglobin)

Mechanism:

  • Normal PO2: PO2 in inspired air and arterial blood is normal.
  • Reduced O2 Transport: Inadequate Hb reduces O2 supply to tissues.
  • Mild/Moderate Anemia: Increased 2,3-DPG in red cells compensates for low Hb; severe hypoxia during exercise.
  • CO Poisoning:
    • CO binds to Hb with 210 times greater affinity than O2, forming carboxyhemoglobin (COHb).
    • Slow release of CO from COHb prevents O2 binding.
  • Normal Hb content, but Hb is unavailable for O2 transport.
  • Hb-dissociation curve shifts left, decreasing O2 release to tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Hypoxic hypoxia (Option B): It is caused by low arterial PO2 due to factors like high altitude or respiratory disease, not related to haemoglobin levels

Stagnant hypoxia (Option C): It occurs due to reduced blood flow or cardiac output, causing inadequate tissue perfusion despite normal arterial PO2

Histotoxic hypoxia (Option D): It Involves impaired cellular utilization of oxygen, often due to toxins, despite normal oxygen supply and delivery

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than with carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Dilutional hyponatremia

Explanation:

  • Dilutional hyponatremia is a side effect more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine rather than carbamazepine. Oxcarbazepine has a greater propensity to cause hyponatremia due to its stronger influence on antidiuretic hormone secretion.

Carbamazepine

  • Mechanism of Action: Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels to reduce high-frequency neuronal discharges.
  • Indications:
    • Trigeminal neuralgia
    • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS)
    • Partial seizures
    • Bipolar disorder
  • Adverse Effects:
    • Hepatotoxicity (Option A): Commonly seen with carbamazepine due to its metabolism through hepatic enzymes.
    • Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (Option B): A rare but severe hypersensitivity reaction, especially in individuals with the HLA-B*1502 allele.
    • Hematologic Toxicity: Agranulocytosis, aplastic anemia, and thrombocytopenia (Option C).
    • Neurotoxicity: Sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, and ataxia.
    • Water Retention and Hyponatremia: Less frequent compared to oxcarbazepine.
    • Teratogenicity: Increased risk of fetal malformations (e.g., neural tube defects).

Oxcarbazepine:

  • A structural derivative of carbamazepine with a similar mechanism but a better safety profile.
  • Causes fewer hematologic and hepatic side effects.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to the zero phase of the action potential in the SA node?

choices.text: Sodium influx via voltage-gated sodium channels
Influx of both sodium and calcium

questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option A) Calcium influx only

Explanation:

  • The L-type Ca2+ channels are responsible for the slow depolarization (Phase 0) in nodal cells.

 

Incorrect Options:

Sodium influx via voltage-gated sodium channels (Option B): It occurs in atrial/ventricular myocytes and Purkinje fibres. Hence, the option is incorrect.

Potassium efflux (Option C): It is responsible for repolarization during phase 3. Hence, this option is incorrect.

Influx of both sodium and calcium (Option D): Sodium influx via "funny current" (If) contributes to the slow depolarization of phase 4. Hence, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Blood pressure changes in the radial artery were measured while performing a valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the reason for the initial rise in blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Increase in aortic pressure

Explanation:

Valsalva Maneuver

Phase I (onset of strain)
  • There is a transient increase in blood pressure that lasts for a few seconds.
  • This occurs due to increased intrathoracic pressure adding to the aortic pressure.

Phase II (phase of straining)
  • Venous return initially decreases, lowering cardiac output and blood pressure for 4 seconds.
  • Later, blood pressure returns to normal due to increased peripheral resistance from sympathetic vasoconstriction.
  • Heart rate steadily increases due to vagal withdrawal and sympathetic activation.

Phase III
  • This phase occurs following the release of strain characterized by a transient decrease in blood pressure lasting for a few seconds.
  • This is caused by the mechanical displacement of blood to the pulmonary vascular bed, which was under increased intrathoracic pressure.
  • There is little change in heart rate.

Phase IV
  • Occurs after further release of strain; blood pressure slowly increases, and heart rate decreases for about a minute.
  • This is due to an increase in venous return, stroke volume, and cardiac output.

questions.text: A patient presented to the outpatient department with fatigue, and exertional and nocturnal dyspnoea. On examination, bilateral pedal oedema is noted. Auscultation reveals an S3 gallop and rales in both the lungs. Which of the following drugs can be used to prevent the progression of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C - Captopril

  • The presence of fatigue, exertional dyspnea, pedal edema, and an S3 gallop points towards heart failure. In this case, captopril (an ACE inhibitor) can be used to help prevent disease progression.

Drugs to prevent the progression of heart failure:

  • Inotropic drugs like digoxin
  • Diuretics
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Beta-blockers
  • Vasodilators like hydralazine, nitroprusside
  • Synthetic BNP: nesiritide
  • Neprilysin inhibitor: Sacubitril
  • Aldosterone antagonists
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors like dapagliflozin
  • The first drugs patient is started on as soon as a diagnosis of Heart failure is made are: ACE inhibitors, ARBs, or ARNI (Angiotensin Receptor/Neprilysin Inhibitor).
  • There are many contraindications to beta-blockers, so the patient is usually started on a very low dose.

Verapamil (Option A) is a Calcium channel blocker, that is absolutely contraindicated in CHF.

Digoxin (Option B) is incorrect as it has no role in decreasing mortality in heart failure. It only increases the force of contraction.

Carvedilol (Option D) is incorrect as there are many contraindications to beta blockers, and they are not considered first line.

questions.text:
Arrange the following parts of the sarcomere from the periphery to center.


	Z line
	M line
	A band
	H zone
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option A) 1,3,4,2

Explanation:

  • A band: The dark band, anisotropic to polarized light. It contains the entire length of the myosin filaments. The ends of the actin filaments also overlap with the myosin filaments in this band.
  • I band: The light band, isotropic to polarized light. It contains only actin filaments.
  • Z disk: A structure composed of filamentous proteins (alpha-actinin) that bisects the I band. Actin filaments attach to the Z disk and extend from it in both directions to interdigitate with myosin filaments. Z disks also pass from myofibril to myofibril, attaching them together across the muscle fiber.
  • H zone: Located at the center of the A band, this zone contains only myosin filaments and appears lighter than the rest of the A band.
  • M line: A structure that runs down the center of the H zone, providing structural support for the myosin filaments.

questions.text: Which of the following pathogens correctly matches its intrinsic drug resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fluconazole - Candida krusei

  • Fluconazole is an antifungal (azole) that does not work on Candida krusei (resistance is due to efflux pump overexpression)
  • Mechanism of action: Inhibits ergosterol synthesis, affecting cell membrane function.
  • Use: Candida infections.
  • Adverse Effect: QT prolongation

Amphotericin B - Candida glabrata (Option B) is incorrect as amphotericin B is effective against Candida glabrata.

Voriconazole - Aspergillus fumigatus (Option C) is incorrect as voriconazole is effective against Aspergillus fumigatus.

Itraconazole - Sporothrix (Option D) is incorrect as itraconazole is effective against Sporothrix.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. There was a history of a local doctor prescribing him some drugs for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) a few weeks ago, and he suddenly stopped taking them. On investigations, there was a serum potassium (K) level of 6.5 mEq/L, sodium (Na) level of 139 mEq/L, signs of dehydration, hypotension (90/40), and a blood glucose level of 40 mg/dL. Which of the following drugs should be used for the life-saving treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hydrocortisone

  • The patient's current presentation is likely due to Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Adrenal (HPA) axis suppression from abrupt discontinuation of steroids, and hydrocortisone is administered as it provides both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid effects.
  • Hydrocortisone, a synthetic glucocorticoid, has both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid effects.

Effects of corticosteroids on the body:

  • Anti-inflammatory effects: It inhibits inflammatory mediators, such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes, and suppresses inflammatory cytokine production.
  • Immunosuppressive effects: Inhibition of immune cell proliferation and function, including T-cells, B-cells, and macrophages
  • Metabolic effects: Increased gluconeogenesis, lipolysis, and protein catabolism, leading to hyperglycemia, insulin resistance, and muscle wasting
  • Mineralocorticoid effects: Promotion of sodium and water retention, potassium excretion, and blood pressure elevation (minimal in prednisone due to low mineralocorticoid activity).

Sodium bicarbonate (Option B): has no role in the initial management of HPA axis suppression.

Insulin (Option C): Glucocorticoid deficiency causes hypoglycemia; therefore treatment of choice is not insulin.

Hypertonic Saline (Option D) has no role in the initial management of HPA axis suppression.

questions.text: Which of the following newly approved anti-diabetic drugs can be given for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and impaired renal function?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Empagliflozin

Diabetic patients with heart failure best benefit from adding a group of drugs called SGLT-2 (sodium-glucose cotransporter-2) inhibitors, and empagliflozin falls in this group.

  • By inhibiting the SGLT-2 receptors in the proximal tubule of the kidneys, glucose (and sodium) reabsorption can be prevented.
  • Since both sodium and glucose are osmotic molecules, increasing their excretion draws out more water, making these drugs effective in patients with heart failure.

Drugs:

  • Dapagliflozin.
  • Empagliflozin.
  • Canagliflozin.
  • Ertugliflozin.

Linagliptin (Option B) is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It is of no use in chronic heart failure.

Rosiglitazone (Option C) is a medication used in the management and treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It is in the thiazolidinediones class of medications. It is of no use in chronic heart failure.

Insulin Degludec (Option D) has no use in chronic heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of decerebrate rigidity according to the Herrington classification?

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Mid-collicular lesion can lead to decerebrate rigidity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

Explanation:

Decerebrate rigidity primarily affects the extensor muscles of the limbs, leading to the characteristic posture of rigid extension. It does not affect all the muscles of the body equally.

According to the Herrington classification, decerebrate rigidity is a form of abnormal muscle tone that occurs due to damage or dysfunction in the medulla resulting in increased activity of motoneurons that facilitate stretch reflexes.

Facilitation of stretch reflexes occurs due to two mechanisms:

  • Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool in general.
  • Increased rate of γ motor neuron discharge.

Producing a mid-collicular lesion in an experimental animal results in decerebration.

Feature

Decerebrate Rigidity

Decorticate Rigidity

Definition

A state of severe hypertonia characterized by extension of all four limbs.

A state in which the upper extremities are flexed and the lower extremities are extended.

Cause

Damage to the lower midbrain and upper pons

Damage to the upper midbrain

Mechanism

Loss of descending inhibition to the pontine reticular system causes overactivity of this system, which excites antigravity muscles.

Rubrospinal tract excitation of flexor muscles in the upper extremities results in flexion due to damage above the red nucleus.

Posture

Arms adducted and extended

Forearms pronated

Wrists and fingers flexed

Legs extended

Feet plantar flexed

Arms adducted and flexed

Wrists and fingers flexed

Legs extended

Plantar flexion of the feet

Clinical Significance

Severe brain stem damage; poor prognosis

Better prognosis than decerebrate rigidity

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and eschar (as shown in the image below). What will be the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Doxycycline

Explanation:

The given clinical picture with fever and eschar (site of the bite) is suggestive of mild to moderate Scrub Typhus in which only Doxycycline is given.

 

Scrub typhus

Causative agent 

Orientia tsutsugamushi (bacteria)

Transmission 

Chiggers (larval mites)

Vector 

Trombiculid mite (Leptotrombidium)

Geographical distribution 

Endemic in the “tsutsugamushi triangle” (parts of Asia, Australia, Pacific Islands).

Clinical manifestations

Fever, headache, muscle pain, eschar (dark, scab-like lesion at the site of bite), and lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis 

Serological tests (ELISA, immunofluorescence) and molecular methods (PCR).

Treatment 

Antibiotics (Doxycycline, Azithromycin)

Prevention 

Avoid mite-infested areas, wearing protective clothing, and using insect repellants.

Complications 

Organ failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), neurological complications.

 

Doxycycline + Azithromycin (Option B) (Dual Therapy) is given in severe scrub typhus, which presents with high-grade fever, body pain, and end-organ damage.

Ceftriaxone + Doxycycline (Option C) is not preferred in scrub typhus.

Ceftriaxone (Option D) is incorrect because Doxycycline is a preferred drug in this case.
